City.
2. The City Manager shall attend all meetings of the Council, shall keep the Council informed as to
the affairs of the City, and shall recommend to the Council such actions as may be necessary or
expedient for the welfare of the City. The City Manager shall be entitled to notice of all meetings
of the Council. (1963 Code, §4.02)
B. Employees:
1. The City Manager shall appoint and remove all directors of departments, and exercise control of
all departments and divisions of the City that may be created by the Council, with the exception
of those under the jurisdiction of the Fire and Police Commission. All appointments made by the
City Manager shall be within the authorization of the Council, at such compensation as may be
set by the Council. All actions by the City Manager shall be in conformance with the "Woodstock
Personnel Manual". All employees shall perform their duties subject to the direction of the City
Manager or that of the superior to whom the City Manager may assign such employee. The City
Manager may delegate to any other official or employee the authority to hire or discharge any
employees so authorized.
2. Any employee assigned to any department or division may be required to perform work in any
other department or division as requested by the City Manager. (1963 Code, §4.03; 1986 Code)
C. Officers And Departments:
1. The City Manager shall report to the Council each appointment or removal made by him/her as
soon as possible after the appointment or removal.
2. Every administrative department of the City shall be under the supervision and control of the
City Manager. (1963 Code, §4.04; 1986 Code)
D. Inventories, Property: The City Manager shall keep a current inventory showing all real personal
property of the City and its location and shall be responsible for the care and custody of all such
property including equipment, buildings, parks and all other City property, which is not by law
assigned to some other officer or body for care and control. (1963 Code, §4.09)
E. Other Duties: The City Manager shall also:
1. Perform such duties in connection with the administration of the licensing and control of the sale
of alcoholic liquor within the City as may from time to time be delegated to him/her by the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner.
2. Issue all licenses and permits not otherwise provided for by law.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 46/525
3. Appoint an assistant or assistants whose number shall be authorized by the City Council.
4. Maintain an office in the City Hall and spend such time in the performance of his duties as may
be required by the Council.
5. Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by article 5 of the Illinois Municipal Code or by
ordinance or resolution of the Council. (1963 Code, §4.14; amd. Ord. 788A, 9-17-1968; Ord.
821, 5-20-1969)
1.6A.5: DUTIES REGARDING MUNICIPAL FINANCES:
A. Contracts:
1. The city manager shall examine all proposed contracts to which the city may be a party, and
may sign on behalf of the city any contract authorized by the council. In the absence of such
authorization, all contracts shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk.
2. The city manager shall see that all terms of any contract to which the city is a party are fully
performed by all parties thereto. (1963 Code, §4.05)
B. Purchases: The city manager shall be the general purchasing agent of the city and, except where
specific provision to the contrary is made by law or by the council, he shall make all purchases of
supplies, materials and equipment authorized by the council in the annual appropriation ordinance
or annual budget in the manner prescribed by, and subject to limitation imposed by, law; provided,
on purchases of more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), he shall first procure the approval of
the city council before making such purchases and on purchases of more than two thousand five
hundred dollars ($2,500.00), he shall obtain at least three (3) prices for the respective item to be
purchased. (Ord. 06-0-16, 3-7-2006)
C. Appropriation And Levies:
1. The city manager shall cause to be prepared each year the annual appropriation ordinance or
annual budget within the time required by law.
2. The city manager shall cause to be prepared the annual tax levy ordinance for passage and file
a certified copy of it with the county clerk within the time required by law. (1963 Code, §4.07;
amd. 1986 Code)
3. The city manager shall keep current accounts of the amounts appropriated and budgeted and
the amounts spent out of each budget account, showing the unexpended balances at all times.
(1963 Code, §4.07)
D. Accounts: The city manager shall keep current accounts showing at all times the fiscal condition of
the city, including the current and anticipated revenue of all municipal funds and accounts; and
shall supervise collection of all money due the city. (1963 Code, §4.08)
1.6A.6: REPORTS AND DOCUMENTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 47/525
A. Reports And Publications: The city manager shall supervise the publication of all notices,
ordinances or other documents required by law to be published, and shall prepare or cause to be
prepared all reports which the city or any city official is required by law to prepare. (1963 Code,
§4.10)
B. Records And Certificates:
1. The city manager shall prepare and have custody of all municipal records required by law to be
kept by the city but not required to be kept by a specific officer. Where the law makes it the duty
of a specific officer to keep or maintain records, the city manager shall make available to such
officer all necessary clerical assistance for the preparation of such records and shall make
available a place for the custody of such records. The city manager shall make available to the
city clerk stenographic or clerical assistance necessary for the preparation of the journal of city
council proceedings, the record of ordinances and all other documents which by law the city
clerk is required to keep. He shall perform similar service for the city treasurer in the
maintenance of bond registers, and all other records or documents which by law the city
treasurer is required to keep or prepare.
2. Where the law requires or provides for certification of any records or documents by any officer of
the city, the city manager shall cause such records or documents to be properly prepared and
presented to such officer for his signature. (1963 Code, §4.12)
C. Maps And Plats: The city manager shall cause to be kept a complete set of maps and plats
showing the location of all city utilities and other municipal properties, all streets and other public
places, and all lots or parcels of land subdivided according to law. (1963 Code, §4.13)
ARTICLE B. CITY CLERK
1.6B.1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
A. The city clerk shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council for a
four (4) year term and shall serve until his/her successor is appointed and qualified as provided by
law.
B. The term of the city clerk shall commence at the first regular or special meeting of the city council in
the month of May following the election of the mayor. (Ord. 2581, 8-15-1995)
1.6B.2: OATH:
The city clerk shall take the oath as required by the Illinois Compiled Statutes. (1986 Code)
1.6B.3: BOND:
Upon entering the duties of his/her office, the city clerk shall execute a bond in the amount and with
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 48/525
such sureties as may be required by the council conditioned upon the faithful performance of his/her
duties1. (1986 Code)
1.6B.4: COMPENSATION:
The salary of the city clerk shall be as determined by the city council from time to time. (Ord. 01-0-13,
5-1-2001)
1.6B.5: DUTIES:
A. Records: The city clerk shall keep all papers belonging to the municipality the custody and control
of which are not given to other officers. The clerk shall attend all meetings of the city council and
keep a full record of their proceedings in the journal. The record of those proceedings shall be
made available for public inspection within ten (10) days after being approved or accepted by the
city council as the official minutes of their proceedings. (Ord. 2581, 8-15-1995)
B. Seal And Attest Documents: The city clerk shall seal and attest all ordinances and resolutions of
the city council, contracts of the city and all licenses, permits and all other such documents that
require this formality.
C. Corporate Seal: The city clerk shall be the custodian of the city's seal and shall affix its impression
on documents whenever required.
D. Warrants: The city clerk shall, upon the allowance of any account or claim by the city council, sign a
warrant therefor upon the city treasury payable to the order of the claimant, which warrant, when
signed by the mayor and the city clerk, shall be paid by the city treasurer. He shall keep in a
suitable book an accurate list of all warrants drawn on the treasury, stating the date, number and
account thereof and the name of the person in whose favor drawn. (1986 Code)
E. (Rep. by Ord. 2581, 8-15-1995)
F. Record Of Ordinances: All ordinances passed by the city council shall be deposited in the office of
the city clerk and shall be duly recorded by the clerk in the record book of ordinances and
appropriately indexed by title or subject.
The city clerk shall file and carefully preserve the originals of all ordinances deposited in his office.
He may correct errors in numbering of any section of any ordinances, and insert the proper
numbers and correct clerical mistakes. The clerk shall make at the foot of the record of each
ordinance recorded a memorandum of the date of its passage and the date of its publication, when
required to be published, which record, memorandum or certified copy thereof shall be deemed
official evidence of the passage and legal publication of such ordinances for all purposes
whatsoever.
G. Records On File: The city clerk shall maintain on file three (3) copies of all codes, regulations or
public records adopted either in this code or otherwise by the city council by reference and there
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 49/525
kept available for public use, inspection and examination. (1986 Code)
H. Additional Duties: In addition to the duties herein provided, the city clerk shall perform such other
duties and functions required by law or ordinance or otherwise assigned by the mayor and city
council. (Ord. 2581, 8-15-1995)
I. Deputy Clerks:
1. It is hereby authorized that the positions of chief deputy clerk and deputy clerk are hereby
established. No person shall be eligible to be appointed chief deputy clerk who is not, at the time
of his or her appointment, a member of the administrative staff of the city.
2. The salary of the chief deputy clerk and deputy clerk shall be as determined by the city council
from time to time. (Ord. 05-0-77, 8-16-2005)
ARTICLE C. CITY TREASURER
1.6C.1: APPOINTMENT:
The City Treasurer shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the approval of the City Council. (Ord. 822,
5-20-69)
1.6C.2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
The City Treasurer shall give bond in the amount as set out in Section 1.6.3 of this Code, with sureties
to be approved by the Council. The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance by the
Treasurer of his duties of office, and to indemnify the City for any loss due to any neglect of duty or
wrongful act on the part of the Treasurer. (1963 Code, §6.02; amd. Ord. 1639, 2-3-81)
1.6C.3: GENERAL DUTIES:
A. Generally: The City Treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed by law or by
ordinance. He shall receive all money paid into the City, either directly from the person paying it or
from the hands of such other officer as may receive it, and he shall pay out money only upon
warrants approved by the City Council and vouchers properly signed by the Finance Director. No
check, draft or voucher, issued in payment of any City obligation, shall be signed by the City
Treasurer until a warrant authorizing payment thereof has been approved by the City Council and
executed by the City Manager, Finance Director, Mayor and City Clerk. (Ord. 1342, 2-1-77)
B. Accounts: The City Treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by the
Council. (1963 Code, §6.05)
C. Reports: The City Treasurer shall make monthly reports to the Council showing the state of the
finances of the City, and the amounts received and spent during the month, which reports shall be
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 50/525
filed, and he shall make an annual report with the total amount of all receipts and expenditures of
the City and his transactions as City Treasurer during the preceding fiscal year. (1963 Code, §6.06;
amd. 1986 Code)
D. Register of Warrants: The City Treasurer shall keep a register of all warrants, bonds or orders filed
with him or paid by him, and all vouchers, as required by law. (1963 Code, §6.07)
1.6C.4: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS:
The City Treasurer shall be custodian of all City funds, and he shall keep the City money separate and
distinct from his own and shall not intermingle his own money with it or make private or personal use
of the City funds. Funds shall be deposited in such depositories as may be designated by the Council
from time to time as provided by law. (Ord. 788A, 9-17-68; amd. 1986 Code)
Chapter 7
MUNICIPAL DEPARTMENTS
ARTICLE A. DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE
1.7A.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the Department of Finance for the City consisting of the Director of Finance
and such other employees as may be provided for by the Council. (1963 Code, §7.01)
1.7A.2: DIRECTOR OF FINANCE:
There is established the position of Director of Finance, who shall be appointed by the City Manager,
as provided by law. The Director of Finance shall have control over all employees assigned to this
Department, subject to the supervision of the City Manager. (1963 Code, §7.02)
1.7A.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE DIRECTOR:
The Director of Finance shall:
A. Prepare and keep all financial records of the City.
B. Keep a current account of the amounts appropriated and budgeted each year and the sums spent
out of each budget account showing the unexpended balance for each item.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 51/525
C. Prepare each year the annual appropriation and tax levy ordinance in time for enactment and filing
as required by law, subject to the supervision of the City Manager.
D. Keep accounts showing at all times the fiscal condition of the City, including the current and
anticipated revenues and expenses of all Municipal funds and accounts.
E. Prepare and keep for the City Treasurer all registers and other records required by law to be kept
by the City Treasurer, and prepare for signature and publication the annual City Treasurer's report
and any other report required by law. (1963 Code, §7.03; amd. Ord. 788A, 9-17-68; Ord. 821, 5-
20-69; 1986 Code)
F. Pay all bills of the City in the following manner:
1. The Director of Finance shall prepare each month a warrant for the payment of all sums due
from the City, listing each item and the account out of which it is payable; which warrant, when
properly signed by the Mayor and City Clerk, shall authorize the issuance of a voucher or check
for the payment of each item. The designation of accounts shall not be necessary on warrants
for the payment of salaries.
2. No item shall be included in such warrant unless it has been authorized by the City Council. A
list of all items to be paid shall be submitted to the Council before the warrant is submitted to the
Mayor for his signature.
G. Receive and Collect Fees: The Director of Finance shall receive and collect all license fees, permit
fees, charges for Municipal utility services rendered by the City, sums due the City on any contract,
and all other sums due the City are required to be paid to him by ordinances of the City.
The Director shall keep the City Manager informed as to all sums due in taxes, accumulations in
the motor fuel tax account to the credit of the City, and all other revenues to which the City is
entitled.
1.7A.4: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
The Finance Director shall give bond in the amount as set out in Section 1.6.3 of this Code, with
sureties to be approved by the Council, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his/her duties.
(1986 Code)
ARTICLE B. BUDGET DEPARTMENT
1.7B.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the Budget Department for the City. It shall consist of the Budget Officer, and
such administrative assistants and other employees as may be provided for by the City Council in the
annual appropriation and budget ordinances of the City. (Ord. 1784, 2-1-83)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 52/525
1.7B.2: BUDGET OFFICER:
There is hereby established a position of Budget Officer, who shall be appointed by the City Manager,
as provided by law. The Budget Officer shall have control over all employees assigned to this
Department, subject to the supervision of the City Manager. In the event of a vacancy in the office of
Budget Officer, the City Manager shall serve as ex-officio head of the Department until the position is
filled by separate appointment.
1.7B.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE OFFICER:
The Budget Officer shall have the following duties:
A. Encourage and establish the use of efficient planning, budgeting, auditing, reporting and other fiscal
management procedures in all City departments, commissions and boards.
B. Compile an annual budget which shall contain estimates of revenues available to the City for the
fiscal year, together with recommended expenditures for the City in all departments, commissions
and boards. Such estimates shall be presented in the manner provided by the Illinois Compiled
Statutes.
C. Examine all books and records of the City departments, commissions and boards, which relate to
monies received or paid out, or any amounts owed by or to the City or any department, board or
commission thereof.
D. To obtain such additional information from the City or any department, board or commission of the
City, as may be helpful in the preparation of the budget. Such information shall be supplied in the
form required by the Budget Officer.
E. To establish such procedures as are necessary to insure compliance with the budget by the City
and all departments, boards and commissions of the City.
1.7B.4: COMPILATION AND CONTENTS OF BUDGET:
The Municipal Budget Officer shall compile a budget, such budget to contain estimates of revenues
available to the Municipality for the fiscal year for which the budget is drafted together with
recommended expenditures for the Municipality and all the Municipality's departments, boards and
commissions. The budget shall contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures for the two (2)
years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared. Each budget shall show
the specific funds from which each anticipated expenditure shall be made.
1.7B.5: CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT, REPAIR OR REPLACEMENT FUND:
In the preparation by the Municipal Budget Officer of the annual budget, an amount not to exceed one6/
5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 53/525
half of one percent (.5%) of equalized assessed value of properties subject to taxation by the
Municipality may be accumulated in a separate fund for the purpose or purposes of specific capital
improvements, repairs and/or replacements of specific types of Municipal equipment, or other tangible
property, both real and personal, to be designated as the "Capital Improvement, Repair or
Replacement Fund". Expenditures from the Capital Improvement, Repair or Replacement Fund shall
be budgeted in the fiscal year in which the capital improvement, repair or replacement will occur. Upon
the completion or abandonment of any object for which the Capital Improvement, Repair or
Replacement Fund, or should any surplus monies remain after the completion or abandonment of any
object for which the Capital Improvement, Repair or Replacement Fund was inaugurated, then such
funds no longer necessary for capital improvements, repairs or the replacement shall be transferred to
the General Corporate Fund of the Municipality on the first day of the fiscal year following such
abandonment, completion or discovery of surplus funds.
1.7B.6: REVISION OF ANNUAL BUDGET:
The City Council may delegate authority to heads of City departments, boards or commissions to
delete, add to, change or create subclasses within object classes budgeted previously to the
department, board or commission subject to such limitations or requirements for prior approval by the
Budget Officer or City Manager as the Council, upon a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the members then
holding office, may establish. By a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the members of the City Council then
holding office, the annual budget for the City may be revised by deleting, adding to, changing or
creating subclasses within object classes and object classes themselves. No revision of the budget
shall be made increasing the budget in the event funds are not available to effectuate the purpose of
the revisions.
1.7B.7: FUNDS FOR CONTINGENCY PURPOSES:
The annual budget for the City may contain money set aside for contingency purposes not to exceed
ten percent (10%) of the total budget, less the amount set aside for contingency purposes, which
monies may be expended for contingencies upon a majority vote of the City Council.
1.7B.8: PUBLIC INSPECTION, NOTICE OF HEARING:
The City Council shall make the tentative annual budget available for public inspection by placing a
suitable number of copies on file at the City Hall at least ten (10) days prior to the passage of the
annual budget. Not less than one week after the tentative budget is placed on file and prior to final
action on the budget, the City Council shall hold at least one public hearing or hearings on the
tentative budget, after which hearing or hearings the tentative budget may be further revised or
passed without any further inspection, notice or hearing. Notice of this hearing shall be given by
publication in a newspaper having a general circulation in the City at least one week prior to the time
of the hearing. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE C. LEGAL DEPARTMENT
1.7C.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 54/525
There is hereby created the legal department of the city, consisting of the corporation counsel and
such other assistants as may be provided by the council. (1963 Code, §16.01)
1.7C.2: CORPORATION COUNSEL:
There is hereby established the position of corporation counsel who shall be appointed by the city
manager, as provided by law. (1963 Code, §16.02)
1.7C.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE CORPORATION COUNSEL, GENERAL DUTIES:
The corporation counsel shall have the following duties:
A. Provide legal advice to the city council, city manager, department heads, the plan commission, the
zoning board of appeals, the liquor commission, and all other boards as the city manager may
direct. (1963 Code, §16.03; amd. 1986 Code; Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
B. Represent the city in all matters brought in the name of the city or against the city in all courts of
competent jurisdiction, administrative boards as established by the Illinois Compiled Statutes, or
other hearings as may be directed by the city manager. (The aforementioned duty is subject to an
exception for those causes of action in which the city is a party defendant under insurance
coverage of the city, in which case, the city's insurance carrier shall have the right to select legal
counsel to appear and represent the city in said cause of action.) (1963 Code, §16.03; amd. 1986
Code)
ARTICLE D. PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
1.7D.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the public works department for the city. It shall consist of the director of
public works and all other employees with such titles as may be appointed by the city manager
provided for in the annual appropriation and city budget ordinance. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7D.2: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS:
There is hereby established a position of director of public works, who shall be appointed by the city
manager, as provided by law. The director of public works shall have control over all employees
assigned to this department, subject to the supervision of the city manager. Qualified persons not
possessing a professional engineering license may hold the position of director of public works. In the
event of a vacancy in the office of the director of public works, the city manager shall serve as the ex
officio head of the department until the position is filled by separate appointment. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-
2004)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 55/525
1.7D.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS:
The director of public works shall have charge over:
A. All public property of the city, including, but not limited to, all streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks,
municipal buildings and all other properties not specifically assigned to some other department.
B. The maintenance and operation of the city's water and sanitary sewer conveyance systems; all
streets and sidewalks and the drainage thereof; all vehicles, equipment, and buildings with the
exception of those items specifically placed under another department.
C. All construction, repair or extension of any pavement, any sewer or water mains, and any
appurtenances thereto, and all other construction, repair or maintenance work conducted by the
city.
D. All motor vehicles, trucks and other equipment of the city, and all buildings or places in which the
same are housed or kept with the exception of those items and buildings specifically placed under
another department.
E. The referral of the making of all surveys, maps, plans and investigations regarding city facilities to
engineers determined by the city manager.
F. The coordination of the functions and duties of the various review processes within the department.
G. The maintenance and operation of the city's water treatment facilities, sanitary sewage treatment
facilities, water supply wells, storage tanks, lift stations and related appurtenances.
H. The maintenance and operation of the city's paratransit division including vehicle maintenance,
preparation of ridership information, preparation of monthly operating reports, and preparation of
reports and records as may be required by the regional transportation authority.
I. The maintenance and operation of the city's park system, exclusive of facility scheduling and
recreation programs.
J. Shall serve as the pollution control officer for the city, with the following additional duties:
1. Provide information to all departments of the city relating to pollution control and environmental
regulations and requirements.
2. Provide environmental evaluations and audits of all city property and disposal practices.
3. Provide environmental audits for the purchase of any real estate by the city.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 56/525
4. Establish and administer programs for the management and documentation of disposal of waste
materials from city facilities.
5. Develop and implement necessary programs of corrective action on all city property.
6. Develop and promote community programs for improvement of waste disposal facilities and
practices. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7D.4: CITY ENGINEER:
There is hereby established the position of city engineer who shall be appointed by the city manager,
as is provided by law. When the director of public works is a licensed engineer, he/she shall be the
director of public works/city engineer. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7D.5: FUNCTIONS OF THE CITY ENGINEER:
The city engineer shall have the following duties:
A. Charge of and supervision over the making of all surveys, plans, maps and investigations regarding
city facilities as may be referred to him/her by either the director of public works or the city
manager.
B. The city engineer shall exercise approval authority over engineering plans for all public
improvements conducted for the city and shall make all inspections needed for that purpose. The
city engineer shall exercise final approval authority for the acceptance of public improvements by
the city, constructed as part of a development project.
C. The review and approval of all engineering plans and development plans for the construction of
private and public improvements to be completed as part of a planned development, subdivision of
land or other private development project.
D. Administer and enforce city regulations and policies for the construction of private and public
improvements to be completed as part of a development project.
E. The city engineer shall issue all permits established by ordinances of the city or the city manager
which are required to be issued by the city engineer.
F. Shall direct all the engineering services required of the city as well as such other duties as may be
prescribed by any ordinance of the city or directed by the city manager. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7D.6: DEVELOPMENT ENGINEER:
There is hereby created the position of development engineer, who shall be appointed by the city
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 57/525
manager, as provided by law, and who shall report to the director of public works. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-
2004)
1.7D.7: FUNCTIONS OF THE DEVELOPMENT ENGINEER:
The development engineer shall have the following duties:
A. Provide reports and recommendations to the director for the review of all engineering plans and
development plans for the construction of private and public improvements to be completed as part
of a planned development, subdivision of land or other private development project.
B. To administer and enforce city regulations and policies for the construction of private and public
improvements to be completed as part of a development project.
C. Provide reports and recommendations to the director pertaining to subdivision standards, typical
details, detailed specifications, and engineering information for development guidelines.
D. Review and approve letter of credit information pertaining to public and private development
project, administer and manage letter of credit guarantees, review and approve applications for the
reduction of letters of credit.
E. Coordinate review of detailed engineering information with consultants who have been retained by
the city.
F. Assist residents with general information regarding storm water drainage, lot grading, and similar
issues.
G. Perform other duties as may be prescribed by any ordinance of the city or as directed by the
director or the city manager. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
ARTICLE E. DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY
DEVELOPMENT
1.7E.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the department of community development for the city. It shall consist of the
director of the department and all such other employees as may be appointed by the city manager and
provided for in the annual appropriation and city budget ordinance. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7E.2: DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 58/525
There is hereby created the position of director of community development, who shall be appointed by
the city manager, as provided by law. The director of community development shall have control over
all employees assigned to this department, subject to the supervision of the city manager, and shall
serve as building and zoning officer for the city. In the event of a vacancy in the office of director of
community development the city manager shall serve as ex officio head of the department until the
position is filled by separate appointment. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7E.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT:
The director of community development shall have the following duties:
A. The interpretation and administration of the zoning ordinance, subdivision ordinance, building code,
comprehensive plan and all other laws and regulations pertaining to the planning, development,
alteration, and use of land and structures.
B. Maintaining and revising the comprehensive plan and corresponding documents and studies for the
city and its extraterritorial planning jurisdiction.
C. Maintaining and revising the city's zoning map.
D. Assisting the corresponding boards and commissions in the review and approval of requests
pertaining to the functional areas within the department, including, but not limited to, all planned
developments, rezonings, amendments to the text of the zoning ordinance, all subdivisions of land,
and variations from or amendments to corresponding codes and ordinances.
E. The coordination of the functions and duties of the various review processes within the department.
(Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7E.4: BUILDING INSPECTOR:
There is hereby created the position of building inspector, who shall be appointed by the city manager,
as provided by law, and who shall report to the director of community development. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-
3-2004)
1.7E.5: FUNCTIONS OF THE BUILDING INSPECTOR:
The building inspector shall have the following duties:
A. Enforce all laws and ordinances of the city pertaining to construction, repair, or alteration of
buildings or structures, and shall make or cause to be made all inspections needed for that
purpose.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 59/525
B. Issue or cause to be issued all proper permits for such work after payment of required fees to the
director of finance.
C. Serve as enforcement officer for the building, electrical, and plumbing codes and for the zoning
ordinances.
D. Serve as the enforcement officer of ordinances of the city relating to the construction and alteration
of private improvements, including signs, swimming pools, parking areas, sidewalks, air
conditioner systems, and private utility services, as well as for ordinances relating to the moving
and/or demolition of buildings and the removal of refuse and/or junk.
E. Perform such duties as may be prescribed by any ordinance of the city, or directed by the director
of community development or the city manager. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
ARTICLE F. FIRE DEPARTMENT
(Rep. by Ord. 2438, 10-5-1993)
ARTICLE G. POLICE DEPARTMENT
1.7G.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created a Police Department for the City which shall consist of the Chief of Police,
supervisory personnel and such sworn officers, special police and civilian employees as provided for
by the Council in the Personnel Plan and annual budget of the City. All sworn officers, including the
Chief of Police, shall be subject to the rules established by the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners of the City, the personnel policies of the City, and any rules and regulations adopted
by ordinances of the City, orders of the Chief of Police or his designated representative, or orders of
the City Manager. (1986 Code)
1.7G.2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
There is hereby established the position of Chief of Police who shall be appointed by the City Manager
as provided by law. The Chief of Police shall have control over all employees assigned to the
Department subject to the rules established by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners and the
supervision of the City Manager. In the event of a vacancy in the office of Chief of Police, the City
Manager shall designate a qualified replacement. (1986 Code)
1.7G.3: FUNCTIONS OF CHIEF OF POLICE:
The Chief of Police shall have the following duties:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 60/525
A. The Chief of Police shall be the chief executive officer of the Police Department of the City. He shall
seek the enforcement of all laws of the State and the City, as well as the enforcement of all orders,
rules and regulations of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. He should devote his whole
time to the duties of his position.
B. The Chief of Police shall be in charge of and exercise control over all sworn officers and civilian
employees of the Police Department, subject to the authority of the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners and the City Manager.
C. He shall have charge and custody of all property of the Police Department including, but not limited
to, alarm systems and other communication systems used or required for the operation of the
Police Department.
D. He shall have the charge and custody of all evidence relating to pending cases, and all lost,
abandoned or stolen property recovered by the City.
E. He shall be the keeper of the City jail and custodian of all persons confined therein.
F. He shall keep or cause to be kept a record of all arrests made in conformity with the best possible
police records system. He shall also keep records of all traffic violations or accidents and other
accidents resulting in loss, damage or injury to persons or property and shall supervise the
operation of traffic-control devices.
G. He shall give notice to the City Manager of all damage to City property coming to the attention of
the Police Department together with the complete report relating thereto.
H. He shall notify the City Manager and the City Attorney of the violation of City ordinances and of the
filing of all complaints for warrants relating to the violations of City ordinances insofar as the
knowledge of the filing of such complaints is had by the Police Department.
I. He shall ensure the preservation of peace and order at elections and provide adequate police
protection at every public assembly in the City.
J. He shall make an annual report to the City Manager showing the work carried on by the Department
during the preceding year in such detail as may be required by the City Manager, together with
suggestions and recommendations for the improvement of police service.
K. The Chief of Police may, subject to the approval of the City Manager, establish reasonable rules
and regulations relating to routine work of the Department consistent with the ordinances of the
City and the rules and regulations of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. Wilful failure on
the part of any sworn or civilian employee of the Police Department to comply with such rules and
regulations shall be deemed to be a disobedience of lawful orders of the Chief of Police.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 61/525
L. The Chief of Police shall assign sworn officers and civilian employees of the Police Department to
such responsibilities within the Department as he shall determine. To implement the foregoing, the
Chief may designate an administrative assistant to the Chief, designate a number of sworn officers
to work in civilian clothes under the title of detective, and to make such other internal assignments
as he may deem necessary and appropriate. No internal appointment as either administrative
assistant to the Chief, or detective or other internal assignment shall be deemed a promotion, and
no sworn officer receiving such an assignment shall be entitled to any automatic increase in salary.
(1986 Code)
1.7G.4: REGULATIONS FOR CIVILIAN EMPLOYEES:
A. All civilian employees of the Police Department shall perform such duties as may be assigned to
them by the Chief of Police or by the City Manager.
B. It shall be the duty of all such civilian employees to adhere to such rules and regulations as may
from time to time be established by the Chief of Police with the approval of the City Manager.
(1986 Code)
1.7G.5: REGULATIONS FOR SWORN OFFICERS:
A. It shall be the duty of every sworn officer of the Police Department to conduct himself in a proper
and law-abiding manner at all times and to avoid the use of unnecessary force.
B. Each and every sworn officer of the Police Department shall devote his whole time and attention to
the business of the Department; and every sworn officer is expressly prohibited from following any
other calling, being in any other business, or holding any other lucrative position unless approval is
first obtained from the Chief of Police and although certain hours are allocated in respect to sworn
officers for the performance of duties on ordinary occasions, they must, nevertheless, be prepared
at all times to act immediately on notice that their services are required.
C. Every sworn officer shall wear a suitable badge and uniform. The badge shall be furnished by the
City and shall be the indicia of authority of all sworn officers. The badge shall remain the property
of the City and be surrendered to the Chief of Police, together with other property of the City which
may be in his/her possession, upon his/her death, discharge or resignation.
D. No sworn officer shall make a false official report or make a false statement or gossip about a
sworn officer or civilian employee of the Department or the business of the Department to the
discredit or detriment of any such sworn officer or civilian employee of the Department. No sworn
officer shall, upon the street, in any business house, or other place, to any sworn officer or civilian
employee of the Department, or to any citizen, make any remark in regard to or about any other
sworn officer or civilian employee of the Department, which may bring the Department or sworn
officer or civilian employee disrepute, or subject it or him to any ridicule.
E. Any matters which any sworn officer feels should be brought to the attention of the Department
shall be communicated directly to the Chief or the person acting in his stead.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 62/525
F. No sworn officer shall drink intoxicating liquor while on duty. No sworn officer shall smoke while on
duty unless otherwise provided for by the rules and regulations of the Chief of Police.
G. No sworn officer shall loiter in any store or other place of business while on duty. No sworn officer
of the Department, while on duty, shall enter any place where intoxicating liquor is sold, unless in
the immediate discharge of duty. No sworn officer shall attend theatrical or other public
performances in uniform unless detailed for such duty.
H. No sworn officer shall receive or accept any fee, reward or gift of any kind from any person
arrested, or from any friend in his/her behalf, while in custody, or after his/her discharge.
I. No sworn officer shall communicate to others, without permission from the Chief of Police, any
information or orders which have been issued to any person who is not a sworn officer of the
Department, the City Manager or the City Attorney's department. (1986 Code)
J. No sworn officer shall reside outside the corporate limits of McHenry County, Illinois. (Ord. 2059, 8-
4-1987)
1.7G.6: DUTIES OF SUPERVISORY PERSONNEL, SWORN AND CIVILIAN:
In addition to the regulations for sworn officers or civilian employees, supervisory personnel shall
perform such leadership and administrative duties and functions as may be assigned by the Chief of
Police or by the City Manager. (1986 Code)
1.7G.7: ARREST PROCEDURES:
Every sworn officer of the Police Department is a conservator of the peace with the power to make
arrests. A sworn officer shall arrest without warrant any person detected or seen by him/her in the
commission of a felony, misdemeanor or violation of a City ordinance, and any person whom he has
reason to believe is guilty of a felony, or who is escaping from lawful arrest or confinement. Sworn
officers of the Police Department shall have power to serve civil and criminal warrants, writs and
processes as are provided by law. No such process shall be served by any sworn officer of the
Department other than the Chief of Police without an order from the Chief or his designated
representative. (1986 Code)
1.7G.8: OBSTRUCTING JUSTICE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or assist in the escape of any person lawfully in the
custody of the Police Department or any sworn officer of the Police Department, or to obstruct or
hinder any sworn officer of the Police Department in the performance of his/her duties or to give or
make a false official report.
No sworn officer of the Department shall recommend counsel to any prisoner in securing counsel. No
sworn officer of the Department shall retain in his/her possession any property of the Police
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 63/525
Department after the demand for the surrender of such property has been made upon his/her by the
Chief of Police. No sworn officer of the Police Department found guilty of any felony or aid in escape,
extortion, oppression or lawful wrong or injustice, or conspiring with any person against the ordinances
of the City and the laws of the State shall be retained as a sworn officer of the Department. (1986
Code)
1.7G.9: SPECIAL AND AUXILIARY POLICE:
A. Special Police: Special police may be appointed by the Chief of Police upon the approval of the City
Manager for such time or times as may be deemed necessary.
B. Auxiliary Police: The Chief of Police, upon the approval of the City Manager, may appoint not more
than twenty one (21) auxiliary police. (1986 Code)
1.7G.10: DEPUTY CHIEF:
The position of Deputy Chief is hereby established for the Police Department of the City. The Deputy
Chief, who shall be appointed by the Chief of Police, shall be an exempt rank immediately below that
of the Chief of Police. Up to two (2) persons may be appointed to the position of Deputy Chief. The
appointment shall be from the rank of sworn, full-time officers of the City, but must have at least five
(5) years of full-time service as a police officer in the Police Department. The Deputy Chief shall serve
at the discretion of the Chief of Police and, if removed from the position, shall revert to the rank held
immediately prior to appointment to the Deputy Chief position. (Ord. 99-0-55, 10-5-1999)
ARTICLE H. PARATRANSIT DEPARTMENT
(Rep. by Ord. 2315, 11-19-1991)
ARTICLE I. AMBULANCE DEPARTMENT
1.7I.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created an Ambulance Department of the City, consisting of an Ambulance Chief and
such other members as may be provided for by the City Council. (Ord. 1821, 12-20-83)
1.7I.2: AMBULANCE CHIEF AND MEMBERS:
A. The Ambulance Chief shall be appointed by the City Manager. At the scene of any emergency, the
Ambulance Chief and assistants shall rank in the order named and the officer of the highest rank at
any emergency shall take command at the scene of such emergency. In the event of an
emergency call at the scene of a fire, the Ambulance Chief and his/her assistants shall take
preliminary orders and directions from the Fire Chief and assistants at the scene of any fire.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 64/525
B. The Ambulance Department shall consist of as many members as may be determined from time to
time by the City Council. The Ambulance Department may have such organization approved by the
Council and may hold meetings and engage in social activities with the approval of the City
Council. No member shall be elected, appointed to or accepted into the Ambulance Department
without the approval of the City Council. No person shall be eligible to appointment within the
Ambulance Department who has not met the minimum requirements of the Illinois Department of
Public Health.
1.7I.3: FUNCTIONS:
The Ambulance Department shall have the following powers and duties:
A. To provide emergency medical services to emergency patients for analytic, resuscitative, stabilizing
or preventative purposes, preceding and during transportation to hospitals.
B. To respond to any calls for emergency medical services for the pre-hospital treatment or
transportation of a person or persons in a condition or situation needing immediate medical
attention or in a situation where such need is declared by emergency medical personnel or public
safety official.
C. To operate a general ambulance service for the transportation of the sick, injured, wounded or
otherwise incapacitated or helpless from or to hospitals, nursing homes or health systems
agencies.
1.7I.4: RECORDS:
The Ambulance Chief shall keep or cause to be kept a record of all meetings and the attendance of
members, a record of all emergency calls and the attendance of members at such calls and a record
of all activities of the Department. Each April, the Ambulance Chief shall file with the City Manager a
full report of said records and attendance and emergency calls.
The Ambulance Chief shall make such Department records as are necessary available for the review
or audit of the City Council or the City Manager, when requested.
The Ambulance Chief shall be responsible for the preliminary preparation of the Department annual
budget.
1.7I.5: USE OF EQUIPMENT:
A. No person shall use any ambulance, equipment or other apparatus belonging to the City for any
private purpose other than the rendition of emergency medical services or care, or remove the
same or any part thereof from its location on the property of the City.
B. No person shall wilfully or negligently break, deface, or in any manner injure any ambulance,
equipment or other apparatus belonging to the City or remove any part of such ambulance
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 65/525
apparatus or equipment or in any manner interfere with the same when being used by a proper
person or authority.
1.7I.6: COMPENSATION:
Each member of the Ambulance Department shall be paid in accordance with the schedule
established by the City Council.
1.7I.7: CHARGES:
The City Council may establish fees and charges for the provision of ambulance services. (1986
Code)
ARTICLE J. PERFORMING ARTS DEPARTMENT
1.7J.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the performing arts department for the city. It shall consist of the director of
the Woodstock Opera House and all other employees as may be appointed by the city manager as
provided by the city council. (1986 Code)
1.7J.2: DIRECTOR OF THE WOODSTOCK OPERA HOUSE:
There is hereby established a position of director of the Woodstock Opera House, who shall be
appointed by the city manager, as provided by law. The director of the opera house shall have control
over all employees assigned to this department, subject to the supervision of the city manager. In the
event of a vacancy in the position of director of the Woodstock Opera House, the city manager shall
serve as ex officio head of the department until the position is filled by separate appointment. (1986
Code)
1.7J.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE DIRECTOR OF THE WOODSTOCK OPERA HOUSE:
The director of the Woodstock Opera House shall have the following duties:
A. The direction, execution and evaluation of all phases of opera house programming.
B. The overseeing of the Woodstock municipal band program and the programming of the bandstand
and the springhouse in the park in the square.
C. The ongoing maintenance of and development of recommendations for the long term restoration of
the Woodstock Opera House.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 66/525
D. Assisting the various boards and commissions which have direct input in the operations of the
opera house including, but not limited to, the establishment of policy and fundraising procedures
and activities.
E. Keeping or causing to be kept a record of all activities of the department including the financial and
attendance records. He shall make an annual report to the city manager regarding the work carried
on by the department during the preceding year, together with suggestions and recommendations
for future improvements. (1986 Code)
1.7J.4: OPERA HOUSE SURCHARGE:
A. A surcharge is hereby established for the sale of any ticket to a performance, program, etc., at the
Woodstock Opera House. For purposes of this section, the purchase of a series ticket shall be
considered one ticket.
B. A surcharge of three dollars ($3.00) shall be applied to each ticket sale. The surcharge shall be
applicable to all productions, except youth programs, beginning on or after May 1, 2006. Youth
programs shall be exempt from the surcharge.
C. All surcharge proceeds shall be deposited in the debt service fund and utilized for the repayment of
the series 2001B alternative revenue bonds, which were issued to construct the opera house
annex. (Ord. 06-0-15, 2-21-2006, eff. 5-1-2006)
ARTICLE K. DEPARTMENT OF BUSINESS
DEVELOPMENT
1.7K.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the Department of Business Development for the City. It shall consist of the
Director of the Department and all such other employees as may be appointed by the City Manager
and provided for in the annual appropriation and City Budget Ordinance. (Ord. 2643, 9-3-1996)
1.7K.2: DIRECTOR OF BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT:
There is hereby created the position of Director of Business Development, who shall be appointed by
the City Manager, as provided by law. The Director of Business Development shall have control over
all employees assigned to this Department, subject to the supervision of the City Manager. In the
event of a vacancy in the Office of Director of Business Development the City Manager shall serve as
ex-officio head of the Department until the position is filled by separate appointment. (Ord. 2643, 9-3-
1996)
1.7K.3: FUNCTIONS OF DIRECTOR OF BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 67/525
The Director of Business Development shall have the following duties:
A. To coordinate the Business Retention and Expansion Program as directed by the City Manager, to
include development of appropriate systems for information flow, analysis and response, and to
prepare periodic reports.
B. Provide follow-up assistance to prospective employers to encourage the attraction of investment to
Woodstock with the assistance of the City Manager.
C. Design and implement activities to stimulate entrepreneurial development, business development
and redevelopment.
D. Assist existing and prospective employers in identifying and obtaining public and private financial
assistance for business expansion/location in Woodstock.
E. Develop and maintain information clearinghouse and files, including: demographic and
socioeconomic indicators, labor force information, available commercial and industrial
site/buildings, locational and market data, updates of fact sheets and individual community profiles.
F. Provide written, telephone and in-person response and follow-up to inquiries from potential and
existing business prospects and the general public of the Woodstock economy and business
climate. Market cold calls to prospective businesses.
G. Conduct specific research on development issues and topics as directed by the City Manager.
H. Represent the City at business development-related functions and meetings; deliver presentations
and other public relations efforts to promote the City.
I. Serve as lead staff person to the Woodstock Economic Development Corporation.
J. Other duties as prescribed by ordinance or as directed by the City Manager. (Ord. 2643, 9-3-1996)
ARTICLE L. CODE HEARING DEPARTMENT
1.7L.1: ADOPTION OF STATE STATUTES:
The following statutes, as from time to time amended, are adopted in their entirety and any person
charged with the violation of a municipal ordinance may be prosecuted under and in accordance with
the provisions herein: a) 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.2-1 et seq., code hearing departments; b)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 68/525
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., building code violations; c) 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-208.3, administrative adjudication of violations of traffic regulations concerning the
standing, parking or conditions of vehicles and automated traffic law violations; d) 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.6, which authorizes the city to create and implement an automated traffic
law enforcement system; and e) 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.7, administrative fees and
procedures for impounding vehicles for specified violations. The adoption of these statutes shall not
preclude the city from using other methods to enforce city ordinances. (Ord. 12-O-02, 1-17-2012)
1.7L.2: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
A. A code hearing department is hereby established for the city as a separate and independent
agency in the municipal government. The purpose of the code hearing department is to expedite
the prosecution and correction of code violations in the manner set forth herein. The provisions set
forth in this article may be used in the adjudication of any violations of a city ordinance except for
any offense under the Illinois vehicle code1 or this code or similar offense that is a traffic regulation
governing the movement of vehicles, and except for any reportable offenses under section 5/6-204
of the Illinois vehicle code.
B. The code hearing department shall be comprised of the following individuals appointed by the city
manager:
1. A hearing officer who may also be referred to as an administrative law judge;
2. The chief of police or designee;
3. The deputy city manager or designee;
4. A code administrator; and
5. Any person or persons deemed necessary for the efficient administration of the code hearing
department.
C. In no event may the hearing officer be an employee of the city. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-
2009)
1.7L.3: HEARING OFFICER POWERS, DUTIES AND QUALIFICATIONS:
A. It is the duty of the hearing officer to:
1. Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine whether or not a code violation exists.
2. Hear testimony and accept evidence relevant to the existence or nonexistence of a code
violation.
3. Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at
the hearing.
4. Issue a written determination, based on the evidence presented at the hearing, of whether a
code violation exists. The determination shall include a written finding of fact; decision based
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 69/525
upon those findings of fact; and an order that states the sanctions including the fine or penalty or
action with which the defendant must comply, or dismissing the case if the violation is not
proved.
5. Imposing penalties consistent with applicable city provisions and assessing costs upon finding a
party liable for the charged violation. The maximum monetary fine imposed under this article
shall be exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs imposed to secure compliance with the city's
ordinances.
6. In no event shall the hearing officer have authority to impose a penalty of incarceration.
B. Every hearing officer shall serve as the hearing officer for matters set forth under these regulations
and be an attorney licensed to practice law in the state of Illinois for at least three (3) years. Prior
to conducting proceedings under this article, hearing officers shall successfully complete a formal
training program that includes:
1. Instruction on the rules of procedure of the hearing that they will conduct;
2. Orientation to each subject area of the code violations they will administer;
3. Observation of administrative hearings; and
4. Participation in hypothetical cases, including rules of evidence and issuing final orders. (Ord. 09-
O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.4: CODE ADMINISTRATOR DUTIES:
The code administrator may be a city employee or an independent contractor or agency contracted by
the city to perform such duties as enumerated herein. The code administrator is authorized,
empowered and directed to:
A. Operate and manage the system of administrative adjudication of all code violations, as may be
permitted by law and directed by ordinance;
B. Adopt, distribute, and process all notices as may be required herein;
C. Operate and maintain a computerized program for the system of administrative adjudication;
D. Keep accurate records of adjudication appearances and activities;
E. Collect monies paid as fines and/or penalties after a final determination of liability; and
F. Other duties as may be necessary to efficiently administer this article. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff.
5-1-2009)
1.7L.5: INSTITUTING CODE HEARING PROVISIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 70/525
A. When a police officer, building inspector, code enforcement officer or other individual authorized to
issue a code violation finds that a code violation exists, that individual shall note the violation on a
multiple copy violation notice, report and hearing notice that indicates:
1. The name and address of the defendant;
2. The type and nature of the violation including a reference to the appropriate section of the code
and potential penalties that may result;
3. The date and time the violation was observed;
4. The names of witnesses to the violation;
5. In the event of a building code violation, the address of the structure or premises where the
violation is observed;
6. The means by which the defendant may waive the right to a hearing and pay the applicable fine
for the violation;
7. The time and date and location of the hearing; and
8. Penalties which may occur if the defendant fails to appear.
B. For the purpose of a code violation relating to real property, the property owner shall be prima facie
responsible for a violation that occurs on such property and subject to the penalty therefor. For
violations relating to motor vehicles, the owner or operator of said vehicle shall be prima facie
responsible for a violation that occurs.
C. The violation report shall be forwarded to the code hearing department and a docket number shall
be assigned and stamped on all copies of the report and a hearing date shall be noted on the form.
The hearing date shall not be less than thirty (30) nor more than forty (40) days after the violation
is reported.
D. One copy of the violation report shall be maintained in the files of the code hearing department and
shall become part of the record of the hearing. One copy of the report shall be returned to the
individual representing the city and one copy of the report shall be served by first class mail to the
defendant, along with a summons commanding the defendant to appear on the specified hearing
date. In the case of a building code violation, service of the report shall be made by first class mail
on the owner of the structure or premises, along with a summons commanding the owner to
appear at the hearing. If the name of the owner of the structure or premises cannot be ascertained
or if service cannot be made by mail, service may be made on the owner by posting, nailing or
substantially affixing a copy of the violation report form on the front door of the structure or
premises where the violation is found, not less than twenty (20) days before the hearing is
scheduled. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.6: SUBPOENAS AND DEFAULTS:
At any time prior to the hearing date, the hearing officer assigned to the case may, at the request of
either party, direct witnesses to appear and give testimony at the hearing. If the defendant or the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 71/525
defendant's attorney fails to appear on the specified hearing date, the hearing officer may find the
defendant in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the existence
of a code violation. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.7: CONTINUANCES AND REPRESENTATION AT CODE HEARINGS:
No continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer in proceedings under this article except in
cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the defendant. Lack of
preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance authorized by a hearing officer
under the terms of this article shall not exceed twenty five (25) days unless agreed to by all parties.
The case for the city may be presented by an attorney designated by the city or by any other city
employee, except that the case for the city shall not be presented by an employee of the code hearing
department. The case for the defendant may be presented by the defendant or the defendant's
attorney or any other agent or representative of the defendant. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.8: HEARING EVIDENCE:
At the hearing, the hearing officer shall preside, shall hear testimony and shall accept any evidence
relevant to the existence or nonexistence of a code violation. The strict rules of evidence applicable to
judicial proceedings shall not apply to hearings authorized by this article. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff.
5-1-2009)
1.7L.9: EVICTION AND RIGHTS OF THE DEFENDANT:
No action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer or other similar
proceedings shall be threatened or instituted against an occupant of a structure or premises solely
because such occupant agrees to testify or testifies at a code violation hearing. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-
2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.10: DEFENSES TO CODE VIOLATIONS:
A. It shall be a defense to a code violation charged if the owner, the owner's attorney or any other
agent or representative proves to the hearing officer's satisfaction that:
1. The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants and that in spite of
reasonable attempts by the owner to maintain the structure or premises free of such violation,
the current occupants continue to cause the violations; or
2. An occupant or resident of the structure or premises has refused entry to the owner or the
owner's agent to all or part of the structure or premises for the purpose of correcting the code
violation.
B. It shall not constitute a defense at any proceeding that a person or entity came into compliance with
the ordinance after the date of the alleged violation, except to the limited extent as set forth in
subsection 3.5B, of the unified development ordinance, pursuant to which penalties shall
commence after the date specified in the notice of violation. (Ord. 17-O-25, 3-7-2017)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 72/525
1.7L.11: FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER:
At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a determination based on the evidence
presented at the hearing as to whether or not a code violation exists. The determination shall be in
writing and shall be designated as "findings, decision and order". The findings, decision and order
shall include: a) the hearing officer's finding of facts, b) a decision as to whether a code violation exists
based on the findings of fact, and c) an order that states the sanction or dismisses the case if a
violation is not proved. A monetary sanction for a violation under the terms of this article shall not
exceed the amount authorized by statute. If a building code violation is proved, the order may also
impose the sanctions that are provided in this code for the violation proved. A copy of the findings,
decision and order shall be served on the defendant within five (5) days after it is issued. Service shall
be in the same manner that the violation report and summons are served in accordance with
subsection 1.7L.5D of this article. Payment of any penalty or fine and the disposition of fine money
shall be in the same manner as set forth in this code unless otherwise provided for; however, payment
of such fine or penalty shall be made no later than ten (10) days after the determination has been
made by the hearing officer. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.12: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW LAW:
The findings, decision, and order shall be subject to review in the 22nd judicial circuit court of
McHenry County, Illinois. The provisions of the Illinois administrative review law, 735 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3-101 et seq., or as hereinafter amended, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall
apply to and govern every action for the judicial review of the findings, decision and order of the
hearing officer under this article. Any person filing for judicial review under the Illinois administrative
review law shall be subject to the assessment of costs for the preparation and certification of the
record of proceeding before the hearing officer. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.13: JUDGMENT ON FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER:
A. Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction or costs imposed,
remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures under
the administrative review law shall be a debt due and owing the city and, as such, may be
collected in accordance with applicable law.
B. After expiration of the period within which judicial review under the administrative review law may
be sought for a final determination of the code violation, the city may commence a proceeding in
said circuit court for the purpose of obtaining a judgment on the findings, decision and order.
Nothing in this section shall prevent the city from consolidating multiple findings, decisions and
orders against a person in such a proceeding. Upon commencement of the action, the city shall file
a certified copy of the findings, decision and order, which shall be accompanied by a certification
that recites facts sufficient to show that the findings, decision and order were issued in accordance
with this article and the applicable city ordinance. Service of the summons and a copy of the
petition may be made by any method provided for by section 2-203 of the code of civil procedures
or by certified mail, return receipt requested, provided that the total amount of fines, other
sanctions and costs imposed by the findings, decision and order do not exceed two thousand five
hundred dollars ($2,500.00). If the court is satisfied that the findings, decision and order were
entered in accordance with the requirements of this article and 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-
2.2-1 et seq., code hearing department and the applicable city ordinance, and that the defendant
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 73/525
had an opportunity for a hearing under this article and for judicial review as provided: 1) the court
shall render judgment in favor of the city and against the defendant for the amount indicated in the
findings, decision and order, plus costs. The judgment shall have the same effect and may be
enforced in the same manner as other judgments for recovery of money; and 2) the court may also
issue any other orders and injunctions that are requested by the city to enforce the order of the
hearing officer to correct a code violation. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
C. In place of a proceeding under subsection B of this section, after expiration of the period in which
judicial review under the Illinois administrative review law may be sought for a final determination
of a code violation, unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the findings, decision, and
order of the hearing officer may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court
of competent jurisdiction.
In any case in which a defendant has failed to comply with a judgment ordering a defendant to
correct a code violation or imposing any fine or other sanction as a result of a code violation, any
expenses incurred by the city to enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney fees,
court costs, and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, after they are fixed by a court
of competent jurisdiction or a hearing officer, shall be a debt due and owing the city and may be
collected in accordance with applicable law. Prior to any expenses being fixed by a hearing officer
pursuant to this subsection, the city shall provide notice to the defendant that states that the
defendant shall appear at a hearing before the administrative hearing officer to determine whether
the defendant has failed to comply with the judgment. The notice shall set the date for such a
hearing, which shall not be less than seven (7) days from the date that notice is served. If notice is
served by mail, the seven (7) day period shall begin to run on the date that the notice was
deposited in the mail.
Upon being recorded in the manner required by article XII of the code of civil procedure or by the
uniform commercial code, a lien shall be imposed on the real estate or personal estate, or both, of
the defendant in the amount of any debt due and owing the city under this section. The lien may be
enforced in the same manner as a judgment lien pursuant to a judgment of a court of competent
jurisdiction.
A hearing officer may set aside any judgment entered by default and set a new hearing date, upon
a petition filed within twenty one (21) days after the issuance of the order of default, if the hearing
officer determines that the petitioner's failure to appear at the hearing was for good cause or at any
time if the petitioner establishes that the city did not provide proper service of process. If any
judgment is set aside pursuant to this subsection, the hearing officer shall have authority to enter
an order extinguishing any lien which has been recorded for any debt due and owing the city as a
result of the vacated default judgment. (Ord. 15-O-58, 10-6-2015)
1.7L.14: SANCTIONS APPLICABLE TO THE OWNER AND PROPERTY:
The order to correct a code violation and the sanctions imposed by the city as the result of a finding of
a code violation shall attach to the property as well as to the owner of the property, so that a finding of
a code violation against one owner cannot be avoided by conveying or transferring the property to
another owner. Any subsequent transferee or owner of property takes ownership of the property
subject to the findings, decision and order of the hearing officer under this article. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-
2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 74/525
1.7L.15: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION CONCERNING AUTOMATED TRAFFIC
LAW VIOLATIONS:
Except as otherwise provided for, title 5, chapter 5, "Automated Traffic Law Enforcement", of this code
shall be subject to the procedures of this article. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.16: VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT:
A. Administrative Fee: In addition to any fees charged for the towing and storage of an impounded
vehicle, the city may impose an administrative fee not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00)
related to its administrative and processing costs associated with the investigation, arrest and
detention of an offender, or the removal, impoundment, storage and release of the vehicle. The
administrative fee shall be waived upon verifiable proof that the vehicle was stolen at the time the
vehicle was impounded. (Ord. 12-O-02, 1-17-2012)
B. Violations: The administrative fee may be imposed and a motor vehicle may be impounded upon
probable cause that any of the following violations have occurred:
1. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense
for which a motor vehicle may be seized and forfeited pursuant to section 36-1 of the criminal
code of 2012; or
2. Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an intoxicating compound or
compounds, or any combination thereof, in violation of section 11-501 of the Illinois vehicle code;
or
3. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, a felony or
in violation of the cannabis control act; or
4. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense
in violation of the Illinois controlled substances act; or
5. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense
in violation of section 24-1, 24-1.5, or 24-3.1 of the criminal code of 1961 or the criminal code of
2012; or
6. Driving while a driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or
revoked pursuant to section 6-303 of the Illinois vehicle code; except that vehicles shall not be
subjected to seizure or impoundment if the suspension is for an unpaid citation (parking or
moving) or due to failure to comply with emission testing; or
7. Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possessing, or attempting to solicit or
possess cannabis or a controlled substance, as defined by the cannabis control act or the Illinois
controlled substances act; or
8. Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver's license, in violation of section 6-101
of the Illinois vehicle code, if the period of expiration is greater than one year; or
9. Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit,
in violation of section 6-101 of the Illinois vehicle code, or operating a motor vehicle without ever
having been issued a driver's license or permit due to a person's age; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 75/525
10. Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a warrant has been issued by a
circuit clerk in Illinois for failing to answer charges that the driver violated section 6-101, 6-303,
or 11-501 of the Illinois vehicle code; or
11. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an
offense in violation of article 16 or 16A of the criminal code of 1961 or the criminal code of 2012;
or
12. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, any
