other misdemeanor or felony offense in violation of the criminal code of 1961 or the criminal
code of 2012, when so provided by this code; or
13. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in violation of section 11-503 of the Illinois vehicle code:
a. While the vehicle is part of a funeral procession; or
b. In a manner that interferes with a funeral procession. (Ord. 17-O-03, 1-17-2017)
C. Fees Imposed And Collection: The following shall apply to any fees imposed for administrative and
processing costs pursuant to subsection B of this section:
1. All administrative fees and towing and storage charges shall be imposed on the registered
owner of the motor vehicle or the agents of that owner. The registered owner shall be the record
titleholder to a motor vehicle as registered with the Illinois secretary of state or any other
applicable governmental agency.
2. The fees shall be in addition to: a) any other penalties that may be assessed by a court of law
for the underlying violations; and b) any towing or storage fees, or both, charged by the towing
company.
3. The fees shall be uniform for all similarly situated vehicles.
4. The fees shall be collected by and paid to the city.
5. The towing or storage fees, or both, shall be collected by and paid to the person, firm, or entity
that tows and stores the impounded vehicle. Costs for towing and storage of a motor vehicle
shall be those approved by the chief of police for all tow companies authorized to tow for the
police department.
D. Administrative Hearing: A hearing shall be provided pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-
208.3(b)(4). The vehicle shall be released to the owner of record, lessee or a lienholder of record
upon payment of all administrative fees and towing and storage fees.
E. Administrative Hearing Requirements:
1. Administrative hearings shall be conducted by a hearing officer who is an attorney licensed to
practice law in the state for a minimum of three (3) years and who is not an officer or employee
of the city. The hearing officer shall be designated by the city manager;
2. The hearing officer shall have the power to administer oaths and to secure the attendance and
testimony of witnesses and the production of relevant books and papers via subpoena;
3. The hearing shall be recorded and the technical/formal rules of evidence shall not apply;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 76/525
4. Individuals appearing before the hearing officer shall have the right to be represented by
counsel at their own expense;
5. At the conclusion of the administrative hearing, the hearing officer shall issue a written decision
either sustaining or overruling the vehicle impoundment;
6. If the basis for the vehicle impoundment is sustained by the administrative hearing officer, any
administrative fee posted to secure the release of the vehicle shall be forfeited to the city;
7. All final decisions of the administrative hearing officer shall be subject to review under the
provisions of the administrative review law; and
8. Unless the administrative hearing officer overturns the basis for the vehicle impoundment, no
vehicle shall be released to the owner, lessee or lienholder of record until all administrative fees
and towing and storage charges are paid.
F. Notice Of Impoundment: The following provisions shall be observed concerning notice of
impoundment:
1. Whenever a police officer has cause to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to impoundment,
the officer shall provide for the towing of the vehicle to a facility authorized by the municipality.
2. At the time the vehicle is towed, the city shall notify or make a reasonable attempt to notify the
owner, lessee, or person identifying himself or herself as the owner or lessee of the vehicle, or
any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged offense, of the
fact of the seizure, and of the vehicle owner's or lessee's right to an administrative hearing.
3. The city shall provide notice that the motor vehicle will remain impounded pending the
completion of an administrative hearing, unless the owner or lessee of the vehicle or a lienholder
posts with the city a bond equal to the administrative fee as provided by this section and pays for
all towing and storage charges.
G. Notice Of Hearing: The registered owner or lessee of the vehicle and any lienholder of record shall
be provided with a notice of hearing. The notice shall:
1. Be served upon the owner, lessee and any lienholder of record either by personal service or by
first class mail to the interested party's address as registered with the secretary of state;
2. Be served upon interested parties within ten (10) days after a vehicle is impounded by the city;
and
3. Contain the date, time and location of the administrative hearing. An initial hearing shall be
scheduled and convened no later than forty five (45) days after the date of the mailing of the
notice of hearing.
H. Failure To Retrieve Vehicle: Vehicles not retrieved from the towing or storage facility within thirty
five (35) days after the administrative officer issues a written decision shall be deemed abandoned
and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-201 et
seq., abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed vehicles.
I. Enforcement: Unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, any fine, penalty or administrative
fee imposed under this section which remains unpaid in whole or in part after the expiration of the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 77/525
deadline for seeking review under section 1.7L.12 of this article, may be enforced in the same
manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction.
J. Applicability Of Other Laws: This section is in addition to and shall not replace or otherwise
abrogate any existing state or federal laws or any ordinance that relates to the seizure or
impoundment of motor vehicles, and any fee provided for in this section shall be in addition to any
and all penalties that may be assessed or imposed by a court for any criminal charges. This
section shall not apply: 1) if the motor vehicle used in the violation was stolen at the time of the
violation or 2) if the motor vehicle is subject to successful forfeiture proceedings under 725 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 150/1 et seq., as amended (drug asset forfeiture procedure act); 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/36-1 et seq., as amended (seizure and forfeiture of vessels, vehicles and
aircraft); or 3) other state or federal forfeiture laws.
K. Administrative Review: Any owner of record, lienholder or other person with a legal interest in the
motor vehicle, shall have the right to appeal the decision of the hearing officer to the 22nd judicial
circuit court, pursuant to the administrative review act, 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et
seq., as amended. Any respondent seeking review of a final decision shall be required to
reimburse the city for the costs of preparing and certifying the record of proceedings. Failure of the
respondent to reimburse the city shall be grounds for the dismissal of a complaint for
administrative review pursuant to 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-109. In the event the reviewing
court reverses the findings, decision and order of the administrative law judge, the city will
reimburse the respondent for the costs for preparing and certifying the record of proceedings. Any
administrative fee posted with the city to secure the release of a motor vehicle prior to a hearing
shall be held by the city until the hearing officer issues a decision or, if there is judicial review of the
hearing officer's decision, until a reviewing court issues a final decision.
L. Administrative Fee Refund: A finding of "not guilty" following a trial in the 22nd judicial circuit court
for the underlying violation wherein the motor vehicle was impounded, shall entitle the owner of
record to a full and complete refund of any administrative fee imposed under this section. However,
the owner of record must request the refund in writing and shall include in the request a certified
disposition of "not guilty" following a trial from the 22nd circuit court clerk. An order of dismissal or
a negotiated disposition on the underlying charge(s) shall not result in a refund of the
administrative fee. (Ord. 12-O-02, 1-17-2012)
Chapter 8
MISCELLANEOUS ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS
1.8.1: CORPORATE SEAL:
The corporate seal of the city is as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 78/525
(1963 Code, §20.03; amd. 1986 Code)
1.8.2: CITY DATUM:
The datum for the establishment of grades in the city is established or fixed from time to time by the
council in ordinances or public improvements or otherwise shall refer. This plane is the city datum and
is established at seventy feet (70') below the center of a crosscut in the cornerstone in the northeast
corner of the Woodstock Opera House. The crosscut is marked "city datum" in the stone. (1963 Code,
§20.07; amd. 1986 Code)
1.8.3: ANNUAL AUDIT OF ACCOUNTS:
The city council shall, no later than six (6) months after the close of each fiscal year, cause an audit to
be made of all accounts of the city by a competent person designated by the council and authorized to
act as an auditor under the law1. Copies of such audit report shall be filed with the city clerk and with
the director of the state department of revenue and in such other places as may be required by law or
designated by the council. (1963 Code, §20.10)
1.8.4: REIMBURSEMENT OF CITY EXPENSES:
A. The mayor, city council and/or the city manager may request the city's planning consultant,
engineer, attorney, any other designated consultant, department head, or staff to review petitions,
land use plans, plats and documents pertaining to subdivision or resubdivision, zoning or rezoning
and/or annexation of land for residential purposes either within or outside the corporate boundary
of the city. Request for review shall be made in advance of any preliminary presentation before the
plan commission to allow designated consultants, department heads or staff to be in attendance at
the presentation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 79/525
B. Each department head, individual or firm designated to review a proposed project shall, within
seven (7) days of the request for review, present the city council and property owner or developer
with a written estimate of time, materials, and costs involved. Such costs shall reflect specific areas
of review and standard hourly or per diem rates charged to the city. Where unusual circumstances
involve a number of unknown tasks, a cost ceiling and standard hourly or per diem rate may be set
to allow "work in progress" review and flexibility to cover costs incurred. All activities shall take
place after preliminary presentation of the proposed project before the plan commission and
sufficient copies of all pertinent documents, land use plan, plats and reports shall be made
available for each review, to the plan commission and city council to inform them of the status and
impact of each project. Copies of all reviews and reports shall be made available to the developer.
C. The person petitioning for rezoning and/or annexation or presenting subdivision, resubdivision, or
land use plan shall be notified that the services of the city's department heads, staff, or the
planning consultant, engineer, attorney, or other consultants are required. Such notification shall be
given to the petitioner prior to the preliminary presentation before the plan commission or other
commission, board or the corporate authority. Should additional review be required, subsequent
notice shall be given by the consultant or department head performing the review, to the petitioner
concerning the extent, content, and estimated cost of such review and report. (Ord. 1406, 10-18-
1977)
D. Petitioners for rezoning and/or annexation, or presenting a subdivision, resubdivision, or land use
plan shall, hereafter, deposit with the city clerk, a sum of money as established from time to time
by the city council, as security for the reimbursement of review expenses. Where unusual
problems or conditions are encountered which require additional review, the corporate authority
shall notify the petitioner of such conditions. Should additional funds be required as a deposit, such
notification shall be given to the petitioner. (Ord. 1406, 10-18-1977; amd. 1986 Code)
E. Planning consultants, engineers, attorneys or other consultants to the city shall submit itemized bills
for services, materials and out of pocket costs incurred in performing tasks identified in
subsections A and B of this section to the city. Standard hourly or per diem rates, normally billed to
the city, shall be charged. The city shall be reimbursed for costs paid to its consultants from the
amount on deposit, as required in subsection D of this section. If the amount on deposit shall, for
any reason, be insufficient to fully reimburse the city for any costs and charges so paid, the
deficiency shall be billed to and collected from the owner or developer. Should city staff be involved
in designated review tasks, such services shall be reimbursed to the city in a similar manner,
determined by multiplying the number of hours spent on the review by the average hourly cost of
the city for salary, materials, overhead, fringe benefits and expenses.
F. Normal review procedures will require from thirty (30) to forty five (45) days depending upon
problems encountered. During the review period, the petitioner may request and shall receive a
statement on costs incurred for review activities to date. As services are completed, statements
shall be presented to the city so that compensation may be made following normal administrative
practices of the corporate authority.
G. Funds deposited with the city clerk which are not required to reimburse the planning consultant,
engineer, attorney or other designated consultant shall be returned to the petitioner; provided, that
all services requested have been completed and all bills have been paid in full. (Ord. 1406, 10-18-
1977)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 80/525
1.8.5: USE OF PUBLIC BUILDINGS:
A. Application for the use of any city building other than a park building shall be in writing addressed to
the city clerk. The application shall state the name and address of the applicant, the use for which
the building is desired and the names of at least two (2) references.
B. The city manager, if satisfied that the applicant is of good character and reputation and the purpose
for which the building is desired is worthy, lawful and of a civic nature, shall report the result of his
investigation to the council. In case of rental, the recommendation shall state the amount of rental
and the financial responsibility of the applicant. No lease shall be entered into without the consent
and approval of the council.
C. If the application is approved by the council, the city clerk shall issue the permit, but in the case of a
lease, the lease itself shall constitute the permit. (1963 Code, §20.11)
1.8.6: USE OF CITY COUNCIL CHAMBERS:
A. The general management and direction of the city council chambers and its use shall be vested in
the city manager.
B. Application for the use of the city council chambers by any person shall be submitted, in writing, on
forms provided by the city not less than seven (7) days prior to the date of the proposed use. The
application shall be submitted in writing over the signature of a duly authorized representative of
the group or organization and shall be submitted on the forms provided by the city. All applications
shall be submitted in duplicate. Within seventy two (72) hours after the submission of the
application in proper form, the city manager shall endorse the original application and the copy
either "approved" or "rejected" and return a copy thereof to the applicant with any appropriate
remarks.
1. In the event there is a question in the mind of the city manager as to the propriety of the use or
the propriety of the person as to its eligibility for use, the city manager shall so advise the
applicant and the question of the issuance of the application shall then be placed upon the next
available agenda of the city council for action and approval.
2. The city manager shall, upon submitting an application for the use of the city council chambers
to the city council, circulate copies of the application to each member of the city council with their
regular agenda lists together with any additional remarks he may have regarding the reasons
that the application is on the council's agenda, the basis of his questions and his general
recommendations as to the disposition of the application. Copies of his remarks shall be
distributed to the applicant as well.
3. Upon the submission to the city council by the city manager of a question regarding the
application for use of the city council chambers, the council shall either approve or reject the
application upon the face of the application and the manager's remarks. The council may, upon
motion of any councilman, suspend its rules and the operation of these rules and permit debate
on the issue of the application or barring the applicant. The submission of the application to the
council shall not automatically entitle any person to debate the question before the council.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 81/525
C. The city manager shall keep a record or calendar of the dates for the use of the city council
chambers and shall keep such dates available for public inspection.
D. The permission to use the city council chambers, given by the city manager to any person shall be
secondary and subject to any and all regular, special or adjourned meetings of the city council and
any regular, adjourned or special meetings of any of the boards, committees or commissions
whose memberships are appointed by either the mayor with the advice and consent of the city
council or by the city manager. In the event that the meeting date of the city council or any of its
boards, commissions or committees, as heretofore described, shall fall upon the date for which
permission has been given for use of the city council chambers of any person, the setting of such
date for a meeting by the city council or any of the boards, committees or commissions of the city
shall be deemed an automatic cancellation of such permission. It shall be the duty of the applicant
for use of the city council chambers, to keep itself advised of the availability of the city council
chambers, notwithstanding the issuance of any permit or the allowance of any application.
E. All applications for the use of the city council chambers shall be accompanied by a damage deposit
of fifty dollars ($50.00). The balance of the damage deposit shall be refunded to the person after
deducting any expenses incurred by the city for cleanup, repair or restoration of the city council
chambers after such use by any person hereafter allowed to use the chambers. (Ord. 1085, 5-7-
1974)
Footnote 1: 65 ILCS 5/8-8-1 et seq.
Chapter 9
CITY OWNED REAL ESTATE
1.9.1: SALE OF CITY OWNED REAL ESTATE:
A. The city council may, by resolution or ordinance, authorize the conveyance of real estate if it finds
the real estate is no longer necessary, appropriate, required for the use of, profitable to, or in the
best interests of the city. At such time the city council may also specify the specific use or purpose
to which they would like to see the real estate put.
B. Following such resolution or ordinance, but prior to a subsequent council vote on any offer for the
real estate, the following notice shall be provided:
1. Notice of the proposal to sell shall be published one time in a daily or weekly paper published in
the city, at least thirty (30) days prior to the passage of any resolution or ordinance approving the
conveyance of real estate. Such notice shall:
a. Solicit bids;
b. Contain an accurate description of the property which may include a common street address
and need not include a full metes and bounds legal description;
c. State the specific use or purpose to which the city council would like to see the real estate put,
if any;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 82/525
d. State the date on which bids will be opened by the city administration.
2. Notice of the proposal to sell shall also be mailed, by certified mail, return receipt requested, to
the owners of all property immediately abutting the real estate proposed for sale, but not for
property separated from the real estate proposed for sale by any public right of way or other
intervening barrier between the property lines.
3. The city manager or his designee may provide notice to such other third parties regarding the
proposed real estate sale as, in the city manager's discretion, would be in the best interest of the
city to be invited to bid on the real estate.
4. The city manager or his designee is authorized to open the bids on the date specified in the
notice and may formulate a recommendation for the city council's consideration. This
recommendation may be provided to the city council in advance of the meeting at which the bids
will be considered. In formulating such a recommendation, if the city manager has not already
done so, the city manager or his designee may, but is not required to, obtain one or more
appraisals of the real estate or may otherwise consult with third parties regarding the value or
best use of the real estate.
C. Thereafter, the city council may accept the highest qualified bid or any other bid determined to be in
the best interest of the city or may reject any and all bids by a majority vote of the members of the
city council.
D. The city council may sell, purchase, accept or otherwise transfer real estate from or to another unit
of government in accordance with the Illinois local government property transfer act1 as presently
exists or as may be subsequently amended. (Ord. 17-O-21, 3-7-2017)
Title 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
2.1.1: BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS ESTABLISHED:
To provide for citizen participation in local municipal governance and advise the city council, who
serve as the sole municipal officers and corporate authorities, there are established within the city of
Woodstock the following named boards and commissions:
Board of building construction
Board of fire and police commissioners
Board of library trustees
Cultural and social awareness commission
Economic development commission
Electrical commission
Environmental commission
Historic preservation commission
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 83/525
Opera house advisory commission
Parks and recreation commission
Plan commission
Police pension board
Transportation commission
Zoning board of appeals (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.1.2: GENERAL MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
A. The members of all established boards and commissions shall be appointed by the mayor with the
advice and consent of the city council.
B. All members, including the chair, of each established board and commission shall be voting
members of the respective board or commission.
C. The specific number of members for each established board and commission shall be as
prescribed by Illinois Compiled Statutes or the chapters of this title.
D. The specific terms of members for each established board and commission shall be as prescribed
by Illinois Compiled Statutes or the chapters of this title.
E. The terms of members of all established boards and commissions shall expire on April 30 in the
year of expiration or until such time as a successor is appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council.
F. The members of all established boards and commissions may succeed themselves.
G. The members of all established boards and commissions shall serve without compensation.
H. The members of all established boards and commissions may be revoked by a majority vote of the
city council or by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council.
I. The members of all established boards and commissions shall not be in violation of any provisions
of this code and shall not have any outstanding or delinquent debt owed to the city. The presence
of such a violation or debt may be grounds for revocation.
J. All vacancies on established boards and commissions, whether created by death, resignation, or
removal, shall be filled through appointment by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city
council, but only for the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
K. All members of boards and commissions are subject to all of the city's ethics rules including the gift
ban act, the rules regarding prohibited political activities and any other prohibitions relating to
contracting with the city.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 84/525
L. Any member of an established board or commission having a personal or professional pecuniary
interest in an application before the body in public hearing status shall recuse and disengage from
any participation as a member.
M. The chair of each established board and commission shall be appointed by the mayor with the
advice and consent of the city council unless otherwise established by Illinois Compiled Statutes
and thereby identified in the respective chapter of this title.
N. The chair of each established board and commission may be revoked at the sole discretion of the
mayor unless otherwise established by Illinois Compiled Statutes.
O. A vice chair shall be elected by the appointed members of each established board and commission
from among its respective membership at the first meeting of each year, and herein defined as the
first meeting after the beginning of each fiscal year.
P. A secretary responsible for maintaining minutes and records of all regular and special meetings of
each established board and commission shall be designated as prescribed in the chapters of this
title. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.1.3: GENERAL MEETINGS:
A. Each established board and commission shall hold regular meetings as prescribed in the chapters
of this title and in no case, less than once each year.
B. Special meetings of each established board and commission may be called if deemed necessary
by the chair or a majority of the members of the respective board or commission.
C. For the purposes of conducting business, the quorum for each established board and commission
shall be a simple majority of the board members or commissioners currently appointed and
serving.
D. Attendance or absence of board members or commissioners shall be recorded in the minutes of
every regular and special meeting of every established board and commission. The absence of
any appointed member from three (3) consecutive meetings shall be cause for removal by the
mayor.
E. Approved minutes of all regular and special meetings of each established board and commission
shall be provided to the city council in a timely fashion.
F. All regular and special meetings of each established board and commission shall be held in
compliance with the Illinois open meetings act.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 85/525
G. Except in cases of emergencies, all notices for meetings, including those for special,
nonemergency meetings, shall be provided at least forty eight (48) hours prior to the time set for
the meeting and in the manner required by the open meetings act. It shall be the responsibility of
the city manager or designee to provide such notice. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
H. The public shall be permitted to comment before each board in the same manner as provided in
section 1.5.8 of this code except that for any public hearings, the public shall have the right to
participate in the hearing in the manner established by the chair of that board. (Ord. 15-O-20, 4-7-
2015)
2.1.4: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. The members of the established boards and commissions in their capacity as board members and
commissioners shall not be recognized as officers of the city. The city council serves as the sole
municipal officers and corporate authorities.
B. The established boards and commissions are vested with the general powers and duties prescribed
by the chapters of this title on behalf of the city of Woodstock.
C. Additional powers and duties may be set forth from time to time as provided and directed by the city
council.
D. Additional powers and duties specified in the Illinois Compiled Statutes/Illinois municipal code shall
also apply for each board and commission.
E. In conducting city business, the members of all established boards and commissions shall comport
themselves in an ethical, professional manner.
F. Regulations or guidelines for the conduct of meetings, hearings, or special projects may be
developed by each of the established boards and commissions and, after approval by the city
council, shall be in full force and effect upon filing with the city clerk. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.1.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS ESTABLISHED:
A. The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to all established boards and commissions in
furtherance of the prescribed duties set forth by Illinois Compiled Statutes or the chapters of this
title.
B. Neither board or commission nor any member of a board or commission shall give direction to any
member of the city staff unless otherwise established by Illinois Compiled Statutes and thereby
identified in the respective chapter of this title.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 86/525
C. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the city manager or the designated agent of the
city as specifically set forth in the chapters of this title.
D. Necessary assistants, consultants, or advisors may be employed at the discretion of the city
manager or as otherwise provided by the city council.
E. All recommendations of an established board or commission shall be referred to the city council for
consideration and implementation unless otherwise prescribed by Illinois Compiled Statutes.
F. Neither board or commission nor any member of a board or commission shall have the authority to
make any expenditure, or cause to be made any purchase or contract, that directly or indirectly
results in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior approval of the mayor
and city council unless otherwise established by Illinois Compiled Statutes and thereby identified in
the respective chapter of this title.
G. In the event the provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes/Illinois municipal code and the
provisions of this title conflict, the Illinois Compiled Statutes/Illinois municipal code shall apply.
(Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
Chapter 2
BOARD OF BUILDING CONSTRUCTION
2.2.1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
To provide for the safety and welfare of residents through safe, quality building construction and
building code enforcement, the board of building construction is hereby established in the city. (Ord.
08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.2.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
A. Board Membership: The board shall consist of four (4) members plus an appointed chair. One
member shall be appointed as the representative of the Woodstock fire/rescue district and at least
three (3) members shall reside within the corporate boundaries of the city of Woodstock.
Voting members shall be appointed recognizing the municipal interest of providing cross sector
representation from the building trades. Therefore, consideration should be given to the
contractor/construction, electrical and plumbing sectors.
All members and the chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city
council.
B. Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the chair, shall be for three (3) years.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 87/525
C. Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
D. Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council in
May of each year. It shall be the duty of the chair to conduct all meetings of the board and to
represent the board at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
E. Vice Chair: The board shall elect a vice chair from among its membership at the first meeting of
each year.
F. Secretary: The appointed staff liaison shall serve as secretary and maintain minutes and records of
regular and special meetings and regularly provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-0-68,
11-4-2008)
2.2.3: MEETINGS:
A. The board shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the chair or a majority of the
board.
B. All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open meetings act. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-
2008)
2.2.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. The board shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the Woodstock city council and shall comply
with all applicable provisions of Illinois state statutes and this code.
B. Specific duties of the board shall be limited to providing for the safety and welfare of residents
through safe, quality building construction and building code enforcement in the city of Woodstock
by:
1. Assisting the building and zoning officers of the city in interpreting the specific ordinances for
which they are responsible.
2. Recommending to the city council amendments to building codes and relevant city ordinances
as may, from time to time, be appropriate.
3. Considering applications for and the results of new materials and methods testing. (Ord. 08-0-
68, 11-4-2008)
4. Preparing and disseminating educational materials regarding city building codes and inspection
procedures. The board shall not, however, have the authority to consider appeals of orders,
decisions, or determinations regarding noncompliance with the city's building codes, the
issuance of citations for building code violations, or the adjudication of such violations.
5. Fostering communication between the public and city regarding ongoing activities of the board.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 88/525
6. Arranging and conducting any form of publicity relative to its activities for the general purpose of
increasing public understanding. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 09-0-24, 4-21-2009, eff. 5-
1-2009)
2.2.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
A. The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the board of building construction in order to
assist the board with its various duties. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the city
manager for appropriate response by the city. Neither the board nor any of its members shall give
direction to any member of the city staff and all recommendations of the board shall be referred to
the city council for consideration and implementation by the city.
B. The board shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or cause to be made any purchase
or contract that directly or indirectly results in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the
express prior approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
Chapter 3
BOARD OF LIBRARY TRUSTEES
2.3.1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
A. To provide and maintain a public library and associated services for the benefit of residents, a
board of trustees of the Woodstock public library is hereby established in the city.
B. For purposes of reference and financial accounting within the municipality, the board of trustees of
the Woodstock public library shall also be known as, and shall serve as one in the same as, the
board of library trustees.
C. The board shall have the following specific responsibilities:
1. To adopt and revise policies so that proper courses of action may be taken;
2. To see that the library has the necessary funds for proper administration of the library; and
3. To see that the public understands the goals and objectives of the library. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-
2008)
2.3.2: MEMBERSHIP AND TERMS:
A. Board Membership: The board of library trustees of the Woodstock public library, a.k.a., board of
library trustees, shall consist of nine (9) members, all of whom shall reside within the corporate
boundaries of the city of Woodstock, shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 89/525
of the city council, and chosen with reference to their fitness for such office. No more than one
member of the city council shall be at any one time a member of the board.
B. Term Of Office: The term of office for all members shall be for three (3) years.
C. Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
D. Officers: The officers of the board shall be a president, vice president, secretary and treasurer who
shall all be elected at the first regular meeting of the board following the annual appointment of
trustees.
E. President: It shall be the duty of the president to preside at all meetings of the board, appoint all
committees, act as ex officio member of all committees, and represent the board at city council
meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
F. Vice President: It shall be the duty of the vice president to perform the duties of the president as
from time to time may be necessary in the absence of the president.
G. Secretary: It shall be the duty of the secretary to notify each member of the board of all regular and
special meetings, including the statement of purpose of each meeting; to maintain minutes and
records of regular and special meetings; and regularly provide such records to the city council.
H. Treasurer: It shall be the duty of the treasurer to report on the status of funds received by the library
and to review their proper disbursement. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 19-07 - BOARD OF LIBRARY
TRUSTEES. Go to new ordinance.
2.3.3: MEETINGS:
A. Meetings of the board shall be held no less than monthly on the first Thursday of each calendar
month in the library or at such time and place as the board may determine.
B. Additional special meetings may be called if deemed necessary by the president, secretary or any
two (2) members of the board, provided that notice of the meeting is provided to all members of the
board at least forty eight (48) hours prior to the time set for the meeting. The notice of a special
meeting shall state the purpose of the meeting and no business other than that stated in the notice
shall be transacted.
C. The board shall cause to have posted said notice of a special meeting at all public library facilities
maintained by the board and not less than one other public place within the city at least forty eight
(48) hours prior to the time set for the special meeting.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 90/525
D. All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open meetings act. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-
2008)
2.3.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of library trustees of the Woodstock public library, a.k.a., board of library trustees, shall
have the following powers and duties:
A. To make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their own guidance and for the
government of the library as may be expedient, not inconsistent with this chapter.
B. To have exclusive control of the expenditure of all monies collected for the library and deposited to
the credit of the library fund.
C. To have the exclusive control of the construction of any library building and of the supervision, care,
and custody of the grounds, rooms or buildings constructed, leased or set apart for that purpose.
D. To purchase or lease real or personal property, and to construct an appropriate building or buildings
for the use of the library, using, at the board's option, contracts providing for all or part of the
consideration to be paid through installments at stated intervals during a certain period not to
exceed twenty (20) years with interest at any lawful rate for municipal corporations in the state of
Illinois on the unpaid balance or such legally applicable rate in effect at the time such contract is
made, whichever is higher, except that contracts which call for installment purchases of real estate
shall provide for not more than seventy five percent (75%) of the total consideration to be repaid by
installments.
E. To remodel or reconstruct a building erected or purchased by the board when such building is not
adapted to its purposes or needs.
F. To sell or otherwise dispose of real or personal property that it no longer deems necessary or useful
for library purposes and to lease to others any real property not immediately useful but for which
plans for ultimate use have been or will be adopted but the city council shall have the first right to
purchase or lease such property.
G. To appoint and to fix the compensation of a qualified librarian who shall have the authority to hire
such other employees as may be necessary, to fix their compensation, to remove such appointees,
subject to the approval of the board and in accordance to Illinois state statutes, and to retain
counsel and professional consultants as needed.
H. To contract with any library association, school board, or any city, village, incorporated town,
township, county or district library board in the state for furnishing or receiving library services
including, but not limited to, contracts for such library services as participants in any library system
formed pursuant to law and as participants in interstate library compacts, and to contract to supply
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 91/525
library services and for the expenditure of any federal or state funds made available to any county,
municipality, township or the state of Illinois for library purposes.
I. To join with the board or boards of any one or more libraries of any city, incorporated town, village,
township, county, or district in maintaining libraries, or for the maintenance of a common library for
such cities, incorporated towns, villages, townships, county or districts upon such terms as may be
agreed upon by and between the boards.
J. To enter into contracts and to take title to any property acquired by it for library purposes by the
name and style of the board of library trustees of the city of Woodstock, McHenry County, Illinois,
and by that name to sue and be sued.
K. To exclude from the use of the library any person who unlawfully violates the rules prescribed by
the board.
L. To extend the privileges and use of the library to persons residing outside the city, incorporated
town, village or township upon such terms and conditions as the board may from time to time by its
regulations prescribe and to impose a nonresident fee for such privileges and uses comparable to
the cost to residents of such entity.
M. To exercise the power of eminent domain subject to the prior approval of the city council as
provided by law.
N. To join the public library as a member in the Illinois Library Association and the American Library
Association, nonprofit, nonpolitical associations as designed by the federal internal revenue
service, having the purpose of library development and librarianship; to provide for the payment of
annual membership dues, fees and assessments and act by, through and in the name of such
instrumentality by providing and disseminating information and research services, employing
personnel and doing any and all other acts for the purpose of improving library development.
O. To invest funds pursuant to Illinois state statutes.
P. To lease from any public building commission created pursuant to the provisions of the public
building commission act, any real or personal property for library purposes for a period of time not
to exceed twenty (20) years.
Q. To pay for the use of such leased property in accordance with the terms of the lease and with the
provisions of the public building commission act as now or hereafter amended.
R. To enter into such a lease without making a previous appropriation for the expense thereby
incurred according to the limitations provided by law.
S. To pay all or part of the cost of maintaining and owning any property leased from the public building
commission for the term or within the period provided by law. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 92/525
2.3.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
A. The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the board of trustees of the Woodstock public
library, a.k.a., board of library trustees, in order to assist the board with its various duties. All
requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the director of the library for appropriate response by
the city. Neither the board nor any of its members shall give direction to any member of the city
staff. Unless otherwise set forth herein or established by Illinois state statutes, all
recommendations of the board shall be referred to the city council for consideration and
implementation by the city.
B. Except as specifically stated in this chapter, the board shall not have the authority to make any
expenditure, or cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results in a
financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior approval of the mayor and city
council. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
Chapter 4
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
2.4.1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
To provide for the safety and protection of residents through the employment of highly qualified and
professional sworn officers of the police department, and in accordance with Illinois state statutes, the
board of fire and police commissioners is hereby established in the city. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.4.2: MEMBERSHIP AND TERMS:
A. Board Membership: The board of fire and police commissioners shall consist of three (3) members,
including an appointed chair, all of which shall reside within the corporate boundaries of the city of
Woodstock. All members, including the chair, shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council.
B. Officers: As an exception to subsection 2.1.4A of this title, the board of fire and police
commissioners shall be considered officers of the city and shall file an oath and a fidelity bond in
such amount as from time to time may be required by the city council.
C. Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the chair, shall be for three (3) years.
D. Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 93/525
E. Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council in
May of each year. It shall be the duty of the chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to
represent the commission at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
F. Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its membership at the first meeting
of each year.
G. Secretary: The administrative assistant to the chief of police or designee shall serve as secretary
and maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and regularly provide such
records to the city council. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.4.3: MEETINGS:
A. The board shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the chair or a majority of the
board.
B. Notice of a board meeting shall be given in writing to each member of the board at least twenty four
(24) hours prior to the time set for the meeting. Additionally, notice of the meeting shall be posted
in a conspicuous place in the police department not less than twenty four (24) hours prior to any
board meeting. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.4.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of fire and police commissioners shall have the following powers and duties pertaining to
sworn members of the police department:
A. To make and promulgate rules and regulations for the conduct of examinations for original
appointments, conduct of examinations for promotions, and conduct of hearings on charges
brought against a member of the police department.
B. To conduct examinations for original appointments and promotions.
C. To make all original appointments to the police department and appointments to promotions within
the police department pursuant to examinations.
D. To conduct hearings on charges brought against any member of the police department.
E. Such other and further powers as may from time to time be authorized by the Illinois general
assembly. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.4.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 94/525
A. The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the board of fire and police commissioners in
order to assist the board with its various duties. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to
the chief of police for appropriate response by the city. Neither the board nor any of its members
shall give direction to any member of the city staff. Unless otherwise set forth herein or established
by Illinois state statutes, all recommendations of the board shall be referred to the city council for
consideration and implementation by the city.
B. The board shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or cause to be made any purchase
or contract that directly or indirectly results in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the
express prior approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
Chapter 5
CULTURAL AND SOCIAL AWARENESS COMMISSION
2.5.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To further the goals of eliminating prejudice and discrimination, enhancing awareness of the benefits
of a culturally diverse community, and awareness of current social issues within a vital, growing
community, a Cultural and Social Awareness Commission is hereby established in the City. (Ord. 12-
O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.5.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
A. Commission Membership: The commission shall consist of six (6) members plus an appointed
Chair. At least four (4) of the members shall reside within the corporate boundaries of the City of
Woodstock. All members and the Chair shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of the City Council. (Ord. 17-O-47, 5-16-2017)
B. Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the Chair, shall be for three (3) years.
C. Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of the City Council, but only for the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
D. Chair: The Chair shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the City Council in
May of each year. It shall be the duty of the Chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to
represent the commission at City Council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
E. Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a Vice Chair from among its membership at the first
meeting of each year.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 95/525
F. Secretary: The City Clerk or designee shall serve as Secretary and maintain minutes and records of
regular and special meetings and regularly provide such records to the City Council. (Ord. 12-O-
21, 3-20-2012)
2.5.3: MEETINGS:
A. The commission shall meet no less than quarterly in January, April, July and October.
Additional meetings may be called if deemed necessary by the Chair or a majority of the
commission.
B. All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-
2012)
2.5.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. The commission shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the Woodstock City Council and shall
comply with all applicable provisions of Illinois State Statutes and this Code.
B. The commission shall serve to encourage and ensure equality of opportunity for all people of
Woodstock, regardless of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, disability, age, marital status or
sexual orientation and to promote awareness of current social issues affecting the well being of the
community and its residents. Social issues may include, but shall not be limited to, issues of
underage consumption of alcohol, the abuse of alcohol and other drugs, synthetic drugs, safe
driving and good neighbor initiatives.
C. Specific duties of the commission shall be limited to promoting cultural diversity education,
awareness of current social issues, and associated outreach, recognition and celebration in the
City of Woodstock through:
1. Preparation and dissemination of promotional and educational materials regarding the City, its
services, programs and opportunities.
2. Preparation and dissemination of promotional and educational materials regarding the impact of
diverse cultural contributions and current social issues to the richness and well being of the
community.
3. Developing and executing a plan of action for fostering communication with and encouraging
participation by residents of all segments of the community. The plan may include, but shall not
be limited to, an active Sister City Program and New Americans' Initiative, as well as joint
dialogue and programming with Woodstock Community Unit School District 200 and other
agencies and organizations in McHenry County and broader community.
4. Serving as a resource for institutions and organizations concerned with social awareness,
cultural diversity and equality.
5. Establishing and executing ongoing recognition programs to foster and enhance individual,
organizational, public and private efforts to eliminate prejudice and discrimination and promote
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 96/525
diversity and social awareness.
6. Establishing and executing ongoing programs designed to celebrate diversity and its unique and
positive impact on the fabric of the community.
7. Preparing and submitting an annual report of its activities to the City Council.
8. Fostering communication between the public and City regarding its ongoing activities.
9. Arranging and conducting any form of publicity relative to its activities for the general purpose of
increasing public understanding.
D. The commission shall not debate, participate or engage in the provision of social services as such
services distinctly do not fall under the purview of this municipal government. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-
2012)
2.5.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
A. The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the cultural and social awareness commission in
order to assist the commission with its various duties. All requests for assistance are to be
conveyed to the city manager for appropriate response by the city. Neither the commission nor any
of its members shall give direction to any member of the city staff and all recommendations of the
commission shall be referred to the city council for consideration and implementation by the city.
B. The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or cause to be made any
purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results in a financial liability or lien against the city,
without the express prior approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
Chapter 6
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
2.6.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To further the goal of economic development, an economic development commission to promote and
enhance the business climate, support business retention and expansion, and encourage the location
of new business and industry is hereby established in the city. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.6.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
A. Commission Membership: The commission shall consist of four (4) members, plus an appointed
chair. At least three (3) members shall reside within the corporate boundaries of the city of
Woodstock.
Members shall be appointed recognizing the municipal interest of providing cross sector
representation from within the business community. Therefore, consideration should be given to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 97/525
sectors including, but not limited to: retail, industrial, building trades, banking, healthcare, real
estate and real estate development.
All members and the chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city
council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
B. Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the chair, shall be for three (3) years.
C. Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
D. Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council in
May of each year. It shall be the duty of the chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to
represent the commission at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
E. Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its membership at the first meeting
of each year.
F. Secretary: The appointed staff liaison shall serve as secretary and maintain minutes and records of
regular and special meetings and regularly provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68,
11-4-2008)
2.6.3: MEETINGS:
The commission shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the chair or a majority of the
commission. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.6.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. The commission shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the Woodstock city council and shall
comply with all applicable provisions of Illinois state statutes and this code.
B. The commission shall investigate and become informed about existing businesses, commercial
enterprises and industries in the city in an effort to encourage and promote business retention and
expansion.
C. The commission shall investigate and become informed about new business development interests
and opportunities within the city and aggressively promote the city to appropriate entrepreneurs
and business entities in an effort to satisfy such opportunities.
D. The commission shall investigate and become informed about the economic climate of the
community and periodically evaluate program and policy opportunities that could positively impact
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 98/525
the climate. Upon consideration of such opportunities, the commission shall forward appropriate
recommendations to the city council for consideration.
E. The commission shall consider and evaluate all economic development opportunities recognizing
the underlying city interests of:
1. Improving the quality of life.
2. Job creation.
3. Provision of services and opportunities for residents.
4. Improvement of the municipal tax base minimal impact upon the natural environment.
5. The value of an open, inclusive residential, business and work environment.
F. The commission shall prepare and recommend to the city council an economic development plan,
looking to the present and future development and growth of the city. Such plan should include an
inventory of vacant and available commercial property, identify areas of business interest and
need, and a strategy for promoting business retention, expansion and attraction.
G. The commission shall prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time such changes
in the plan as may be deemed necessary by the council or the economic development
commission, but not less often than once every five (5) years.
H. The commission shall prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time,
recommendations for specific improvements, additions to or deletions from the plan.
I. Arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities for the general purpose of
increasing public awareness and understanding.
J. Nothing in this section shall be construed to provide or imply a right or responsibility of the
commission to advise or participate in any review or approval process under the specific purview of
other city boards and commissions. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.6.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
A. The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the economic development commission in order
to assist the commission with its various duties. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to
the city manager for appropriate response by the city. Neither the commission nor any of its
members shall give direction to any member of the city staff and all recommendations of the
commission shall be referred to the city council for consideration and implementation by the city.
B. The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or cause to be made any
purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results in a financial liability or lien against the city,
without the express prior approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 99/525
Chapter 7
ELECTRICAL COMMISSION
2.7.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To provide for the safety and welfare of residents through safe, quality electrical installation and
conveyance and code enforcement, the electrical commission is hereby established in the city. (Ord.
08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.7.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
A. Commission Membership: The electrical commission shall consist of three (3) members plus an
appointed chair. The chief electrical inspector shall be one of the members and at least two (2) of
the members shall reside within the corporate boundaries of the city of Woodstock.
Members shall be appointed recognizing the municipal interest of providing cross representation
from the associated trades. Therefore, consideration should be given to the inclusion of a
professional electrical engineer, an electrical contractor, a journeyman electrician, an electrical
supplier, and a representative of the Woodstock fire/rescue district.
All members and the chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city
council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
B. Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the chair, shall be for three (3) years.
C. Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
D. Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council in
May of each year. It shall be the duty of the chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to
represent the commission at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
E. Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its membership at the first meeting
of each year.
F. Secretary: The appointed staff liaison shall serve as secretary and maintain minutes and records of
regular and special meetings and regularly provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68,
11-4-2008)
2.7.3: MEETINGS:
A. The electrical commission shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the chair or a
majority of the commission.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 100/525
B. The chief electrical inspector or designee shall attend all meetings of the commission. (Ord. 08-O-
68, 11-4-2008)
2.7.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. The commission shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the Woodstock city council and shall
comply with all applicable provisions of Illinois state statutes and this code.
B. Specific duties of the commission shall be limited to providing for the safety and welfare of
residents through safe, quality electrical installation and conveyance and code enforcement in the
city of Woodstock by:
1. Assisting the chief electrical inspector of the city in interpreting the specific ordinances for which
they are responsible.
2. Recommending to the city council safe and practical standards and specifications for the
installation, alteration and use of electrical equipment in the city designed to meet the
necessities and conditions of the municipality. Such standards and specifications shall not be
effective until adopted as an ordinance by the city council.
3. Recommending reasonable rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits and fees to
be paid. Such rules, regulations and fees shall not be effective until adopted as an ordinance by
the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
4. Preparing and disseminating educational materials regarding city electrical standards and
inspection procedures. The commission shall not, however, have the authority to consider
appeals of orders, decisions, or determinations regarding noncompliance with the city's electrical
codes and standards, the issuance of citations for violations of said electrical codes and
standards, or the adjudication of such violations.
5. Fostering communication between the public and city regarding its ongoing activities.
6. Arranging and conducting any form of publicity relative to its activities for the general purpose of
increasing public understanding. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 09-O-24, 4-21-2009, eff.
5-1-2009)
2.7.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
A. The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the electrical commission in order to assist the
commission with its various duties. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the city
manager for appropriate response by the city. Neither the commission nor any of its members shall
give direction to any member of the city staff and all recommendations of the commission shall be
referred to the city council for consideration and implementation by the city.
B. The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or cause to be made any
purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results in a financial liability or lien against the city,
without the express prior approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 101/525
Chapter 8
ENVIRONMENTAL COMMISSION
2.8.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
The environmental commission is hereby established in the city. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.8.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
A. Commission Membership: The commission shall consist of four (4) members plus an appointed
chair. All members shall be residents of McHenry County. Two (2) members and the chair shall be
appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council and the remainder shall
include one representative selected by and from each of the following community based
constituent groups:
McHenry County Defenders
Land Conservancy Of McHenry County
Of the two (2) members and the chair appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the
city council, none may be members of the governing boards of the above identified constituent
groups. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
B. Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the chair, shall be for three (3) years.
C. Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled by appointment by the appointing authority, but only for the
unexpired portion of the vacated term.
D. Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council in
May of each year. It shall be the duty of the chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to
represent the commission at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
E. Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its membership at the first meeting
of each year.
F. Secretary: The city clerk or designee shall serve as secretary and maintain minutes and records of
regular and special meetings and regularly provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68,
11-4-2008)
2.8.3: MEETINGS:
A. The commission shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the chair or a majority of the
commission.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 102/525
B. All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open meetings act. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-
2008)
2.8.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The commission shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the Woodstock city council and shall
comply with all applicable provisions of Illinois state statutes and this code. Specific duties of the
commission shall be limited to:
A. Prepare and recommend to the city council an environmental plan, looking to the present and future
development and growth of the city. Such plan should include and identify, in conformance with the
comprehensive plan of the city of Woodstock, open spaces, including municipal parks and
identified conservation areas, wetlands and water recharge areas, and forests.
B. Prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time such changes in the plan as may be
deemed necessary by the council or the environmental commission, but not less often than once
every five (5) years.
C. Prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time, recommendations for specific
improvements, additions or deletions to the plan.
D. Provide input and advice to the city council regarding contracts between the city and conservation
management organizations and associated management plans.
E. Provide input and advice to the city council on issues referred to the commission by specific action
of the city council and associated with specific USEPA or IEPA monitoring or oversight projects.
F. Provide input and advice to the city council on issues referred to the commission by specific action
of the city council on topics such as wetland remediation, groundwater regeneration and quality,
the municipal use of insecticides for control of mosquitoes and other insect pests, tree inventories
and maintenance.
G. Foster communication between the public and city regarding ongoing environmental protection and
oversight efforts.
H. Arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities for the general purpose of
increasing public understanding. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.8.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
A. The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the environmental commission in order to assist
the commission with its various duties. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the city
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 103/525
manager for appropriate response by the city. Neither the commission nor any of its members shall
give direction to any member of the city staff and all recommendations of the commission shall be
referred to the city council for consideration and implementation by the city.
B. The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or cause to be made any
purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results in a financial liability or lien against the city,
without the express prior approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
Chapter 9
HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION
2.9.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To promote the preservation of historically significant buildings and structures within the municipality
and pursue the objectives and procedures contained in this code, the historic preservation
commission is hereby established in the city. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.9.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
A. Commission Membership: The commission shall consist of four (4) members plus an appointed
chair. At least three (3) members shall live within the corporate boundaries of the city of
Woodstock.
All members and the chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city
council.
All members shall be selected on the basis of their demonstrated interest, competence or
knowledge of historic preservation. Other criteria for selection may include vocation, employment,
community interests, artistic skill, or special training or knowledge in the development of the city.
Further, members shall be appointed recognizing the municipal interest of providing cross sector
representation from within the community. Therefore, reasonable consideration should be given to
professionals in the disciplines of history, architectural history, architecture planning, archaeology,
historic preservation or related field; property or business owners within the historic downtown
area; real estate professionals; and representatives from the fields of engineering and
construction. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
B. Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the chair, shall be for three (3) years.
C. Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
D. Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council in
May of each year. It shall be the duty of the chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to
represent the commission at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 104/525
E. Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its membership at the first meeting
of each year.
F. Secretary: The city clerk or designee shall serve as secretary and maintain minutes and records of
regular and special meetings and regularly provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68,
11-4-2008)
2.9.3: MEETINGS:
A. The commission shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the chair or a majority of the
commission.
B. All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open meetings act. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-
2008)
2.9.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The historic preservation commission shall have the following powers and duties:
A. Work to establish greater public interest and participation in historic preservation within the city.
B. Formulate standards and regulations for the evaluation of proposed landmark and historic
preservation district designation and rules of procedure for application and hearings. Such
regulations and rules of procedure shall be submitted to the city council and shall be approved by
the city council in advance of their application to specific projects.
C. Prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time such changes in standards,
regulations and rules as may be deemed necessary by the city council or the commission.
D. Develop and conduct an ongoing survey of the city, to identify buildings, structures, areas, sites and
landscapes that are of historic, archaeological, architectural, or scenic significance, and, therefore,
are potential landmarks or historic preservation districts.
E. Hold public hearings and recommend to the city council the designation of landmarks and historic
preservation districts identified in the survey.
F. Compile and retain information concerning landmarks and historic preservation districts identified
and recommended for designation. This shall include descriptions of the landmarks and historic
preservation districts and the characteristics that meet the standards for designation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 105/525
G. Keep a register of all designated landmarks and historic preservation districts and prepare, update
and publish a map or maps showing the locations and exact boundaries of proposed and
designated landmarks and historic preservation districts, and, if the commission so chooses, the
locations and/or boundaries of designated McHenry County, state or national landmarks or
districts.
H. Establish an appropriate system of markers and plaques for all designated landmarks and historic
preservation districts, and to confer recognition upon the owners of landmarks and property within
historic preservation districts by means of certificates, plaques and markers.
I. Nominate landmarks and historic preservation districts to any state or national register of historic
places.
J. Advise and assist owners of landmarks and property within the historic preservation districts on
physical and financial aspects of preservation, renovation, rehabilitation and reuse, and on
procedures of any state or any national register of historic places.
K. Inform and educate the citizens of the city concerning the historic, archaeological, architectural and
scenic heritage of the city by publishing appropriate maps, newsletters, brochures and pamphlets,
and by holding programs and seminars.
L. Develop specific criteria and guidelines for the proper alteration, construction, demolition or removal
of landmarks, or of property within a historic preservation district. Such criteria and guidelines shall
be submitted to the city council and shall be approved by the city council in advance of their
application to specific projects.
M. Consider certificate of hardship applications that would allow the performance of work for which a
certificate of appropriateness has been denied pursuant to this code.
N. Consider the issuance of certificates of appropriateness for category 2, major projects, and appeals
when applications for certificates of appropriateness for category 1, minor projects, are denied.
O. Review proposed amendments to zoning regulations, applications for special use permits and
applications for zoning variations that affect any landmark or historic preservation district. Notice of
