Nonresident adult $145.00 per game/field
Nonresident youth 105.00 per game/field
Resident adult 65.00 per game/field
Resident youth No fee for resident youth leagues
(Ord. 08-O-46, 7-15-2008, eff. 1-1-2009)
D. The city shall have the authority to determine the category of user group for the purpose of
calculating fees and charges. Where possible, the determination of the user group classification
shall be made by the city utilizing a current list of participants, to be provided by the user group, for
the same year. In the event that a membership list is not available for the current year, the
determination of the user group shall be made by the city utilizing a list of participants, to be
provided by the group, from the previous year.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 402/525
E. Each user group shall be required to submit information to the city as part of the permit process for
the use of city park facilities, athletic facilities, and recreational facilities. The city reserves the right
to reject any application that does not include the necessary membership information. In the event
that the user group fails to provide the membership information as part of the permit application, or
when requested by the city, the city may then automatically classify the user group as a
"nonresident user group" and shall charge the appropriate fees. (Ord. 2605, 2-6-1996)
F. (Rep. by Ord. 06-O-81, 11-7-2006, eff. 1-1-2007)
G. The fees for any one year period for any user group which has completed a capital improvement
project formally authorized by the city may, upon the formal written request of the user group, be
waived up to the value of the completed improvement. Such request for a waiver shall be
submitted to the parks and recreation commission within one year of the completion of the capital
improvement project for review. The parks and recreation commission shall then submit a
recommendation to the city council regarding the fee waiver request and the decision of the city
council shall then be final. (Ord. 2605, 2-6-1996)
H. The fees required in this chapter shall be subject to a "CPI adjustment" which shall be calculated
on January 1, 2010, and on January 1 in each year thereafter. Annually, the fees and cash
contributions shall be adjusted by the December through December percent change as published
by the United States department of labor's bureau of labor statistics, all items consumer price
index ("CPI") for urban consumers (1982-1984 = 100) for the Chicago consolidated metropolitan
statistical area, Illinois. If any index is calculated from a base different from the base period 1982-
1984 = 100, such index shall be converted to a base period of 1982-1984 = 100 by use of a
conversion factor supplied by said bureau of labor statistics. If the CPI is discontinued or replaced,
such other governmental cost of living index or computation which replaces the CPI shall be used
in order to obtain substantially the same result as would be obtained if the CPI had not been
discontinued or replaced. (Ord. 08-O-46, 7-15-2008, eff. 1-1-2009)
6.2.4: REQUIRED POLICE SUPERVISION:
A. Determination By Size: No organization sponsoring a picnic at which the anticipated or expected
attendance is in excess of one hundred fifty (150) shall be granted a permit unless, at the time
application for the picnic permit is made, arrangements have been made for the supervision of
such picnic by off duty police officers. For each anticipated three hundred fifty (350) persons, or
part thereof, in excess of one hundred fifty (150) persons, provisions shall be made for supervision
by one off duty police officer. All expenses attendant to the supervision by off duty police officers
shall be borne by the sponsoring organization and shall be paid in advance.
B. Possible Exclusion: This requirement shall not apply to organizations whose entire attendance at a
picnic, excluding supervisory personnel, is limited to children not older than twelfth grade school
age, unless, in the opinion of the Chief of Police, such police supervision is necessary.
C. Approval: Arrangements for off duty police officers shall be subject to the approval of the Chief of
Police. (Ord. 1914, 5-21-1985)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 403/525
6.2.5: HOURS FOR CITY PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS, PUBLIC FACILITIES AND
PUBLIC GROUNDS:
A. Emricson Park: It shall be unlawful for any person to be present in Emricson Park between the
hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. or not more than fifteen (15) minutes following the completion
of a City approved recreational activity (whichever is later) and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. (Ord. 05-O-
109, 11-1-2005)
B. Sesquicentennial Park And Park In The Square: It shall be unlawful for any person to remain in
Sesquicentennial Park or Park in the Square between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. or
not more than fifteen (15) minutes following the completion of a City approved recreational activity
(whichever is later) and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. Pedestrian traffic is allowed during prohibited hours
provided that pedestrians traverse the park without stopping or loitering. (Ord. 15-O-55, 9-15-2015)
C. Public Facilities And Public Grounds: In addition to any prescribed hours for any public park, it shall
be unlawful for any person to occupy or use any individual public facilities (including those within
City parks or playgrounds and on public grounds) or public grounds (outside of City parks) in
excess of four (4) hours in any twenty four-hour period unless such use or occupancy is associated
with a City authorized event or program.
D. All Other: Unless otherwise specifically provided for in this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any
person to be present in or on any park, playground, public facility and public grounds within the
City between dusk and dawn or not more than fifteen (15) minutes following the completion of a
City-approved activity (whichever is later) and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. (Ord. 17-O-90, 10-17-2017)
6.2.6: PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person using any parks, playgrounds, public facilities and public grounds
within the City to either perform or permit to be performed any of the following acts: (Ord. 17-O-90, 10-
17-2017)
A. Vandalism: Wilfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, or displace or remove any buildings,
bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, paving or paving material, water lines or other public
utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or
permanent, monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers or other structures or
equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal.
B. Pollution Of Waters: Throw, discharge or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any
fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or other body of water, in the City park or any tributary, stream,
storm drain or drain flowing into such waters, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which
would or may result in the pollution of said waters.
C. Dumping Refuse Or Trash: Bring in or dump, deposit or leave any empty bottles, broken glass,
ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage or refuse or other trash. No refuse or
trash of any kind, nature or description shall be placed in any waters in or contiguous to any park
or left anywhere on the grounds thereof but shall be placed in proper receptacles where these are
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 404/525
provided. Where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away
from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere.
D. Endangerment: Endanger the safety of any person by any conduct.
E. Assault, Battery Or Fighting: Commit any assault, battery or engage in any fighting.
F. Interference: Prevent any person from using any park or any of its facilities or interfere with such
use in compliance with this chapter and the rules applicable thereto.
G. Swimming Or Bathing: Swim, bathe or wade in any waters in or adjacent to any park except in such
waters and at such places as are provided therefor and in compliance with such regulations as are
adopted with respect to such use.
H. Dressing Or Undressing: Dress or undress except in bathing houses or structures as may be
provided for that purpose.
I. Activity Areas: Engage in flying model airplanes, golf practice, ice skating and picnics except at
locations specifically designated for such activities by the Director of Public Works. (Ord. 1096, 7-
2-1974)
J. Vehicles In Parks:
1. Drive or park any motor vehicles except on a street, driveway, or parking lot in any park or to
park and/or leave any such vehicle in any place other than one established for public parking.
Drive, park, or otherwise operate a motorized vehicle of any type on any recreational path
whether paved or unpaved in any park. This prohibition of the operation of motorized vehicles on
a recreation path shall not apply to vehicles and equipment owned by the City or authorized by
the City, when being used for the maintenance of park lands and facilities. (Ord. 02-O-97, 11-5-
2002)
2. It shall be unlawful to operate any unregistered or unlicensed vehicle at any time in any City
park.
3. It shall be unlawful for any person not holding a valid driver's license to operate any vehicle at
any time in any portion of a City park.
4. No vehicle which has an overall length of more than twenty feet (20') or an average width of
more than eight feet (8') shall be parked in any parking lot in a City park.
5. No vehicle shall be parked so that it occupies more than one designated parking space.
6. No vehicle shall be parked or left unattended in any City park after the stated time of closing.
7. Use of all driveways, roadways, and parking areas by vehicles in excess of eight thousand
(8,000) pounds' GVW in all City parks is hereby prohibited, without special permission from the
City Manager. (Ord. 2508, 10-4-1994)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 405/525
8. Operation of any snowmobile in any Municipally owned park within the City at any time.
9. Operation of any motorized off road vehicle in any Municipally owned park within the City at any
time. This prohibition of the operation of motorized off road vehicles shall not apply to vehicles
and equipment owned by the City or authorized by the City, when used for the maintenance of
park lands and facilities. (Ord. 99-O-48, 8-17-1999)
K. Dangerous Animals: Bring any dangerous animal into the City park, and it shall be unlawful to
permit any dog to be in the City park unless on a leash not more than six feet (6') in length. (Ord.
1096, 7-2-1974)
L. Peddling: To vend, sell, peddle or offer for sale any commodity or article within any park, unless
specifically authorized to do so by the City Council. (Ord. 1096, 7-2-1974; amd. 1986 Code)
M. Smoking: To smoke, burn or use any cigarette, cigar, or other form of or device containing tobacco
or to use any "alternative nicotine product" (as defined in subsection 4.9.4A of this Code). (Ord. 16-
O-26, 4-5-2016)
N. Consumption Of Food/Beverages: Handle, possess or consume food or beverages inside the pool
area.
O. Post Signs: Post, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement or inscription
whatever or to cause to be erected any sign whatever on any public lands or highways or roads
adjacent to or within any City park. (Ord. 1096, 7-2-1974)
P. Alcohol: Consume or possess any alcoholic beverage at any time. (Ord. 2072, 11-3-1987, eff. 1-1-
1988)
Q. Davis Road Park: It shall be unlawful to permit any animal to be within the confines of Davis Road
Park. (Ord. 06-O-81, 11-7-2006, eff. 1-1-2007)
R. Illegal Drug Or Substance: To possess or use any illegal drug or substance as defined by this Code
or the Illinois Criminal Code.
S. Drone Use: To use or fly a drone without first obtaining City staff approval from the City Manager's
Office. (Ord. 16-O-26, 4-5-2016)
T. Posted Notice: Where posted notice has been given that such activity is not permitted, no person
shall walk, stand, sit (including upon a chair of any sort) or lie upon the grass or surface in or on
any park, playground, public facility or public grounds. Notwithstanding the notice requirements of
this subsection T, no posted notice of prohibition shall be required for areas that are by their nature
not designed for walking, standing, sitting or lying by the public such as flower, garden or other
planted beds, restored natural or grassy areas, wetlands and similar grounds. In addition, the City
Manager or designee may order a prohibition on access to any part of any park, playground, public
facility or public grounds, without posted notice, when they conclude that the public health, safety
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 406/525
and welfare require such prohibition (such as, for example, for landscaping, cleaning or repairs)
provided however that this prohibition shall first be communicated verbally to any affected person
and that such person shall be provided a reasonable opportunity to remove themselves from that
area. (Ord. 17-O-90, 10-17-2017)
U. Park In The Square: Additional prohibitions applying to the Park in the Square are codified in
section 6.2B.2 of this chapter. (Ord. 16-O-26, 4-5-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-90, 10-17-2017)
6.2.7: PENALTIES:
A. Any person who violates or neglects to comply with any provision of this chapter, as well as any
provisions of articles A, B and C of this chapter, shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) in addition to any additional penalties
prescribed in articles A, B, and C of this chapter. (Ord. 17-O-73, 9-5-2017)
B. In addition to the monetary penalty, any person who violates the provisions identified in subsection
C of this section shall be prohibited from access to or use of any park, playground, public facility or
public grounds in the City of Woodstock for:
1. Two (2) weeks for the first conviction.
2. One month for the second conviction.
3. Six (6) months for the third conviction.
C. Violations subject to subsection B of this section access and use prohibitions:
1. Subsection 6.2.5C of this chapter (time limitations for occupancy or use of public facilities or
public grounds).
2. Subsection 6.2.6P of this chapter (consumption and possession of alcohol in any park,
playground, public facility or public grounds).
3. Subsection 6.2.6R of this chapter (consumption and possession of illegal drugs or other illegal
substances in any park, playground, public facility or public grounds).
4. Subsection 6.2.6T of this chapter (walking, standing, sitting or lying in or on any prohibited part
of any park, playground, public facility or public grounds).
5. Subsection 6.2B.2D of this chapter (smoking and tobacco use in the Park in the Square).
D. Notice of said prohibition shall be provided to the violator by personal service. (Ord. 17-O-90, 10-
17-2017)
ARTICLE A. CITY BANDSTAND
6.2A.1: MANAGEMENT:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 407/525
The general management and direction of the community bandstand located in the Woodstock Park in
the Square and its use shall be vested in the City Manager. (Ord. 1045, 10-23-1973; amd. 1986 Code)
6.2A.2: RESERVED USE RESTRICTIONS:
A. The reserved use of the bandstand shall be restricted to the City and organizations recognized by
general ordinance or resolution of the City Council.
B. The bandstand may be used by other "recognized organizations". "Recognized organizations" as
mentioned herein, shall include the following:
1. Fraternal Organizations: Moose, Elks, Knights of Columbus, Lions, Rotary, Kiwanis, Odd
Fellows, etc.
2. Religious: All organizations, clubs, groups, study groups and the like organized and/or
sponsored by an existing parish or religious congregation in the City.
3. Business Organizations: Chamber of Commerce, Business and Professional Women's Club,
etc.
4. Educational Organizations: Any club or group of students organized and existing pursuant to the
rules and regulations of an established school district.
5. Veterans' Organizations: Veterans' organizations.
6. Charitable Organizations: Charitable organizations.
7. Others: Others as deemed appropriate by the director of the opera house or the City Manager.
(Ord. 1045, 10-23-1973; amd. 1986 Code)
6.2A.3: APPLICATION FOR USE:
A. Requests for use may be directed to the office of the director of the opera house. If deemed
necessary, a written application and assurances may be required. Requests for use of the
bandstand shall be made not less than seven (7) days prior to the date of the proposed use.
Although not automatic, permission to use the bandstand shall not be withheld unreasonably.
B. In the event there is a question as to the propriety of the use or the propriety of the person, group or
organization as to its eligibility for use, the applicant shall be so advised and the request for use
shall then be placed upon the next available agenda of the City Council for action.
C. The City Manager shall, upon submitting a written request for the use of the bandstand to the City
Council, circulate copies of the request to each member of the City Council with their regular
agenda lists together with any additional remarks regarding the reasons that the application is on
the Council's agenda, the basis of the Manager's questions, and general recommendations as to
the disposition of the request. Copies of the Manager's remarks shall be distributed to the applicant
as well.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 408/525
D. Upon the submission to the City Council by the City Manager of a question regarding the request
for use of the bandstand, the Council shall either approve or reject the application upon the face of
the application and the Manager's remarks. The City Council may, upon motion of any Council
member, suspend its rules and the operation of these rules and permit debate on the issue of the
request or barring the applicant. The submission of the request to the City Council shall not
automatically entitle any person to debate the question before the Council. (Ord. 1045, 10-23-
1973; amd. 1986 Code)
6.2A.4: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT, INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
No solely private group, club, corporation or organization shall be automatically permitted the use of
the bandstand upon the submission of an application. A private person or corporation may, upon
making a proper request and upon submitting in addition thereto a request to be declared a
recognized organization for the date or dates requested, be given permission to use the bandstand.
Any private group, corporation or organization shall submit a certificate of public liability insurance with
limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per person and three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) per occurrence for bodily injury and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property
damage inuring to the benefit of the City and with the City an additional insured thereunder. A
certificate of insurance for the date or dates upon which the private organization wishes to use the
bandstand shall accompany the application. (Ord. 1045, 10-23-1973; amd. 1986 Code)
6.2A.5: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
All permits hereafter issued shall be subject to such reasonable regulations regarding the emission of
noise from the bandstand as may be imposed from time to time by the City Manager or designee. The
determination of the City Manager or designee as to the reasonableness of any noise shall be binding
upon the applicant for the use of the bandstand. (Ord. 1045, 10-23-1973; amd. 1986 Code)
6.2A.6: RECORD OF DATES KEPT:
The city manager or designee shall keep a record or calendar of dates for the use of the bandstand
and shall keep such dates available for public inspection. (Ord. 1045, 10-23-1973; amd. 1986 Code)
6.2A.7: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be penalized in accordance with section 6.2.7 of
this chapter. (Ord. 16-O-26, 4-5-2016)
ARTICLE B. PUBLIC SQUARE
6.2B.1: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 409/525
ADJACENT SIDEWALKS: The public sidewalks within the right-of-way of the following street
locations:
Benton Street: From Van Buren to Church
Cass Street: From Throop to Benton
Dean Street: From Van Buren to Calhoun
Jackson Street: From Benton to Jefferson
Jackson Street: From Throop to Johnson
Johnson Street: From Cass to Calhoun
Judd Street: From Jefferson to Benton
Main Street: From Church to Cass
Van Buren Street: From Johnson to Benton
PARK IN THE SQUARE: That public park located in the City of Woodstock in the square area
bounded by Cass Street, Johnson Street, Van Buren Street and Benton Street. (Ord. 1365, 4-20-1977;
amd. Ord. 08-O-53, 9-16-2008)
6.2B.2: ADDITIONAL PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES:
In addition to the prohibited activities contained in section 6.2.6 of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for
any person to engage in any of the following activities in the Park in the Square:
A. Playing ball, riding skateboards, riding bicycles, serving or gliding frisbees or other similar sailing or
gliding devices.
B. For any group of persons to congregate in the Park in the Square in such a manner that free
access along paved walkways in the park or adjacent sidewalks is restricted, prohibited or blocked.
C. To ride any bicycle, skateboard or other devices on any paved walkways in the Park in the Square
or adjacent sidewalk to the Park in the Square.
D. To smoke, burn or use any cigarette, cigar, or other form of or device containing tobacco or to use
any "alternative nicotine product" (as defined in subsection 4.9.4A of this Code). (Ord. 16-O-26, 4-
5-2016)
6.2B.3: PENALTIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 410/525
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be penalized in accordance with section 6.2.7 of
this chapter. (Ord. 16-O-26, 4-5-2016; amd. Ord. 16-O-60, 10-4-2016)
ARTICLE C. TRAIN DEPOT
6.2C.1: TRAIN DEPOT DEFINED:
The Train Depot refers to the building located on or about 90 Church Street, in the City, which is
owned by the Union Pacific Railroad and is leased to the City. The City, with the permission of the
Union Pacific Railroad may sublet all or part of the Train Depot to private third parties. (Ord. 17-O-73,
9-5-2017)
6.2C.2: USE OF THE TRAIN DEPOT:
A. At any time that the Train Depot is not fully or partially subject to a lease with a third party, then the
un-sublet part of the Train Depot building shall be open only to those members of the public who
are using it for a reasonable period before departing on and after arriving from any commuter
trains or from any public buses that make stops at the Train Depot. The hours of operation shall be
established by the City Manager.
B. At any time that any part of the Train Depot has been sublet by the City to a third party, in addition
to the provisions of section 6.2C.3 of this article and subject to the terms of such sublet, the third
party shall have control of the use of that part of the Train Depot, of its hours of operation, of
whether or not to restrict access to all or part of the property to its customers and of any additional
rules of conduct for individuals within the sublet part of the Train Depot. (Ord. 17-O-73, 9-5-2017)
6.2C.3: PROHIBITED ACTS:
At all times, whether the Train Depot has been sublet or not, it shall be unlawful for any person using
the Train Depot to either perform or permit to be performed any of the following acts:
A. Vandalism: Willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, or displace or remove any part of
the Train Depot building or parts of the building, equipment, furniture, signage, decorative items or
any personal property within the Train Depot all of which may be, but are not limited to tables,
benches, railings, entranceways, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances
thereof, restrooms, signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or permanent, equipment,
facilities or other property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal.
B. Dumping Refuse Or Trash: Bring in or dump, deposit or leave any empty bottles, broken glass,
ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, refuse or other trash unless directly
associated with the operations of the Train Depot. Any permitted refuse shall be placed in proper
receptacles where these are provided. Where receptacles are not so provided, all such refuse or
trash shall be carried away from the Train Depot by the person responsible for its presence and
properly disposed of elsewhere.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 411/525
C. Endangerment: Endanger the safety of any person by any conduct or engage in any disorderly
conduct.
D. Assault, Battery Or Fighting: Commit any assault, battery or engage in any fighting.
E. Interference: Prevent or interfere with any person using the Train Depot for the purposes authorized
in section 6.2C.2 of this article.
F. Dangerous Animals: Bring any animal into the Train Depot except authorized therapy animals.
G. Peddling: To vend, sell, peddle or offer for sale any commodity or article within the Train Depot,
unless specifically authorized to do so by the City Council.
H. Smoking: To smoke, burn or use any cigarette, cigar, or other form of or device containing tobacco
or to use any "alternative nicotine product" (as defined in subsection 4.9.4A of this Code).
I. Post Signs: Post, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement or inscription
whatever or to cause to be erected any sign whatever (unless authorized by the subtenant in
possession of the Train Depot or at the request to the City by the Union Pacific, METRA, PACE or
other transportation authorities for transportation-related communications).
J. Alcohol: Consume or possess any alcoholic beverage at any time.
K. Illegal Drug Or Substance: To possess or use any illegal drug or substance as defined by this Code
or the Illinois Criminal Code.
L. Sanitary Violations: To urinate or defecate in any portion of the building not specifically intended for
such use. (Ord. 17-O-73, 9-5-2017)
6.2C.4: PENALTIES:
A. Any person who violates or neglects to comply with any provision of this article, shall be punished
by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
B. In addition to the monetary penalty, any person who violates the provisions of:
1. Subsection 6.2C.3H of this article related to smoking and tobacco use in the Train Depot;
2. Subsection 6.2C.3J of this article related to consumption and possession of alcohol in the Train
Depot;
3. Subsection 6.2C.3K of this article related to consumption and possession of illegal drugs or
other illegal substances in the Train Depot;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 412/525
4. Subsection 6.2C.3L of this article related to sanitary violations involving urination or defecation;
shall be prohibited from access to the Train Depot for:
1. Two (2) weeks for the first conviction;
2. One month for the second conviction; and
3. Six (6) months for the third conviction.
Notice of said prohibition shall be provided to the violator by personal service. (Ord. 17-O-73, 9-5-
2017)
Chapter 3
PREVAILING WAGE RATES
6.3.1: WAGE RATES ON PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS:
To the extent and as required by "an act regulating wages of laborers, mechanics and other workers
employed in any public works by the state, county, city or any public body or any political subdivision
or by anyone under contract for public works", approved June 26, 1941, as amended1, the general
prevailing rate of wages in this locality for laborers, mechanics, and other workers engaged in the
construction of public works coming under the jurisdiction of the city is hereby ascertained to be the
same as the prevailing rate of wages for construction work in the McHenry County area as determined
by the department of labor of the state of Illinois as of June of the current year a copy of that
determination being on file in the office of the city clerk and incorporated herein by reference. As
required by said act, any and all revisions of the prevailing rate of wages by the department of labor of
the state of Illinois shall supersede the department's June determination and apply to any and all
public works construction undertaken by the city. The definition of any terms appearing in this chapter
which are also used in aforesaid act shall be the same as in said act.
Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply said general prevailing rate of wages as herein
ascertained to any work or employment except public works construction of the city to the extent
required by the aforesaid act.
The city clerk shall publicly post or keep available for inspection by any interested party in the main
office of the city this determination or any revisions of such prevailing rate of wage. A copy of this
determination or of the current revised determination of prevailing rate of wages then in effect shall be
attached to all contract specifications.
The city clerk shall mail a copy of this determination to any employer, and to any association of
employers and to any person or association of employees who have filed their names and addresses,
requesting copies of any determination stating the particular rates and the particular class of workers
whose wages will be affected by such rates.
The city clerk shall promptly file a certified copy of this section with both the secretary of state index
division and the department of labor of the state of Illinois. (Ord. 2296, 6-4-1991)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 413/525
Footnote 1: 820 ILCS 130/1 et seq.
Chapter 4
MUNICIPAL WATER AND SEWER
ARTICLE A. WATER SERVICE
6.4A.1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this article shall be
as follows:
PERSON: Any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation, or group.
PREMISES: Any building, structure, part of a building, or parcel of land.
SHALL, MAY: "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive.
SHUTOFF BOX OR SERVICE BOX: A valve located on the water service line which can be used to
shut off the flow of potable water between the main and the premises being served.
WATER MAIN: A pipe owned by and maintained by the city of Woodstock for the purposes of
distributing potable water to serve, or is accessible to, more than one property, dwelling, or premises
and is exterior to buildings.
WATER MASTER PLAN: The most recent publication of the city of Woodstock's water master plan,
providing an assessment and summary of the city's water systems and including recommendations for
the construction of future improvements.
WATER SERVICE LINE, SERVICE PIPE: That line connected to the water main, including the fittings
at the point of the connection, which delivers potable water to the user's facilities, property, or
premises. (Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4A.2: PLUMBING REQUIREMENTS:
No water shall be turned on for service for premises where the plumbing does not comply with the city
regulations. (Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4A.3: WATER MAINS:
A. Water mains shall be constructed of ductile iron of a minimum internal diameter of six inches (6"),
or the minimum size designated with the water master plan if greater than six inches (6").
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 414/525
B. Water mains installed in the city shall comply with the requirements of the subdivision and platting
ordinance of the city and shall include all performance and maintenance warranties.
C. The extension or installation of any water main in the city shall be preceded by the submission of
plans prepared and sealed by a professional engineer. Said plans shall be approved by the city
prior to the extension or installation of any water main.
D. All water main extensions shall be installed across the entire width of the lot or lots to be served
and shall include connection to the closest existing water main to complete a loop, when directed
by the city engineer.
E. The cost of plans, specifications, engineering services and construction of water mains specified in
this section shall be borne by the property owners or other person causing the installation to be
made. (Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4A.4: CONNECTIONS WITH WATER MAINS:
A. Requirements: No connection with a water main shall be made until the requirements set forth
herein have been met:
1. Application is made by the owner of the real estate involved, or his duly authorized agent, for a
permit, such application to be made with the city engineer, and such permit is issued by the city
engineer.
2. No less than twenty four (24) hours (excluding weekends and holidays) prior to the connection,
notice, either in writing or verbal, is given of such connection to the city engineer.
3. The connection is made under the supervision, at the site thereof, of the director of public works,
or his duly authorized agent, and the connection is covered only after such connection has been
inspected by the director of public works or his duly authorized agent.
4. Payment, or evidence of payment, is made of any liens, encumbrances or special assessments
impressed or levied against the real estate involved for the cost of water mains serving the
property which are recorded in the office of the city clerk and McHenry County recorder of
deeds.
B. Fees: No connection with a water main shall be made until the fees set forth in article D of this
chapter have been paid. (Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4A.5: INSTALLATION OF SERVICE PIPES:
A. Service pipes from the water main to the premises to be served shall be installed by and at the cost
of the property owner involved or the applicant for the service. Such installation shall be under the
supervision of the director of public works. After installation of the service pipe, the responsibility of
maintaining the service pipe to the water main shall be the responsibility of the property owner.
(Ord. 06-0-22, 3-21-2006, eff. 5-1-2006)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 415/525
B. No service pipe shall be installed unless it conforms to specifications drawn up by the city engineer,
a copy of which specifications shall be kept on file by the City Engineer and shall be open to
inspection by any person interested.
C. Each property served by the Municipal water supply must have a separate water service. Such
service shall be located on property owned by the water customer, or within a recorded easement.
D. All excavations for water service pipes shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so
as to protect the public from hazards. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property
disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the Director of
Public Works, at the expense of the owner. (Ord. 99-O-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4A.6: REPAIRS TO PIPES:
Repairs of damages, including, but not limited to, leaks, to service pipes from the water main to the
premises and plumbing systems, shall be made as follows: (Ord. 99-O-57, 10-19-1999)
A. Owner Responsible For Cost: Repairs to service pipes, from the water main to the premises
served, and plumbing systems of buildings shall be made by and at the expense of the property
owner of the premises served. (Ord. 06-O-22, 3-21-2006, eff. 5-1-2006)
B. Repairs: (Rep. by Ord. 18-O-52, 10-2-2018)
C. Emergency: In case of emergency whereby a service pipe is damaged, the City may immediately
go on the premises, without notice to the owner or user thereof, and repair such pipe. An
emergency exists when there is an immediate threat of substantial property damage, or an
immediate threat to the public health, safety and welfare. The decision as to the existence of an
emergency shall be made by the Director of Public Works or the City Manager, who shall certify in
writing thereto, such certification to be filed in the records of the Director of Public Works. The cost
of such repair shall be repaid to the City by the owner or user, or both, of the premises served.
Collection of such cost shall be made and enforced in the manner described in article D of this
chapter. (Ord. 99-O-57, 10-19-1999)
D. Service Pipe Repairs: Whenever suspected or actual damage, including, but not limited to, leaks, to
a service pipe exists, and such damage is not certified to constitute an emergency, the City shall
notify the owner to have the damage repaired at the owner's expense. Such repairs must be
completed by the owner within five (5) business days of the date of the notice. In the event that
repairs are not completed within five (5) business days of the date of notice, the City may either
turn off water to the property involved until repairs are made or perform such repairs and charge all
costs and expenses related thereto to the property owner. In the event water is turned off to the
property involved, the building shall be red tagged as "unfit for human occupancy" and the property
owner shall be responsible for the City's cost of termination and a fifty dollar ($50.00)
reinstatement fee when the water is turned on. (Ord. 06-O-22, 3-21-2006, eff. 5-1-2006)
6.4A.7: SHUTOFF BOXES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 416/525
A. Shutoff boxes or service boxes shall be placed on every service pipe, and shall be located between
the curb line and the front sidewalk line where this is practicable. Shutoff boxes or service boxes
may not be located within sidewalks, driveways or other paved areas within the right-of-way. Such
boxes shall be so located that they are easily accessible and shall be protected from frost. All
shutoff boxes shall be in good working order. (Ord. 99-O-57, 10-19-1999; amd. Ord. 18-O-52, 10-
2-2018)
B. Water service pipes connected to multi-tenant buildings must include a shutoff box on the primary
service pipe and must include an additional shutoff box for the service to each tenant space. All
shutoff boxes for multi-tenant buildings must be accessible by the City, from the exterior of the
building. (Ord. 99-O-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4A.8: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
A. Resale Of Water: No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient to any premises other than
that for which application has been made and the meter installed, except in the case of an
emergency.
B. Tampering: No person, not authorized by the City Council, shall tamper with, alter or injure any part
of the City waterworks or supply system, or with any meter. (Ord. 99-O-57, 10-19-1999)
C. Service Pipe: Unless authorized by the City, no person shall be permitted to turn water on or off at
the service pipe. (Ord. 06-O-22, 3-21-2006, eff. 5-1-2006)
6.4A.9: LIABILITY OF CITY:
The City shall not be liable for any damage caused by a leak or break in any service pipe, or for
damage caused by the repair or installation of such pipes when such work is not done by the City, nor
shall the City be liable for any damage caused by a failure to repair any leak or break in any service
pipe. (Ord. 99-O-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4A.10: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any portion of this article, once a restriction/prohibition has
been put into place, shall be fined in accordance with section 1.4.1 of this Code for each offense plus
the City's cost of prosecution including, but not limited to, its attorney fees. Each day that a violation
continues or persists shall be deemed a separate offense. At the discretion of the City Manager or
his/her designee, the City may initiate adjudication procedures in accordance with title 1, chapter 7,
article L of this Code to settle contested matter(s), to achieve compliance with this article, assess
penalties and fines, and collect outstanding obligations. In addition, the City reserves the right to
discontinue water service to any premises until the violation is corrected. (Ord. 10-O-21, 4-20-2010)
ARTICLE B. SEWER SERVICE
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 417/525
6.4B.1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this article shall be
as follows:
BOD (Denoting BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty
degrees centigrade (20°C), expressed in milligrams per liter.
BUILDING DRAIN: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the
discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to
the building sewer, beginning five feet (5') (1.5 m) outside the inner face of the building wall.
BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of
disposal.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: The liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade or business
as distinct from sanitary sewage.
INSPECTOR: The building inspector of the city of Woodstock.
NATURAL OUTLET: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or
ground water.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group.
pH: The logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution.
PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of
food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow
conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2") (1.27
cm) in any dimension.
PUBLIC SEWER: A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is
controlled by public authority.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface and ground waters
are not intentionally admitted.
SANITARY SEWER MASTER PLAN: The most recent publication of the city of Woodstock's sanitary
sewer master plan, providing an assessment and summary of the city's sanitary sewer collection,
conveyance, and treatment systems and including recommendations for the construction of future
improvements.
SEWAGE: A combination of the water carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions,
and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface and storm waters as may be
present.
SEWAGE TREATMENT PLANT: Any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage.
SEWAGE WORKS: All facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 418/525
SEWER: A pipe or conduit for carrying sewage.
SHALL, MAY: "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive.
SLUG: Any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which, in concentration of any given
constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes
more than five (5) times the average twenty four (24) hour concentration of flows during normal
operation.
STORM DRAIN OR STORM SEWER: A sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage,
but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water.
SUPERINTENDENT: The superintendent of sewage treatment of the city of Woodstock, or his
authorized deputy, agent or representative.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water,
sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering.
WATERCOURSE: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently.
(Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4B.2: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary
manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city,
any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste.
B. It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet or storm drain within the city, or in any area
under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable
treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article.
C. Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy vault, septic
tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
D. The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment,
recreation, or other purposes, situated within the City and abutting on any street, alley or right of
way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the
City, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such
facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this Article,
within ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so; provided, that said public sewer is
within one hundred fifty feet (150') of the property line. (Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4B.3: PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL:
Where a public sanitary sewer is not within one hundred fifty feet (150') of the property, the building
sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system that has been accepted by the
McHenry County Health Department. Location and discharge of the private sewage disposal system
shall also be subject to City approval. At such time as a public sewer is within one hundred fifty feet
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 419/525
(150') of the property, the private sewage disposal system shall be abandoned pursuant to McHenry
County Health Department regulations and the building sewer shall be connected to the public
sanitary sewer pursuant to this Article. (Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4B.4: BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS:
A. No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with, or opening into; use; alter; or
disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the
Director of Public Works.
B. There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits: 1) for residential and commercial service,
and 2) for service to establishments producing industrial wastes. In either case, the owner or his
agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the City.
The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information
considered pertinent in the judgment of the Director of Public Works. A permit and inspection fee of
ten dollars ($10.00) for a residential or commercial building sewer permit shall be paid to the City
at the time the application is filed.
C. All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be
borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the City from any loss or damage that may directly
or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer.
Repairs, maintenance, and replacement of all building sewers and building drains shall be made
by and at the expense of the owner of the premises served.
D. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except that where
one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can
be connected to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building
sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as
one building sewer.
E. Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on
examination and test by the owner and approval by the Director of Public Works, to meet all
requirements of this Article.
F. The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be
used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform
to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes1 or other applicable rules and regulations
of the City. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the material and
procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials,
Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications for
Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois shall apply.
G. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer,
sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by a means which is approved in
accordance with this Article, and discharged to the building sewer.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 420/525
H. No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains,
or other sources of surface runoff or ground water to building sewer or building drain which in turn
is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
I. The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the
building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the City, or the
procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials,
Water Pollution Control Federal Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications for Water
and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois. All such connections shall be made gastight and
watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the
Director of Public Works before installation.
J. The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the Director of Public Works not less than
twenty four (24) hours (excluding weekends and holidays) of when the building sewer is ready for
inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the
supervision of the Director of Public Works or his representative, and the connection shall not be
covered until approved by the City.
K. All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and
lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public
property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the
Director of Public Works, at the expense of the owner. (Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4B.5: SANITARY SEWER EXTENSIONS:
A. Sanitary sewer mains shall be constructed in accordance with standard practices approved by the
City Engineer and in accordance with requirements of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency
as from time to time amended. Sanitary sewer mains shall be constructed with minimum size
designated with the Sanitary Sewer Master Plan, where appropriate.
B. Sanitary sewer mains installed in the City shall comply with the requirements of the Subdivision and
Platting Ordinance of the City.
C. The extension or installation of any sanitary sewer main in the City shall be preceded by the
submission of plans, prepared and sealed by a professional engineer. Said plans shall be
approved by the City prior to the extension or construction of any sanitary sewer main.
D. All sanitary sewer mains shall be installed across the entire width or length of the lot, parcel or tract
of land to be served. The City Council may, upon the recommendation of the City Engineer, in
accordance with standard engineering practices, excuse the obligation to extend a sanitary sewer
main across the entire length or width of a lot under the following circumstances:
1. When the carrying capacity of a sanitary sewer main has been reached and further extensions
thereof are not feasible.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 421/525
2. When there is no further extension of any given main and it is reasonably foreseeable to serve
any adjacent, contiguous or adjoining property, then the obligation of extending a sanitary sewer
main across the entire length or width of a lot, parcel or tract of land may be temporarily excused
until an extension of any such main is needed to serve adjacent, contiguous or adjoining real
estate. The owner of any lot, parcel or tract of land shall, when applying for any such temporary
excuse from the obligations of this Section, execute a covenant running with the land obligating
their heirs, administrators, successors or assigns of the owner at the time of the application to
extend any such main when extension is needed to serve adjacent, contiguous or adjoining
properties, or to pay the cost therefor, and to give to the City such temporary and permanent
easements as may in the future be needed to lay, trench, dig or extend any such sewer pipe.
(Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4B.6: USE OF THE PUBLIC SEWERS:
A. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm water, surface water, ground water,
roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process
waters to any sanitary sewer.
B. Storm water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are
specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the City Engineer.
Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the City
Engineer, to a storm sewer or natural outlet.
C. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or
wastes to any public sewer:
1. Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas.
2. Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity,
either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment
process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any
hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant.
3. Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than five and five-tenths (5.5), or having any other
corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel
of the sewage works.
4. Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the
flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but
not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, wax, tar,
plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and
paper dishes, cups, milk containers, either whole or ground by garbage grinders.
D. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances,
materials, waters or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the Director of Public Works that
such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment; have an
adverse effect on the receiving stream; or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property or
constitute a nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the Director of
Public Works will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation
to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 422/525
treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and maximum limits
established by regulatory agencies. The substances prohibited are:
1. Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit
(150°F) (65°C).
2. Any water or wastes containing toxic or poisonous materials; or oils, whether emulsified or not,
in excess of one hundred milligrams per liter (100 mg/l) or containing substances which may
solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty two degrees Fahrenheit (32°F) and
one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) (0° and 65°C).
3. Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any
garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/4) horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or
greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the Director of Public Works.
4. Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating
solutions whether neutralized or not.
5. Any waters or wastes containing objectionable or toxic substances, or wastes exerting an
excessive chlorine requirement to such degree that such material received in the composite
sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the Director of Public
Works in compliance with applicable State and Federal regulations; and which exceed the
following concentration:
Zinc 0.5 ppm
Chromium 1.5 ppm
Cadmium 0.5 ppm
Lead 0.1 ppm
Nickel 2.0 ppm
Phenols 1.0 ppm
Copper 3.0 ppm
BOD 340 ppm
Suspended solids 400 ppm
6. Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor-producing substances, in such
concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the Director of Public Works as
necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the State,
Federal or other public agencies or jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters.
7. Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such high-life or concentration as may exceed limits
established by the Director of Public Works in compliance with applicable State or Federal
regulations.
8. Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of nine and five-tenths (9.5).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 423/525
9. Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 milligrams per liter as Hg at any time
except as permitted by the Director of Public Works in compliance with State and Federal
regulations.
10. Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 milligrams per liter at any time except as permitted by the
Director of Public Works in compliance with applicable State and Federal regulations.
11. Materials which exert or cause:
a. Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, fuller's earth,
lime slurries and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium
chloride and sodium sulfate).
b. Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning
solutions).
c. Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting "slugs" as defined herein.
12. Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by
the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree
that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having
jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters.
E. If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers,
which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in subsection D of
this Section, and/or which are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in chapter 1,
EPA Rules and Regulations, subchapter D, Water Programs, part 128 - Pretreatment Standards,
Federal Register Volume 38, No. 215, Thursday, November 8, 1973, and any amendments thereto,
and which in the judgment of the Director of Public Works may have a deleterious effect upon the
sewage works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to
life or constitute a public nuisance, the Director of Public Works may:
1. Reject the wastes.
2. Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers.
3. Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge.
4. Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by
existing taxes or sewer charges under the provisions of subsection J of this Section.
If the Director of Public Works permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the
design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval
of the Director of Public Works, and subject to all the requirements of all applicable codes,
ordinances and laws.
F. Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the Director of Public
Works, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive
amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except that such
interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall
be of a type and capacity approved by the Director of Public Works, and shall be located as to be
readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 424/525
G. Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided, they shall be maintained
continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense.
H. Each new industry shall be required to install a control manhole, and when required by the Director
of Public Works, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes
shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other
appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observations, sampling, and measurement of
wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be
constructed in accordance with plans approved by the Director of Public Works. The manhole shall
be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and
accessible at all times.
I. All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference
is made in this Article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard
Methods For The Examination Of Water And Wastewater", published by the American Public
Health Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable
samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required,
the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public
sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by
customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to
determine the existence of hazards of life, limb, and property. (The particular analyses involved will
determine whether a 24 hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a
grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids
analyses are obtained from 24 hour composites of all outfalls whereas pHs are determined from
periodic grab samples.)
J. No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or
arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual
strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor, in
accordance with article D of this chapter, by the industrial concern. (Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4B.7: DISCHARGES INTO STORM DRAINS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to connect or cause to be connected, any drain carrying, or to carry,
any toilet, sink, basement, septic tank, cesspool, industrial waste, or any fixture or device discharging
polluting substances, to any storm drain in the city. (Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999; amd. Ord. 09-0-24, 4-
21-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
6.4B.8: PROTECTION FROM DAMAGE:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, or tamper
with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Any person
violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct. (Ord.
99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4B.9: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 425/525
A. The director of public works and other duly authorized employees of the city and/or USEPA and
IEPA, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the
purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the
provisions of this article. The director of public works or his representatives shall have no authority
to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper, or
other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to
the sewers or waterway or facilities for waste treatment.
B. While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsection A of this
section, the director of public works or duly authorized employees of the city and/or USEPA and
IEPA shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company and the
company shall be held harmless for injury and death to the city and/or USEPA and IEPA
employees and the city and/or USEPA and IEPA shall indemnify the company against loss or
damage to its property by city and/or USEPA and IEPA employees and against liability claims and
demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of
the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the
company to maintain safety conditions as required in subsection 6.4B.6H of this article.
C. The director of public works and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper
credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city
holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation,
measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within
said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement, shall be done in full
accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property
involved. (Ord. 99-0-57, 10-19-1999)
6.4B.10: PENALTIES:
A. Any person found to be violating any provision of this article, except section 6.4B.8 of this article,
shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and demanding
immediate correction thereof.
B. Any person, firm or corporation violating any portion of this article, once a restriction/prohibition has
been put into place, shall be fined in accordance with section 1.4.1 of this code for each offense
plus the city's cost of prosecution including, but not limited to, its attorney fees. Each day that a
violation continues or persists shall be deemed a separate offense. At the discretion of the city
manager or his/her designee, the city may initiate adjudication procedures in accordance with title
1, chapter 7, article L of this code to settle contested matter(s), to achieve compliance with this
article, assess penalties and fines, and collect outstanding obligations. In addition, the city
reserves the right to discontinue water service to any premises until the violation is corrected. (Ord.
10-0-21, 4-20-2010)
Footnote 1: See Title 7, Chapters 1 and 3, respectively, of this Code.
ARTICLE C. METERS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 426/525
6.4C.1: METERS REQUIRED:
All premises using water from the City water supply shall be equipped with an adequate water meter.
Water service may be supplied at a flat rate of charge until such meter is installed. Every single-family
and duplex dwelling hereafter connected to the water system shall be equipped with a device so as to
permit the direct reading of the meter outside the house. Such devices shall be installed under the
supervision of the Director of Public Works. (Ord. 777, 4-23-1968; amd. 1986 Code)
6.4C.2: INSTALLATION OF METERS, FEES:
All water meters shall be installed by the Department of Public Works. In addition to any and all other
charges for water service, tapping fees, service connection fees, and all other charges, there is hereby
imposed a fee to provide and install a water meter upon a premises that is connected to the City water
supply system. The fee shall be the cost to the City of the meter and installation of the meter plus a
fifty dollar ($50.00) administrative fee. (Ord. 18-O-52, 10-2-2018)
6.4C.3: LOCATION OF METERS:
A. Approval Of Location: Water meters may be located inside or outside of buildings in position
approved by the Director of Public Works, with easy access for reading, inspecting, repairing or
removing. Any meter placed inside a building shall be set as near as practicable to the wall where
the service pipe enters the building and shall be kept above the basement or cellar floor. The meter
shall not be set in toilet or storage rooms nor in positions where it may become inaccessible.
Meters shall be protected against hot water, freezing or other injuries. (1963 Code, §40.20)
B. Setting Of Meters:
1. Water meters must be set level and made firm by resting on proper supports. Square faced
unions must be used in connecting the meter so that it can be readily removed by the
Department of Public Works in case of necessity for testing or otherwise. Provision shall be
made for easily restoring the water supply in the event the meter must be removed. A stop of
waste shall be placed on both the inlet and outlet end of the meter.
2. Before a water meter is set the pipes shall be thoroughly flushed. Red or white lead shall not be
used in making the couplings. Care shall be exercised to prevent filings, bits of waste, lead or
other foreign substances from remaining in the meter, fittings or pipe.
3. In case two (2) or more meters are placed upon the service connection, they shall be so placed
that not one of them shall measure water that has passed through another meter. (1963 Code,
§40.21)
6.4C.4: READING METERS:
The Director of Finance shall read or cause to be read every water meter used in the City at such
times as are necessary for billing. (1963 Code, §40.23)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 427/525
6.4C.5: OPERATION OF METERS, TESTS:
A. Meter Wear: The consumer shall not be responsible for failure on the part of the meter due to wear,
or injury by freezing, hot water or other accident. (Ord. 18-O-52, 10-2-2018)
B. Testing Meters: All meters in service shall be sealed and shall be tested for accuracy by the
Director of Public Works at such times as he may direct. The test so made shall be at the expense
of the City. The City will test the accuracy of any water meter on request of the consumer, who
shall pay the actual cost of such test in case the meter shall be found inaccurate or registering
slow. In the event the meter shall be found registering fast, the City will bear expense of the test.
Water meters testing not more than two percent (2%) slow shall be considered accurate. (1963
Code, §40.16)
C. Wasted Water: All water passing through a meter will be charged for, whether used or wasted, and
no deductions will be made for water wasted through defective pipes, fixtures or otherwise, unless
otherwise approved by the Finance Director. (Ord. 18-O-52, 10-2-2018)
D. Estimates Of Water Consumption: If any water meter ceases to register, stops or is otherwise out of
repair and fails to correctly indicate the water consumed, the Director of Public Works shall
estimate from the most reliable data available, the quantity of water passing through the meter
during such failure and the bill so estimated shall be paid by the consumer. (1963 Code, §40.18)
6.4C.6: REPAIR OF METERS:
A. No water meter shall be repaired, changed, altered, disconnected or in any manner disturbed
except by the Department of Public Works. In case of freezing, leak or other dangerous
emergencies, qualified plumbers may, without first obtaining a permit, remove the damaged meter
from the line, but in no case from the premises. Notice of such removal shall be filed with the
Director of Public Works by the plumber within forty eight (48) hours after such removal.
B. Consumers shall promptly notify the Director of Public Works when a water meter is frozen, and
shall not attempt to thaw such meter. Consumers shall also give notice of injury or accident to
water meters or their supply. (1963 Code, §40.19)
6.4C.7: TAMPERING WITH METERS:
No person other than a duly authorized officer or employee of the Department of Public Works shall
set, repair or interfere with any water supply or meter; and if it shall be found that the water supply or
water meter is being tampered with by any unauthorized person, the owner or occupant of the
premises at which such meter is located shall be held responsible, and the water supply to such
premises may be cut off. If the water supply is cut off for such cause, it shall not again be turned on
until the owner or occupant of the premises shall have paid to the City the cost and expense of cutting
off and turning on such water supply. The charges to the owner or occupant will be based on each
individual incurrence that requires a City employee to cut off the water supply. In addition, one
hundred dollars ($100.00) will be charged as liquidated damages for each incurrence of such
unauthorized tampering and interference. (Ord. 10-O-21, 4-20-2010)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 428/525
6.4C.8: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any portion of this article, once a restriction/prohibition has
been put into place, shall be fined in accordance with section 1.4.1 of this Code for each offense plus
the City's cost of prosecution including, but not limited to, its attorney fees. Each day that a violation
continues or persists shall be deemed a separate offense. At the discretion of the City Manager or
his/her designee, the City may initiate adjudication procedures in accordance with title 1, chapter 7,
article L of this Code to settle contested matter(s), to achieve compliance with this article, assess
penalties and fines, and collect outstanding obligations. In addition, the City reserves the right to
discontinue water service to any premises until the violation is corrected. (Ord. 10-O-21, 4-20-2010)
6.4C.9: INSPECTIONS, ACCESS TO PREMISES:
A. Public Works or its designee shall have the right of access to any premises within the City for
purposes of reasonable inspection to ascertain whether such premises are connected to the City
water system, to inspect the plumbing within the building and the number and type of water
connections, and to inspect the water meter on the premises. Any person refusing the right of the
Sewer and Water Department or its designee to access and inspect their premises shall be subject
to a penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00) each day such refusal continues to exist starting fifteen (15)
days after first notice is sent.
B. Access for inspection or reading of water meters shall be allowed at least six (6) times per year.
C. In addition to any other penalties provided herein, the City shall have the power to physically
disconnect the water service to a building. The procedure to be followed in any such disconnection
shall be as follows:
1. If access to a building cannot be obtained voluntarily, a first notice shall be served personally or
sent by certified or registered mail to the owner or the occupant of the building (if his name be
known) informing them of the need for the City to gain access to the water meter.
2. If inspection cannot be reasonably made within fifteen (15) days of the first mailing or posting,
then a second termination notice shall be mailed and posted giving the owner or the occupant of
the building an additional fifteen (15) days to allow the City access to the water meter before
water service is disconnected. Notice shall give owner or the occupant the opportunity to request
a hearing.
3. If a hearing is requested, it shall be conducted by the City Manager or his designee. If said
Hearing Officer determines the water should be disconnected, then the date of such
disconnection shall be furnished to the person requesting the hearing in person, if he attends the
hearing, or by mail if he fails to attend the hearing, and the City shall disconnect the water
service on or after that date.
4. Once water service has been disconnected, the reinstatement fee specified in subsection
6.4D.9L of this chapter shall apply and be paid prior to reconnection. (Ord. 14-O-44, 7-15-2014)
ARTICLE D. RATES AND CHARGES
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
