December 5, 2006, and as amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference as part of this
code. (Ord. 09-0-24, 4-21-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
7.4.2: ADOPTION OF STORMWATER MANAGEMENT REGULATIONS:
The McHenry County stormwater management ordinance adopted by the city of Woodstock on
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 498/525
September 22, 2004, and as amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference as part of
this code. (Ord. 09-0-24, 4-21-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
Chapter 5
SWIMMING POOLS
(Rep. by Ord. 99-0-17, 3-16-1999, eff. 5-1-1999)
Chapter 6
EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL
7.6.1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings provided in this section:
EXCAVATION: Includes removal, stripping or disturbance of soil, earth, sand, rock, gravel or other
similar substance from the ground.
FILLING: Includes the placing of any soil, earth, sand, rock, gravel or other similar substance on the
ground.
GRADING: Includes any operation involving either excavation and/or filling.
GROUND: Includes, but is not limited to, land below mean high water line, natural watercourse, and
the banks and beds of any river, stream or lake. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
7.6.2: INTERPRETATION AND COMPLIANCE:
A. Compliance Required: No excavation, grading or filling shall be commenced in the city, except as
hereinafter provided, and then only in full compliance with the requirements, standards and
conditions contained herein.
B. Interpretation Of Provisions: The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed as permitting the
applicant to carry on any commercial operation or business, or use any premises or buildings or
structures thereon for any purpose not permitted by other provisions of this chapter or the zoning
ordinances. For the purpose of this subsection, an excavation shall not be considered a
commercial operation or business if the excavation is incidental to and necessary for the
establishment or operation of a use permitted in the applicable zoning district.
C. Applicability: The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all excavations, grading or filling
operations which are being worked at the time this chapter goes into effect as provided in section
7.6.3 of this chapter. No existing operation shall be extended in area or any new operation
commenced after such date without first securing a permit therefor as hereinafter provided, and
such operation shall be subject to all of the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 499/525
7.6.3: PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
A. Except as provided in subsection B of this section, a permit shall be required for every "excavation",
"grading" or "filling" as defined herein.
B. No permit shall be required for the following classes of excavation, grading or filling operations:
1. Building Permit: Under provisions of a duly issued building permit.
2. Incidental Excavations, Grading Or Filling: Excavations and removal of excavated material, and
filling, shall be permitted in any zone, provided such operation is clearly incidental to the
improvement of the property, consists of less than two hundred (200) cubic yards of material and
the area is graded and covered by revegetation or other suitable means.
3. Excavation For Streets And Drains: Necessary grading, removal or excavation of topsoil, or
other materials shall be permitted within the limits of the right of way or slope rights of any
existing street or for the purpose of constructing streets and other related improvements within
the area of new subdivisions when made in accordance with subdivision plans approved by the
planning and zoning commission, which subdivision plans shall establish the elevations and
grades of said streets and/or the location of said improvements, and for which a street
construction permit or a drain connection permit has been issued.
4. Other Construction Work: Construction work relating to drains, utilities or sanitary sewerage
systems for which a street opening and/or other necessary permit has been issued by the city
council.
5. Farming: The provisions of this section shall not be construed as prohibiting or limiting the lawful
use of land for farming, nurseries or gardening, or similar agricultural or horticultural use in any
zoning district where and as permitted by the zoning ordinances. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
7.6.4: APPLICATION PROCEDURES:
Application for such permit shall be made by the property owner or his authorized agent, and shall be
made to the director of public works as enforcement officer, on forms provided by the city. An
application form in duplicate shall be accompanied by a detailed statement of proposed work and the
purpose thereof and why the excavation, grading and/or filling is clearly incidental to the improvement
of the property. An application shall be accompanied by the following:
A. Two (2) sets of maps and plans with specifications showing proposed excavation, grading or filling.
Such plans shall be prepared by and shall bear the seal of a licensed engineer, except, when
engineering design for excavation or construction is unnecessary to assure compliance with the
standards established by this regulation, in which event, such plans may be prepared by a licensed
surveyor. All such plans shall be drawn to a scale of not less than one inch to one hundred feet (1"
= 100') and shall show the following:
1. Full name and address of the owner of the property.
2. Description of property by street address and tax assessor designation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 500/525
3. The location of the premises and its geographic relation to neighboring properties, showing all
buildings and roads within one hundred feet (100') of the boundaries of the plot on which the
excavation, grading or filling is proposed.
4. The portion of the property that is to be excavated, graded or filled with excavated material.
5. The estimated maximum quantity of material to be excavated, graded or filled, and the
estimated part thereof that will be used for grading or filling.
6. When available, the location and depth of any well situated within fifty feet (50') of the proposed
excavation and/or filling.
7. When available, the location of any sewerage disposal system or underground utility line, any
part of which is within fifty feet (50') of the proposed excavation, grading or filling area and the
location of any gas transmission pipeline operated at a maximum service pressure in excess of
two hundred (200) psig, any part of which is within one hundred feet (100') of the proposed
excavation, grading or filling area.
8. Existing topography of the premises at a contour interval of not more than two feet (2') and the
proposed final contours of existing and final elevations at intervals of not more than fifty feet
(50').
9. The location and present status of any previously permitted excavation operations on the
property.
10. The details of any drainage system proposed to be installed and maintained by the applicant,
designed to provide for proper surface drainage of the land, both during the performance of the
work applied for and after the completion thereof.
11. If the proposed excavation and/or filling is for the purpose of constructing a lake or pond, the
details of the proposed dam or other structures and the embankments intended to impound the
water, together with the details and location of proposed discharge through a valved outlet for
drainage purposes, and the proposed level of any impounded water. Any proposal involving the
construction of a dam for the impoundment of water must be approved by the state water board,
if and where necessary, and such approval shall be obtained prior to the issuance of a permit
hereunder.
12. Details of soil preparation and of revegetation or of other methods of soil erosion control.
13. Proposed truck and equipment accessways to the work site.
14. A statement from the property owner or his agent assuming full responsibility for the
performance of the operation as stated in the application. This statement shall also contain an
assurance that all city property and/or city roads will be protected adequately.
B. Upon receipt of the application and plan, the director of public works shall establish the amount of
the performance bond, if any, and if said application and plan comply with the standards contained
in this chapter, the director shall issue a permit in accordance therewith. In acting on such an
application, the director shall be guided by and shall take into consideration the public health,
safety and general welfare and particular consideration shall be given as to whether the plan will
create any of the following conditions:
1. Interfere with surface water flow and drainage.
2. Interfere with lateral supports and slopes.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 501/525
3. Cause erosion, alteration of the natural topography and grade of land, depletion of natural
deposits of topsoil and other natural materials, disturbance of the plant and wildlife, creation of
nuisances and dangerous open pits, creation of stagnant water pools.
4. Interfere with mean high water on riparian properties.
The director of public works may impose such conditions or requirements upon the issuance of a
permit as he deems necessary or proper to assure faithful compliance with this chapter.
C. A covenant in duplicate, executed by the record owner of the real estate which shall be in
substantially the following form:
Form:
Covenant
To the City of Woodstock, McHenry County, Illinois:
The undersigned has herewith applied for a permit to excavate, fill or grade the following described
premises:
(Legal Description)
In consideration of the issuance of a permit to excavate or fill the above described premises, the
undersigned hereby declares for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns that the
above described premises will constitute made lands after the completion of the filling or
excavating requested in the permit application which contain or may contain subsurface soil
conditions limiting the utility of said real estate for the construction of any improvement.
The undersigned therefore agrees for himself, his heirs, his or its administrators, or assigns, that
no owner shall be entitled to any building permit in the City of Woodstock, Illinois, for the
construction of the improvements on the above described real estate unless and until plans and
specifications have been submitted to and approved by the Director of Public Works of the City for
such improvements designed to overcome any or all of the known limitations to which the subsoil
may be subject on the above described real estate.
This covenant shall run with the land and is binding upon the owner, his heirs, executors,
administrators, assigns and successors in interest. Compliance may be enforced by injunction
obtained by the City of Woodstock or any interested person or by a suit for damages by any
interested person against any owner violating or permitting the violation of the same.
(Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
7.6.5: BOND AND FEE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Bond: For excavations, grading or filling of more than three thousand (3,000) cubic yards of
material, a performance bond in form and with surety approved by the city council in such amount
said council shall deem sufficient to ensure completion of all work following excavation, grading or
filling pursuant to the conditions of approval, provided the director of public works may accept and
hold a certified or bank officer's check payable to the city in the same amount in lieu of such bond.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 502/525
B. Fee: A fee to cover the cost of permit and inspections based on a rate of five dollars ($5.00) per
one thousand (1,000) cubic yards of material or fraction thereof to be excavated, graded or filled,
with a minimum fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) and maximum fee of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00).
C. Term Of Permit: A permit issued under this chapter shall expire one year from the date of issuance,
except that the city council may, for due cause shown, extend any permit for one year periods after
complete review of all plans and examination of work accomplished and proposed, provided
application is made at least thirty (30) days prior to the expiration date of such permit. In no case
shall a permit be extended if the provisions of this regulation have not been complied with;
provided, however, that in connection with continuing operations, the city council may waive, for
one year periods, those requirements which would make continuing operations impractical. (Ord.
04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
7.6.6: STANDARDS:
Approval of plans and specifications for excavations shall be based upon the following standards:
A. In residence districts no excavation, grading or filling shall be permitted within twenty feet (20') of
an existing or approved street property line except to conform to approximate street grade.
B. In residence districts finished slopes of an excavation shall not exceed one to one and one-half
(1:11/2) (vertical to horizontal) in undisturbed earth, one to two (1:2) in earth fill, and four to one
(4:1) in rock cut, whether or not the ground surface will be below water.
C. In business districts the same standards shall apply, except that vertical slopes shall be permitted if
adequate retaining walls and protective fences are provided when needed.
D. Truck and equipment accessways to the site of the operation shall be located so as to minimize
danger to traffic and nuisance to surrounding properties. Such access shall be kept either wet or
oiled or treated with chemical dust deterrents, or paved, to the extent necessary to prevent any
dust nuisance to surrounding properties. All such accessways shall be clearly marked with signs
and shall be posted approximately two hundred feet (200') distant from such accessways or other
traveled areas. Such signs shall read, "Caution, Trucks Entering", and be of size, type, coloring,
lettering and format used by the highway department of the city or state.
E. Excavations shall not interfere with public or private utility systems and shall not create or
aggravate any condition detrimental to the public health and safety. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
7.6.7: OPERATION RESTRICTIONS:
A. Processing of any kind on the excavation site or the erection or use of any structure thereon, such
as, but not limited to, hoppers, washers, crushers or sheds, except simple screens to remove
oversized aggregates during loading, shall be deemed a commercial use and are hereby
prohibited.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 503/525
B. Except as otherwise provided in subsection 7.6.3B of this chapter, no storage area may be created
or maintained in connection with an excavation, grading or filling operation except that, under a
duly issued permit, an owner or his contractor shall be allowed temporarily to store such material
incidental to the operation, but such storage shall not be for a longer term than the term of the
permit issued.
C. It shall be unlawful to keep or store any trucks, machinery or equipment on any property or street
after completion of the operation. All such trucks, machinery or equipment shall be removed from
such property within ten (10) days after completion of the work.
D. No operation shall be permitted on Sundays or holidays, nor before eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. or
after five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on other days.
E. Barricades and lights shall be erected where necessary to protect pedestrians and vehicles during
the period of operations. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
7.6.8: COMPLETION OF WORK:
Upon completion of the work allowed by permit, the permittee shall comply with the applicable
provisions of the following:
A. All pits, quarries, holes or other excavated areas shall be refilled with, and no new filling operation
shall be conducted with any material except clean, nonburnable fill containing no trash, refuse or
harmful matter, and such excavated areas and new filling operations shall be graded to the level of
adjoining properties, or to an elevation from which all surface and other waters collected therein
may find natural drainage therefrom. Stumps and logs may be used for fill material but only in
accordance with standards and requirements established by the city council. Excess material shall
either be removed from the premises or leveled and covered with topsoil and seeded as
hereinafter provided.
B. If the proposed method of soil erosion control is by revegetation, the specifications for the work
shall provide that any layer of topsoil over the area to be excavated, graded or filled shall be set
aside and retained on the premises in sufficient quantity to cover all surfaces which will remain
exposed, except rock, to a depth of at least four inches (4"), with topsoil added if necessary to
make up any deficiency. The specifications shall also provide that at the completion of respreading
of topsoil it shall immediately be harrowed or raked to establish a seedbed and shall be seeded for
grass, permanent pasture mixture, or other approved fast growing vegetation and shall be
repeated as often as necessary until the area is stabilized.
C. In the case of extended operations, except for access drives, and the accrual work area, the
completed portion of the excavation, filling or grading operation shall be subject to the provisions of
subsection B of this section and the operation shall be completed prior to the reissuance of the
permit under subsection 7.6.5C of this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 504/525
D. Where a permit has been issued for the excavation of a lake or pond, the provisions of this section
applicable to seeding shall not apply to that part of the excavation below the high water mark of
such lake or pond.
E. The applicant shall notify the director of public works of the following, when and as completed: 1)
rough grading, 2) final grading before seeding, and 3) all reestablishment and construction work.
Upon such notification, the director shall make field inspections on the site before rough grading,
after final grading, before seeding and at completion to determine if work in progress and the
completed operation have been performed in accordance with this chapter. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-
2004)
7.6.9: PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES:
No excavation, grading or filling shall be permitted which would interfere with the natural drainage of
the general area surrounding the site. All existing watercourses shall be preserved, except that such
watercourses may be relocated or piped; provided, that there will not thereby be created any
interference with the riparian and drainage rights or easements of other property owners, and provided
further that no drainage shall be made onto public land or connected with public facilities without the
express approval of the city council, except with respect to land controlled by the board of education,
in which event such approval shall be obtained from the board of education. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
Chapter 7
HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION REGULATIONS
7.7.1: PURPOSES AND INTENT:
The purposes and intent of this chapter are as follows:
A. To identify, designate, protect, preserve, and encourage the restoration, rehabilitation, and adaption
for continued use of those properties and structures which represent or reflect the prehistoric,
historic, architectural, cultural, artistic, social, economic, ethnic, or political heritage of the nation,
state, county, or city, or which may be representative of an architectural or engineering type
inherently valuable for the study of style, period, craftsmanship, method of construction or use of
indigenous materials.
B. To safeguard the historic, aesthetic, and cultural heritage of the city as embodied and reflected in
such structures, landscape features, and areas seen in such examples as houses, commercial
buildings, public buildings, factories, cemeteries, barns, bridges, and fences.
C. To stabilize and improve the economic vitality and value of designated landmarks and historic
preservation districts in particular and the city in general.
D. To educate the general public, government officials, and commercial and industrial interests as to
the need to foster historic preservation through the provisions of the preservation ordinance.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 505/525
E. To work with the city community development department and with other city commissions in the
development and application of a historic preservation program.
F. To foster civic pride in the technological accomplishments, beauty, and nobility of the past.
G. To protect and enhance the attraction of the city to tourists and visitors, and to support the retention
of and stimulus to business and industry.
H. To strengthen the economy and enhance the tax base of the city.
I. To promote the use of historic preservation districts, landmarks, and landscapes for the education,
pleasure, and welfare of the citizens of the city.
J. To assist property owners in obtaining the financial benefits and incentives offered by achieving
certified local government status from the state of Illinois historic preservation agency. (Ord. 2604,
1-16-1996)
7.7.2: DEFINITIONS:
ALTERATION: Any act or process which changes one or more of the exterior architectural features of
a structure, including, but not limited to, the erection, construction, reconstruction of any
"improvement" as defined herein.
ARCHITECTURAL SIGNIFICANCE: The distinctive characteristics of a type, period, style, or method
of construction or use of indigenous construction, or representing the work of an important builder,
designer, architect, or craftsman who has contributed to the development of the community, McHenry
County, state of Illinois, or the nation.
CATEGORY 1 MINOR PROJECT: All projects which do not require a building permit including, but not
limited to, awnings, windows and doors (with no change in the size of the opening), paint, masonry
maintenance (cleaning, sealing or tuckpointing), dumpster enclosures, gutters, landscape, fencing,
sidewalks, parking, reshingling, removing inappropriate and/or nonoriginal siding, and replication or
restoration of original siding, and simple repairs affecting a nominated or designated landmark or
property within a nominated or designated historic preservation district. Category 1 minor projects
include storefront and facade renovations that involve the replacement of nonoriginal or nonsignificant
storefront facade materials, if this work does not require a building permit.
CATEGORY 2 MAJOR PROJECT: All projects which require a building permit such as the creation of
new openings, enlarging window or doors, new construction, additions, demolition, storefront or
facade alterations, and the replacement of historic elements affecting a nominated or designated
landmark or property within a nominated or designated historic preservation district. Category 2 major
projects include all projects which permanently cover, alter, or destroy original or significant siding
materials or architectural features except for simple repairs, even if a building permit is not otherwise
required.
CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS: A certificate issued by the department (category 1) or the
commission (category 2) indicating its approval of plans affecting a nominated or designated landmark
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 506/525
or property within a nominated or designated historic preservation district.
CERTIFICATE OF HARDSHIP: A certificate issued by the commission allowing the alteration,
construction, demolition, or removal affecting a nominated or designated landmark or property within a
nominated or designated historic preservation district after a certificate of appropriateness has been
denied and after the owner(s) has (have) provided proof that all reasonable use of, or return from, the
property would be lost.
CITY COUNCIL: The city council of the city of Woodstock, Illinois.
COMMISSION: The city of Woodstock historic preservation commission.
CONSTRUCTION: The act of adding an addition to a structure or the erection of a new principal
and/or accessory structure on a lot or property.
DEMOLITION: Any act or process which destroys, in part or in whole, any improvement.
DEMOLITION BY NEGLECT: Neglect in the maintenance of any landmark and/or building or structure
within a historic preservation district resulting in the deterioration of that building to the extent that it
creates a hazardous or unsafe condition as determined by the building officer of the city of
Woodstock.
DEPARTMENT: The city's community development department.
DIRECTOR: The director of the city's community development department.
EXTERIOR ARCHITECTURAL FEATURES: The architectural character and general composition of
the exterior of a building or structure, including, but not limited to, the kind and texture of the building
exterior, and the type, design and character of all windows, doors, light fixtures, signs and appurtenant
elements.
HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICT: A place or area so designated by ordinance of the city
council, pursuant to the procedures and requirements prescribed hereunder.
HISTORIC STRUCTURE: Any structure or building designated as a landmark or located in a historic
preservation district.
IMPROVEMENT: Any building, structure, wall, fence, steps, paving, gate, sign, light fixture, general
arrangement of place or area, the kind of texture or quality of building material, landscaping or
landscape architecture, or work of art which may be erected upon or proposed to be erected upon any
specific real estate.
LANDMARK: Any improvement designated as a landmark by ordinance of the city council, pursuant to
procedures and requirements prescribed herein.
LANDMARK SITE: A parcel or part thereof on which is situated a "landmark" as described herein, and
any abutting parcel or part thereof used and constituting part of the premises on which the landmark is
situated.
ORDINARY MAINTENANCE: That which does not alter the exterior features of a historic site or
historic resource within a historic preservation district. Exterior features include the architectural style,
design, and general arrangement of the exterior; the nature, and texture of building materials; and the
type and style of all windows, doors, light fixtures, signs, and similar items found on, or related to, the
exterior of a historic site or historic resource within a historic preservation district. Ordinary
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 507/525
maintenance is that which will have no material effect on the historical, architectural, cultural, or
archaeological value of the historic site or resource within a historic preservation district.
OWNER OF RECORD: All of the holders of fee simple title, or an estate of such duration and
enjoyment as to be substantially equivalent to fee simple title, as indicated by documents recorded in
the office of the recorder of deeds of McHenry County, Illinois.
PRESERVATION RESTRICTION: A right, whether or not stated in the form of a restriction, easement,
covenant or condition, in any deed, will or other instrument, executed by or on behalf of the owner(s)
of the land or in any order of taking, appropriate to the preservation of areas, places, building or
structures to forbid or limit acts of demolition, alteration, use or other acts detrimental to the
preservation of the buildings, places or areas designated pursuant to the provisions hereunder as a
landmark or as within a historic preservation district.
REPLACEMENT OF MATERIALS: The removal of an existing element on a building and affixes a
replica in its place using materials that are compatible with the historic structure.
SIMPLE REPAIR: The repair of existing elements which keep the original fabric and fix the problem
using materials compatible with the existing element and replaces minor part(s). (Ord. 2604, 1-16-
1996; amd. Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002; Ord. 06-0-10, 2-7-2006)
7.7.3: DESIGNATION OF LANDMARKS:
7.7.3.1: NOMINATION OF LANDMARKS:
Any person, group of persons, or association, including the Woodstock historic preservation
commission may submit an application to the commission requesting that a building, structure, place,
or area within the city be designated as a landmark.
Upon nomination or designation of landmark status, such building, structure, place, or area shall be
afforded the protection of the historic preservation ordinance. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.3.2: CRITERIA FOR NOMINATION:
The commission may recommend to the city council the designation of landmark, upon written proof of
owner notification, after a thorough investigation results in a determination that a property, structure, or
alteration retains the integrity and spirit of the original design, provided that it is:
A. Located within the corporate boundaries of the city; and
B. Is at least fifty (50) years old; and
It meets one or more of the following criteria:
C. It has character, interest, or value which is part of the development, heritage, or cultural
characteristic(s) of the city, the county, the state, or the nation;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 508/525
D. Its location is a site of a significant local, county, state, or national event;
E. It is identified with a person or persons who significantly contributed to the development of the city,
county, state, or the nation;
F. It embodies distinguishing characteristics of an architectural style valuable for the study of a period,
type, method of construction, or use of indigenous materials;
G. It is identified with the work of a master builder, designer, architect, or landscape architect whose
individual work has influenced the development of the city, county, state, or the nation;
H. It embodies elements of design, detailing, materials, or craftsmanship that render it architecturally
significant;
I. It embodies design elements that make it structurally or architecturally innovative;
J. It has a unique location or singular physical characteristics that make it an established or familiar
visual feature;
K. It has character which is a particularly fine or unique example of a utilitarian structure, including, but
not limited to, commercial buildings, factories, industrial buildings or structures, including pump
houses or viaducts, with a high level of integrity or architectural significance;
L. It establishes a sense of time and place unique to the City;
M. It is suitable for preservation or restoration;
N. It is included in the National Register of Historic Places and/or the Illinois Register of Historic
Places;
O. It has yielded, or may be likely to yield, information important to pre-history or other areas of
archaeological significance;
P. It is an exceptional example of a historic or vernacular style or one of few remaining in the City.
The applicant for landmark designation must demonstrate convincingly the applicability of one or
more of the criteria outlined above, providing ample documentation to support all statements and
assertions. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.3.3: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 509/525
A. Application forms shall be obtained from the Community Development Department.
B. Completed forms shall be submitted to the Community Development Department which shall
forward them to the Commission for their consideration. Persons wishing guidance or advice prior
to completing an application may contact the staff of the Department. A filing fee may be required.
C. The information which must be submitted shall include, but is not limited to the following:
1. The name(s) and mailing addresses of the individuals who last paid property tax;
2. The legal description and common street address of the property proposed for designation;
3. A map drawn to scale delineating the boundaries and location of the property proposed for
designation;
4. A written statement describing the property and setting forth reasons in support of the proposed
designation;
5. A list and photographs of significant exterior architectural features;
6. A statement indicating whether or not the owner(s) consent(s) to the landmark designation.
(Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.3.4: DESIGNATION PROCESS:
A. All reasonable efforts shall be made to secure the written consent of the owner(s) before
proceeding with the designation. The owner(s) of record of any property for which an application is
made (unless the request is made by the owner) shall be informed within seven (7) working days
of receipt of such application. A landmark can be nominated or designated without the consent of
the owners.
B. Upon receipt of the completed application, the Commission shall conduct a public hearing within
forty five (45) days. Notice of the public hearing will be made to the owner(s) of record by certified
mail, and to adjacent property owners and the person(s) filing the application by regular mail.
Notice will also be placed in a newspaper of general circulation of the date, time, place, and
purpose of the public hearing no less than fifteen (15) but not more than twenty nine (29) days
prior to the hearing. A sign shall be placed on a property within full view of a public right of way,
giving notice of the date, time, place, and purpose of the public hearing for no less than seven (7)
days prior to the hearing.
C. At the public hearing, oral or written testimony pertinent to the proposed designation shall be taken
from any person or organization.
D. A decision shall be made within sixty (60) days following the date of the closing of the public
hearing. The evaluation and recommendation of the Commission, and all pertinent information
shall be submitted to the City Council within thirty (30) days of the Commission's decision.
Decisions are made by a simple majority of Commission members in attendance.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 510/525
E. The owner(s) of record shall be notified promptly in a letter of the decision of the commission and
the date of the City Council meeting at which the application will be addressed.
F. To override a recommendation of the Commission, a favorable vote of three-fourths (3/4) of all the
elected members of the City Council is necessary. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.3.5: NOTICE OF DESIGNATION:
Within five (5) working days after designation by ordinance of the City Council, and on a yearly basis
thereafter, the Commission shall notify the owner(s) of the landmark site, and tenant(s) if any, that it
has been designated as such, and that an owner must possess a Certificate of Appropriateness
before he or she can procure a building permit, or otherwise materially affect the exterior appearance
of the property. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.4: DESIGNATION OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICTS:
7.7.4.1: NOMINATION OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICTS:
Any person, group of persons, or association, including the Woodstock Historic Preservation
Commission, may submit an application to the commission requesting that a defined geographic area
be designated as an historic preservation district.
Upon nomination or designation of historic preservation district status, each building, structure, place,
or area shall be afforded the protection of the Historic Preservation Ordinance. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.4.2: CRITERIA FOR NOMINATION:
The Commission may recommend to the City Council the designation of an historic preservation
district, upon written proof of notification of the owner(s), that the following requirements shall be met:
A. In the case of a new district:
1. The geographic area which is the subject of the application has definable boundaries in the form
of natural features or existing physical improvements; and
2. A visual sense of history exists within the proposed boundaries; and
3. The buildings, places or areas within the proposed district, by their inclusion therein, are of
sufficient historic significance to be worthy of rehabilitation, restoration, and preservation
because either:
a. The proposed district contains within definable geographic boundaries one or more landmarks
along with such other buildings, places or areas, which, while not of such historic significance
to be designated as landmarks, nevertheless contribute to the overall visual characteristics of
the landmark or landmarks located within the district; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 511/525
b. The proposed district contains within definable geographic boundaries such buildings, places
or areas which, while not of such individual significance to be designated as landmarks,
nevertheless, as an aggregate, possess historic significance for the City in:
(1) Establishing a sense of time and place unique to the City; or
(2) Exemplifying or reflecting the cultural, social, economic, political, or architectural history of
the Nation, the State, or the City; or
(3) Representing the distinguishing characteristics of an architectural type which is inherently
valuable for studying a period, style, method of construction, indigenous materials or unique
craftsmanship.
B. In the case of addition to existing historic preservation districts:
1. The historic preservation district, after inclusion of the property or properties proposed for
addition, constitutes one contiguous area without "holes" or "gaps", defined by natural or existing
improved boundaries.
2. The proposed addition does not impair the visual sense of history within the existing historic
preservation district.
3. Properties within the proposed addition possess historic significance or characteristics
compatible with that found to exist in the original district at the time it was designated.
C. In the case of deletion from existing historic preservation districts:
1. The historic preservation district, after removal of the property or properties proposed for
deletion, constitutes one contiguous area without "holes" or "gaps", defined by natural or existing
improved boundaries.
2. The historic preservation district, after removal of the property or properties proposed for
deletion, retains the historic significance or historic characteristics found to exist at the time the
district was originally designated.
3. The property or properties proposed for deletion do not materially contribute to the historic
significance or historic characteristics found to exist at the time the district was originally
designated. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.4.3: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
A. Application forms shall be obtained from the Community Development Department.
B. Completed forms shall be submitted to the Community Development Department which shall
forward them to the Commission for their consideration. Persons wishing guidance or advice prior
to completing an application may contact the staff of the Department. A filing fee may be required.
C. The information which must be submitted shall include, but is not limited to the following:
1. The names and mailing addresses of all the individuals who last paid property taxes;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 512/525
2. The legal description of the boundary of the proposed district and the common street address of
each of the properties proposed for designation;
3. A map delineating the boundary and location of the area proposed for designation;
4. A written statement describing the district and setting forth reasons in support of the proposed
designation;
5. A list and photographs of significant exterior architectural features;
6. A statement of which owners consent to the historic preservation district designation and which
do not. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.4.4: DESIGNATION PROCESS:
A. All reasonable efforts shall be made to secure the written consent of the owner(s) before
proceeding with the designation. The owner(s) of record of any property for which an application is
made shall be informed within ten (10) working days of receipt of such application. A property may
be included in a historic preservation district without the owner(s) consent.
B. Upon receipt of the completed application, the Commission shall conduct a public hearing within
forty five (45) days. Notice of the public hearing will be made to the owner(s) of record by certified
mail, and to adjacent property owners and the person(s) filing the application by regular mail.
Notice will also be placed in a newspaper of general circulation of the date, time, place, and
purpose of the public hearing no less than fifteen (15) but not more than twenty nine (29) days
prior to the hearing. A sign shall be placed on a property within the proposed district, within full
view of a public right of way, giving notice of the date, time, place, and purpose of the public
hearing for no less than seven (7) days prior to the hearing.
C. At the public hearing, oral or written testimony pertinent to the proposed designation shall be taken
from any person or organization.
D. A decision shall be made within sixty (60) days following the date of the closing of the public
hearing. The evaluation and recommendation of the commission, and all pertinent information shall
be submitted to the city council within thirty (30) days of the decision of the commission. Decisions
are made by a simple majority of commission members in attendance.
E. The owner(s) of record shall be notified promptly in a letter of the decision of the commission and
the date of the city council meeting at which the application will be addressed.
F. To override a recommendation of the commission, a favorable vote of three-fourths (3/4) of all the
elected members of the city council is necessary. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.4.5: NOTICE OF DESIGNATION:
Within thirty (30) days after designation, and on a yearly basis thereafter, the commission shall notify
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 513/525
the owner(s), and tenants if any, of the properties in the historic preservation district that it has been
designated as such, and that a certificate of appropriateness or a certificate of hardship must be
issued by the commission before an owner or tenant can materially affect the exterior appearance of a
property or obtain a building permit for alterations. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.4.6: RECOGNITION OF EXISTING HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICT:
The following area, which includes the Woodstock square historic district as listed on the National
Register of Historic Places in December 1982, is designated as the historic downtown business
preservation district and is legally described as:
Part of the Southwest Quarter of Section 5, Township 44 North, Range 7 East of the 3rd Principal
Meridian, beginning at the intersection of the centerline of South Street with the intersection with the
centerline of Seminary Avenue; thence northerly along the centerline of Seminary Avenue to the
intersection with the centerline of Hutchins Street; thence westerly along the centerline of Hutchins
Street to the intersection with the centerline of Madison Street; thence northerly along the centerline of
Madison Street to the intersection with the centerline of Newell Street; thence westerly along the
centerline of Newell Street to the intersection with the centerline of Clay Street; thence northerly along
the centerline of Clay Street to the centerline of First Street; thence westerly along the centerline of
First Street to the centerline of the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad right-of-way; thence
southeasterly along said right-of-way to the centerline of Wheeler Street; thence southerly and
southwesterly along the centerline of Wheeler Street to the intersection with the centerline of
Washington Street (Illinois Route 120); thence northwesterly along the centerline of Washington Street
390 feet to a point; thence southwesterly perpendicular to the centerline of Washington Street from the
last described point 285 feet to a point; thence westerly 386 feet to a point, said point being on the
west line of said Section 5; thence southerly from the last described point to the centerline of Lincoln
Avenue; thence easterly along the centerline of Lincoln Avenue to the centerline of Tryon Street;
thence southerly along the centerline of Tryon Street to the intersection of the centerline with Judd
Street; thence westerly along the centerline of Judd Street to the intersection with the centerline of
Hayward Street; thence southerly along the centerline of Hayward Street to the intersection with the
centerline of South Street; thence easterly along the centerline of South Street to the place of
beginning all within the City of Woodstock, McHenry County, Illinois.
(Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.5: CATEGORY 2 MAJOR PROJECT:
7.7.5.1: CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS:
A. No alteration, new construction, improvement or demolition designated as a category 2 major
project shall be allowed within an existing or proposed historic preservation district or upon an
existing or proposed landmark unless a certificate of appropriateness has been issued by the
commission.
B. The building and zoning officer shall not issue a building permit or demolition permit for any
landmark or any historic structure unless a certificate of appropriateness has been issued by the
commission.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 514/525
C. Any category 2 major project that affects the exterior architectural features visible from any public
way shall require a certificate of appropriateness. (Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002)
D. A certificate of appropriateness approval card shall be issued by the department and shall be
prominently displayed on the property until all exterior work is completed. (Ord. 06-0-11, 2-7-2006)
7.7.5.2: CRITERIA FOR GRANTING A CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS:
A. The commission and the community development department shall consider the following criteria,
based on the secretary of the interior's standard for rehabilitation, and any historic preservation
guidelines approved by the city council when reviewing an application for a certificate of
appropriateness: (Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002)
1. A property shall be used for its historic purpose or to be placed in a new use that requires
minimal change to the defining characteristics of the building and its site and environment.
2. The historic character of a property shall be retained and preserved. The removal of historic
materials or alteration of features and spaces that characterize a property shall be avoided.
3. Each property shall be recognized as a physical record of its time, place, and use. Changes that
create a false sense of historical development, such as adding conjectural features or
architectural elements from other buildings, shall not be undertaken.
4. Most properties change over time; those changes that have acquired historic significance in their
own right shall be retained and preserved.
5. Distinctive features, finishes, and construction techniques or examples of craftsmanship that
characterize a property shall be preserved.
6. Deteriorated historic features shall be repaired rather than replaced. Where the severity of
deterioration requires replacement of a distinctive feature, the new feature shall match the old in
design, color, texture, and other visual qualities and, where possible, materials. Replacement of
missing features shall be substantiated by documentary, physical, or pictorial evidence.
7. Chemical or physical treatments, such as sandblasting, that cause damage to historic materials
shall not be used. The surface cleaning of structures, if appropriate, shall be undertaken using
the gentlest means possible.
8. Significant archeological resources affected by a project shall be protected and preserved. If
such resources must be disturbed, mitigation measures shall be undertaken.
9. New additions, exterior alterations, or related new construction shall not destroy historic
materials that characterize the property. The new work shall be differentiated from the old and
shall be compatible with the massing, size, scale, and architectural features to protect the
historic integrity of the property and its environment.
10. New additions and adjacent or related new construction shall be undertaken in such a manner
that if removed in the future, the essential form and integrity of the historic property and its
environment would be unimpaired. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
B. The commission shall consider the following architectural design elements when reviewing plans
for a category 2 major project: (Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 515/525
1. Height And Roof: The height of proposed buildings and structures shall be visually compatible
with the style and character of the surrounding structures. The roof shape shall be compatible
with the architectural style of the landmark and the surrounding structures to which it is visually
related.
2. Proportion Of Front Facade: The relationship of the width to the height of the front elevation
shall be visually compatible with buildings, public ways, and places to which it is visually related.
3. Proportion Of Openings: The proportion of window and doors shall be compatible with the
architectural style and character of the adjacent building or buildings within the historic
preservation district.
4. Relationship Of Spacing And Buildings: The relationship of a building or structure to the open
space between it and adjoining buildings shall be visually compatible with the buildings, public
ways, and places to which it is visually related.
5. Scale: The size and mass of buildings and structures in relation to open spaces, windows, door
openings, porches and other projections shall be visually compatible with the buildings, public
ways and places to which they are visually related.
6. Materials, Textures, Colors, And Architectural Detail: The relationship of the materials, textures,
colors, and architectural details should be compatible with the predominant materials used in the
existing building or in the surrounding buildings and structures to which it is related.
7. Directional Expression: A building shall be visually compatible with the buildings, public ways,
and places to which it is visually related in its directional character whether this be vertical,
horizontal, or nondirectional character.
8. Landscape: Landscape and appurtenances including signs, fences, accessory structures and
pavings shall be visually compatible with the buildings, public ways and places to which they are
visually related. Landscape is not considered for one- and two-family dwelling units. (Ord. 2604,
1-16-1996)
7.7.5.3: ORDINARY MAINTENANCE:
Cosmetic or ordinary maintenance items are not subject to a certificate of appropriateness except
significant changes in exterior schemes for nonresidential uses. Exterior siding, porch improvements,
railings, fences, storm windows, storm doors, screens, exterior lighting, and similar items shall be
subject to this chapter. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.5.4: DEMOLITION:
Before granting a request for a certificate to demolish a structure which has been designated a
landmark or a structure within a historic preservation district, the commission must find that at least
one of the following conditions exist:
A. The demolition request is for an inappropriate addition, or a nonsignificant accessory structure,
provided that the demolition will not adversely affect those parts of a building or buildings which are
significant as determined by the commission; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 516/525
B. The demolition request is for a noncontributing building and the demolition will not adversely affect
the character of the historic preservation district; or
C. The building and zoning officer for the city certifies that demolition is required for the public safety
because of an unsafe or dangerous condition; or
D. The property owner shows that failure to allow demolition would involve a substantial hardship,
economic or otherwise, pursuant to the provisions of section 7.7.5.6 of this chapter. (Ord. 2604, 1-
16-1996)
7.7.5.5: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
A. Category 2 major project application forms, which are available from the department, shall be
completed and submitted to the department. The department will forward the completed
application to the commission for its review. Department staff will be available to assist applicants
in completing their applications. A filing fee may be required.
B. In addition to the documents required for the issuance of a building permit, the application shall
include, but is not limited to, the following:
1. Structure Plan: A drawing including the color and type of surface materials showing the front and
rear elevations, and side elevations where there are no adjoining buildings.
2. Landscape Plan: A drawing showing the location, dimensions and arrangements of all open
spaces and yards, including type and size of planting materials, color and type of surface
materials, methods to be employed for screening and proposed grades. A landscape plan is not
required for single-family dwellings.
3. Plan Details: All plans submitted shall contain or show the following: height and roof; proportion
of front facade; proportion of openings; relationship of spacing and buildings; scale; materials,
textures, colors, and architectural detail; and directional expression.
4. Written Statement: A written statement describing the proposed construction, alteration, addition
or demolition and setting forth the reasons in support of the proposed action.
5. Demolition Applications: Demolition applications shall include photographs of all exterior
elevations and significant interior details.
C. The commission shall review the completed application at a regularly scheduled meeting and shall
approve, approve with modifications, or deny the application within sixty (60) days of the meeting;
in the event the application is continued to another meeting(s), the sixty (60) day deadline shall be
after the last meeting. Written notice of the commission's decision shall be sent to the applicant
within seven (7) days of the decision.
D. A denial, or approval with modifications, shall be accompanied by a statement containing the
reasons for the decision. The commission may make recommendations to the applicant that would
cause the commission to reconsider the application.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 517/525
E. A denial, or approval with modifications, may be appealed pursuant to the appeal process in
section 2.9.6 of this code. (Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002)
7.7.5.6: HARDSHIP:
A. A certificate of hardship shall be issued by the commission upon a finding by it that all reasonable
use of, or return from, a designated landmark or property within a historic preservation district
would be denied a property owner as a result of the disapproval of a certificate of appropriateness.
B. The commission may solicit expert testimony, or the applicant may submit evidence, concerning
any of the following items at the time of the public hearing on the certificate of appropriateness:
1. Any substantial decrease in the fair market value of the property as a result of the denial of the
certificate of appropriateness;
2. Any substantial decrease in the pretax or after tax return to owner(s) of record or other investors
in the property as a result of the denial of the certificate of appropriateness;
3. Any additional cost of work necessary to comply with the standards and criteria for the issuance
of a certificate of appropriateness;
4. In the case of a proposed demolition, the economic feasibility of rehabilitation or reuse of the
existing structure on the property.
C. The commission may adopt procedural rules concerning the types of information, evidence or
expert testimony that it considers necessary to make a determination on an application for a
certificate of hardship.
D. Upon a finding by the commission that without approval of the proposed work all reasonable use of,
or return from, a designated landmark or property within a historic preservation district will be
denied a property owner, then the application shall be delayed for a period not to exceed sixty (60)
days. During this period of delay, the commission shall investigate plans and make
recommendations to the city council to allow for a reasonable use of, or return from, the property,
or to otherwise preserve the subject property. Such plans and recommendations may include, but
are not limited to: a relaxation of the provisions of this chapter, a reduction in real property taxes,
financial assistance, building code modifications, and/or changes in zoning regulations.
E. If by the end of this sixty (60) day period, the commission has found that without approval of the
proposed work, the property cannot be put to a reasonable use or the owner cannot obtain a
reasonable economic return therefrom, then the commission shall issue a certificate of hardship
approving the proposed work. If the commission finds otherwise, it shall deny the application for a
certificate of hardship, and notify the applicant by mail of the final denial.
F. In granting a certificate of hardship in such circumstances, the commission may prescribe any
conditions or limitations that may be necessary to minimize the adverse impact of the requested
alteration or demolition.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 518/525
G. Appeal from the denial of a certificate of hardship may be made to the city council in the same
manner as an appeal from the issuance or denial of a certificate of appropriateness. (Ord. 2604, 1-
16-1996)
7.7.5.7: ISSUANCE OF PERMITS:
No building permit shall be issued for the alteration, construction, improvement, or demolition of any
building or structure within an existing or proposed historic preservation district or upon an existing or
proposed landmark, until all requirements of this chapter, as well as applicable construction codes of
the city, have been met. A certificate of appropriateness or a certificate of hardship shall be required
prior to the issuance of such a permit and shall be valid for a period of one year. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-
1996)
7.7.5.8: PENALTIES:
A. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the fines and penalties set
forth in section 1.4.1 of this code. If any person, firm, organization or corporation receiving a
citation for violating any provision of this chapter fails to pay, settle or adjust the fine specified
herein, then adjudication procedures may be initiated in accordance with title 1, chapter 7, article L
of this code or with a court of competent jurisdiction, and such processes as necessary shall
commence. (Ord. 09-0-24, 4-21-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
B. Any person, firm or corporation who alters, repairs, relocates or demolishes by neglect any
landmark or any building or structure within a historic preservation district without complying with
the provisions of this chapter shall be required to restore the building or structure and its site to its
appearance prior to the violation. This civil remedy shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any
criminal prosecution and penalty contained in this section.
C. In the case of an unauthorized demolition of a landmark or any building or structure within a historic
preservation district, the city council may prohibit the issuance of a building permit for the subject
property for a period of up to five (5) years after the date of the demolition. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996;
amd. Ord. 09-0-24, 4-21-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
7.7.5.9: PREVENTION OF DEMOLITION BY NEGLECT:
The commission, on its own initiative, may file a petition with the building and zoning officer requesting
that the department proceed under public safety and housing codes to require correction of defects or
repairs to eligible or designated historic landmarks or to buildings or structures in historic preservation
districts so that such landmarks, buildings, and structures shall be preserved and protected in
accordance with the purposes of this chapter. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.6: CATEGORY 1 MINOR PROJECTS:
Category 1 minor projects shall not be undertaken without the issuance of a certificate of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 519/525
appropriateness by the director. The criteria for a category 1 minor project certificate of
appropriateness shall be as follows:
A. Forms; Fee: Category 1 minor project application forms, which are available from the department,
shall be completed and submitted to the department. Department staff will be available to assist
applicants in completing their applications. A filing fee may be required.
B. Written Statement: A written statement describing the proposed category 1 minor project which
includes the reasons in support of the proposed action shall accompany the application.
C. Approval Or Denial; Notice: The director shall approve, approve with modifications, or deny the
application within sixty (60) days after it has been submitted. Written notice of the director's
decision shall be sent to the applicant within seven (7) days of the decision.
D. Reconsideration: A denial, or approval with modifications, shall be accompanied by a statement
containing the reasons for the decision. The director may make recommendations to the applicant
that would cause the director to reconsider the application.
E. Appeal Of Decision: In the event the application is denied the applicant may appeal the decision to
the commission pursuant to section 2.9.6 of this code. (Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002)
Chapter 8
PROJECT REVIEW
7.8.1: PROJECT REVIEW REQUIRED:
To promote the harmonious development of real estate within the city, and to ensure that such
properties are developed in accordance with the preamble of ordinance 1470, project plans and
project reviews are required, in addition to the requirements of all other regulations of the municipal
code of the city prior to the issuance of building permits for construction of any of the following types of
improvements: (Ord. 1470, 11-7-1978; amd. Ord. 01-O-41, 11-6-2001)
A. Required land improvements of a subdivision within the city's planning and subdivision jurisdiction
limits, but limited to entrance features, common areas and/or open spaces prior to the construction
of any subdivision improvement.
B. Multiple-family dwellings for more than two (2) families.
C. Public, religious and institutional buildings.
D. Hospitals, clinics and nursing homes.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 520/525
E. Hotels, motels and motor courts.
F. Commercial and industrial buildings. (Ord. 1470, 11-7-1978)
G. Appurtenant structures to above types of projects including, but not limited to, parking areas,
loading docks, driveways, guardhouses, porches, canopies, courtyards and service yards. (Ord.
1470, 11-7-1978; amd. Ord. 2613, 3-6-1996)
H. Planned development as required by the zoning ordinance. (Ord. 1470, 11-7-1978)
7.8.2: SCOPE AND JURISDICTION OF REVIEW:
All development of structure sites and improvements identified within section 7.8.1 of this chapter
within the city limits, except those sites under the jurisdiction of review by the historic preservation
commission, as determined by this code, will be examined with respect to each of the following
aspects: (Ord. 01-O-41, 11-6-2001)
A. Compatibility of building and landscape design with surrounding development, existing and future.
B. Traffic and traffic patterns, vehicular and pedestrian, both internally on the site and externally,
especially in relation to major thoroughfares.
C. Preservation of existing trees, shrubs and/or historic amenities.
D. Site grading and topography.
E. Provision for open space.
F. Screening between incompatible uses.
G. Effectiveness of exterior lighting and impact upon surrounding properties and uses.
H. Water retention and runoff, in relation to adjoining properties and on site amenities.
I. Relationship of structures and improvements to public utilities, existing and proposed. (Ord. 1470,
11-7-1978)
J. Screening of refuse containers and accessory equipment. (Ord. 1470, 11-7-1978; amd. Ord. 2613,
3-6-1996)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 521/525
7.8.3: PROJECT PLAN REVIEW PROCEDURE:
A. Before an applicant files a building permit application to construct a building, structure or
improvement as defined in section 7.8.1 of this chapter, the applicant shall first file an application
for project review with the community development department ("department" for purposes of this
chapter). (Ord. 01-O-41, 11-6-2001)
B. Project review applications shall include those materials required by the plan commission
("commission" for purposes of this chapter) and the department. (Ord. 01-O-41, 11-6-2001; amd.
Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
C. Upon receipt of the required filings, the department shall review the application and plans for
compliance with the commission's standards and other city ordinances. The department shall
provide the applicant with a written report of its review no more than ten (10) business days after a
completed application has been filed. The written report shall include any problems or deficiencies.
The applicant may revise the application and resubmit it to the department or file for an appeal
pursuant to section 2.12.9 of this code.
D. Project review approval for an individual building site shall be revoked in the event the applicant
has not applied for a building permit for the construction of the proposed structure within one year
from the date of the approval of the project.
E. Project review approval for a planned development shall be valid as long as the preliminary and
final plats of planned development are valid.
F. Prior to approval of the project review application, the applicant may submit a building permit
application to the building and zoning officer. However, the building and zoning officer shall not
issue a building permit until written project plan approval has been received from the department
and the applicant has established an escrow or letter of credit with the city pursuant to section
7.8.4 of this chapter. (Ord. 01-O-41, 11-6-2001)
7.8.4: COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Prior to the issuance of any building permit, and subsequent to either project review or city council
action, the applicant for a building permit shall deposit with the building inspector an itemized
estimate of the cost of the installation of all site improvements, including, but not limited to,
landscaping, plantings, lighting, driveways, off street parking and loading facilities, sidewalks,
parkways and interior streets. In addition to the estimate of the costs of improvement, the applicant
shall also deposit an escrow deposit or letter of credit in a sum equal to one hundred ten percent
(110%) of the total improvement costs. Escrow accounts shall be created in an institution
designated by the city manager and shall be governed by the terms and provisions in accordance
with escrow agreements, forms of which are available in the city offices and subject to the approval
of the city manager and the city attorney. (Ord. 1470, 11-7-1978; amd. Ord. 01-0-41, 11-6-2001)
B. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued until all site improvements have been completed;
provided, however, that delays due to circumstances beyond the control of the builder, developer
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 522/525
or applicant may be recognized as a condition for the issuance of a temporary certificate of
occupancy, provided the buildings are otherwise complete. A temporary certificate of occupancy
shall not exceed six (6) months and is not renewable. A temporary certificate of occupancy may be
issued in such circumstances when an escrow deposit or letter of credit has been deposited
equaling one hundred ten percent (110%) of the cost of any unfinished improvements as
determined by the city's development engineer.
C. All escrow deposits and letters of credit shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
applicant and/or builder to complete all the improvements specified in the project plan. If, in the
judgment of the development engineer the completion of the improvement is being or has been
unreasonably delayed, the development engineer shall serve notice upon the builder or applicant
at his last known address. If, within thirty (30) days after the date of service of notice, the builder or
applicant has not completed the improvements, the development engineer shall cause the
completion of the improvements specified in the project plan, paying for such improvements out of
the balance of the escrow deposit or letter of credit.
D. Prior to the issuance of a final certificate of occupancy for any improvement, the building owner or
applicant shall file with his application for a final certificate of occupancy, a surety bond in an
amount equal to five percent (5%) of the total cost of the improvements as originally provided in
the cost estimate. The surety bond shall be conditioned upon the workmanlike installation of the
project plan improvements, and shall guarantee the work of the builder for a period of one year.
Evidence of the use of faulty material, negligence in construction or unworkmanlike performance, if
determined by the development engineer, shall cause forfeiture of the bond. The development
engineer shall then cause the repair and/or replacement of any faulty construction using the
proceeds of such bond to defray the cost of such repair or replacement. The remainder of any
bond forfeited for the repair or replacement of the improvements shall be returned to the builder.
Upon issuance of the final certificate of occupancy and the filing of the required surety bond with
the city, all previous escrow accounts shall terminate and any balance returned to the applicant or
builder.
E. Any decision, ruling or regulation of the development engineer may be appealed to the city council.
The city council may sustain or overrule the development engineer's decision, ruling or regulation.
(Ord. 01-0-41, 11-6-2001)
7.8.5: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense, plus
reasonable attorney fees incurred by the city. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each
day during or on which such violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 01-0-41, 11-6-2001)
Chapter 9
FLOODPLAIN REGULATIONS
(Rep. by Ord. 06-0-93, 12-5-2006)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 523/525
Chapter 10
CAPITAL EXPANSION FEE
(Rep. by letter dated 6-22-1998)
Chapter 11
DEVELOPMENT FEES
7.11.1: ZONING FEES:
The following fees are hereby established for the following services:
A. Zoning Amendment (Text Only): $500.00;
B. Zoning Amendment (Map/Rezoning): Base fee of $500.00 plus $50.00 for each acre;
C. Zoning Special Use:
1. Planned developments: Base fee of $500.00 plus $50.00 for each acre;
2. All other special uses: Base fee of $500.00 plus $50.00 for each acre;
D. Temporary Use Permit: $50.00, payable at the time of permit issuance; and
E. Zoning, Variation And/Or Appeal: $125.00.
All fees specified herein shall be paid at the time of filing the first document or petition. (Ord. 04-0-
12, 1-6-2004)
7.11.2: SUBDIVISION FEES:
At the time of filing the first draft of a plat of subdivision a base fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00)
plus fifty dollars ($50.00) for each acre shall be paid to the city. (Ord. 04-0-12, 1-6-2004)
7.11.3: JOINT FEES:
For any application involving more than one of the items listed in sections 7.11.1 and 7.11.2 of this
chapter, the fee shall be calculated on the basis of the highest fee plus five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for each additional item. (Ord. 04-0-12, 1-6-2004)
7.11.4: DEVELOPMENT REVIEW DEPOSITS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 524/525
A. Petitions for rezoning and/or annexation, the subdivision or resubdivision of land for special uses or
planned developments shall be accompanied with a deposit as provided herein as security for the
reimbursement of review expenses incurred by the city. The amount of the deposit is determined
on the basis of total land area and shall consist of a base fee of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00)
plus the following sums:
1 to 20 acres $100.00 per acre
21 to 50 acres 90.00 per acre
51 to 100 acres 80.00 per acre
Over 100 acres A base fee of $8,000.00 plus $70.00 per acre.
B. Development review deposits are held by the city to cover the expense of reviewing both residential
and nonresidential development activities, including, but not limited to, subdivisions, planned
developments, special uses, rezonings and similar activities. The deposit shall be held by the city
until reimbursement of all costs for said activities has been received, at which time the balance on
the deposit will be refunded. In the event said costs are not reimbursed by the petitioner, the city
may use the deposit for reimbursement.
C. Where unusual problems or conditions are encountered which require additional review, the
community development director may require the deposit of additional funds to cover the cost of
such additional review. (Ord. 04-0-12, 1-6-2004)
7.11.5: ANNEXATION FEES:
The following fees are hereby established for the annexation of land into the city:
A. Land having an area of two (2) or more acres: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per acre, which
shall be paid at the time of annexation, and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per lot or unit,
whichever is greater, which shall be paid at the time the building permit is issued.
B. Annexation fees shall not be required for annexations which are initiated by the city. (Ord. 04-0-12,
1-6-2004)
7.11.6: CPI ADJUSTMENT:
The fees required in this chapter shall be subject to a "CPI adjustment" which shall be calculated on
January 1, 2005, and on January 1 in each year thereafter. Annually, the fees and cash contributions
shall be adjusted by the December_December percent change as published by the United States
department of labor's bureau of labor statistics, all items consumer price index ("CPI") for urban
consumers (1982-1984 = 100) for the Chicago consolidated metropolitan statistical area, Illinois. If any
index is calculated from a base different from the base period 1982-1984 = 100, such index shall be
converted to a base period of 1982-1984 = 100 by use of a conversion factor supplied by said bureau
of labor statistics. If the CPI is discontinued or replaced, such other governmental cost of living index
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=562 525/525
or computation which replaces the CPI shall be used in order to obtain substantially the same result
as would be obtained if the CPI had not been discontinued or replaced. (Ord. 04-0-12, 1-6-2004)
